0_0.text: FOR THE COMMON GOOD This is the manifesto of the Green Party of England and Wales.

0_1.text: It covers England and Wales, not the whole of the United Kingdom.

0_2.text: There are independent sister Green parties in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

0_3.text: Their websites are at www.scottishgreens.org.uk and www.greenpartyni.org The text in this document may be reproduced free of charge in any format or medium provided that it is reproduced accurately and not used in a misleading context.

0_4.text: Enquiries relating to the content of and the copyright in this document should be sent to: The Press Office The Green Party of England and Wales Development House 56–64 Leonard Street Britain has the wealth and resources to do great things.

0_5.text: We can build an economy that gives everyone their fair share of the world’s sixth-richest economy.

0_6.text: We can create a humane,  caring society that supports everyone’s needs.

0_7.text: And we can be a world leader in tackling the threat of climate change.

0_8.text: Sadly, our current politics – dominated by a small social group and the power of vested interests - are failing to realise this potential.

0_9.text: Our manifesto is a bold plan to create a more equal, more democratic society while doing our part to heal the planet,  which has been severely damaged by the effects of an unstable, unsustainable economy.

0_10.text: The austerity experiment has failed, as it did in the 1930s.

0_11.text: Most people have seen their living standards fall, while the top one perce333nt have increased their wealth.

0_12.text: Millions of households are living in poverty, in fear of want.

0_13.text: Our NHS is being handed over to the private sector, resulting ina more expensive and inferior service, while highly skilled staffare underpaid and treated without proper respect.

0_14.text: Governments of all colours – except Green – are failing to get to grips with climate change – the greatest challenge of our time.

0_15.text: Yet none of this is inevitable – there is a real alternative.

0_16.text: We do not apologise for being bold, ambitious or having a longterm vision for our country.

0_17.text: We certainly cannot continue as a nation on our current path.

0_18.text: We believe in restoring and extending our public services to create good jobs and meet the needs of a diverse population.

0_19.text: We believe in tackling climate change – taking serious action to limit our emissions at home and fi ghting for a fair global deal that secures humanity’s shared future.

0_20.text: We believe that we can build a society that works for the common good – and that those with the broadest shoulders really should pay their fair share towards it.

0_23.text: NATALIE BENNETT, GREEN PARTY LEADER We face three connected crises: Healing the planet from the effects of an unstable, unsustainable economy.

0_24.text: Creating a more equal society, reversing the trend towards a society divided between poverty and great wealth.

0_25.text: Creating truly democratic central and local government that governs for the common good.

0_26.text: To help heal the planet we will: Make achieving international agreement and action to limit climate change to below 2 degrees C of warming the major foreign policy priority.

0_27.text: Invest in an £85 billion public programme of renewable electricity generation, flood defences and building insulation.

0_28.text: Support local sustainable agriculture, with respect for animals and wild places.

0_29.text: Cut emissions by providing cheaper public transport and encouraging cycling and walking.

0_30.text: To become more equal and support our public services we will: End privatisation in the National Health Service, provide proper funding and free social care for the elderly, and combat the loneliness of the elderly.

0_31.text: Let teachers teach in properly funded democratically controlled schools, end SATS (Standard Assessment Tests), league tables and academies, and introduce free early education and childcare.

0_32.text: End tuition fees and cancel student debt.

0_33.text: Provide 500,000 social homes for rent over the five-year Parliament, control excessive rents and achieve house price stability.

0_34.text: Increase public spending to almost half of national income.

0_35.text: Make tax fair and crack down vigorously on tax avoidance and evasion.

0_36.text: Make the minimum wage a living wage for all, with a target of £10 per hour by 2020.

0_37.text: Make the highest wage in any organisation no more than ten times the lowest wage.

0_38.text: Create jobs and help small business by reducing employers’ National Insurance.

0_39.text: Bring rail back into public ownership.

0_40.text: Ensure respect for everyone whatever their ethnicity, gender, age, religious belief or non-belief, sexual orientation, class, size, disability or other status.

0_41.text: Create over 1 million jobs through our programme of green investment and restoring the public sector.

0_42.text: To create a truly democratic central and local government and a common citizenship and to promote peace based on democratic principles we will: Reform the benefits system.

0_44.text: Double Child Benefit and pay a pension that people can live on.

0_45.text: In the longer term, unite tax and benefits in a Basic Income system covering everyone.

0_46.text: Fund local government adequately and set democratically elected local authorities free to decide how to run education, public transport and other local services and to raise local taxes.

0_47.text: Bring in a fair voting system involving proportional representation.

0_48.text: Respect immigrants for the contribution they make and control immigration fairly.

0_49.text: Decommission the Trident nuclear deterrent system and promote peacemaking.

0_50.text: CHAPTER 1 Imagine a world of efficient and welcoming public services, coordinated action on climate change, equality, workers’ rights, an economy that works for people and planet at a human scale, restorative justice, and real care for the future, including young people now.

0_51.text: Imagine a world in which we protect the planet, its land and its oceans, and the plants, animals and people that live on it.

0_52.text: Imagine a world of security for all, of social security as opportunity not dependency, of lives lived more locally, with services close to where people need them and connected by affordable, energy-efficient public transport.

0_53.text: Imagine a government that believes in society, in our common humanity, in a culture of hope, and in our capacity to govern ourselves.

0_54.text: Imagine a government that believes in the common good, and that the best way of achieving it is by working for each other, rather than against each other.

0_56.text: That’s the world the Green Party wants to make real.

0_57.text: It’s also the world that most of us want.

0_58.text: When asked to vote for policies rather than parties or personalities, Green policies consistently come out on top.

0_59.text: And it’s so different from what we have now.

0_60.text: In consumer societies like ours, the common good has been forgotten.

0_61.text: So much government has been outsourced, put out to tender.

0_62.text: The reins have been handed over to the unfettered market and big corporations.

0_63.text: They are given as the reason why we can’t do things (such as bring the railways back into public ownership), why we must do things (lower taxes for the rich) and how we must do things (privatise public utilities).

0_64.text: When government has been active it’s been to make the rich richer and the poor poorer, while blocking action to prevent ecological catastrophe.

0_65.text: This has had disastrous consequences for the common good and for the protection of the natural world.

0_66.text: Back in the 1970s a determined assault on public life began, and the market became the model and measure of life.

0_67.text: Since then, successive governments of all colours have found ways to justify and deepen the role of the market in our lives.

0_69.text: Check out your nearest website or leaflet: you’re likely to be referred to as a customer, not a citizen.

0_71.text: Look at one of the most recent – Royal Mail.

0_72.text: This was owned by you and me, then it was sold for a song, with windfall profits for companies doing the only job the market really understands – maximising shareholder profit.

0_73.text: The public lost £1 billion, while George Osborne’s best man’s hedge fund pocketed £36 million.

0_75.text: This is what governments do when they’ve given up governing.

0_76.text: The result is a series of scandals from companies with increasingly infamous names – G4S, SERCO, ATOS – over which we have no control.

0_78.text: These are designed for companies looking to maximise profits through labour flexibility, but hopeless if you have regular bills to pay.

0_79.text: The market has been in charge for so long that it dominates our imagination and colours our view of ourselves.

0_80.text: The market is short sighted and short term.

0_81.text: It’s time for change – time to put the market to work for the common good and for people to be put back in charge.

0_82.text: The Green Party knows that: It’s hard to be a citizen when life tells you that you are a consumer; It’s hard to think of others when we are pitted against one another and sold the lie that individuals are to blame for their misfortunes; and It’s hard to think of the common good when it’s never mentioned.

0_83.text: Private interests have ruled the roost for far too long.

0_84.text: The result is a society scarred by inequalities of power and wealth, and a planet plundered of resources and damaged by pollution.

0_87.text: Those with power and wealth have done very well out of austerity: the UK’s wealthiest 1% grab more than anywhere else in Europe.

0_88.text: Politics has fragmented, public institutions have weakened, people’s lives are dominated by insecurity, and prejudice is rife.

0_89.text: We live in a price-tag society – and if you can’t pay the price, too bad.

0_90.text: Things that used to be done by public agencies have been outsourced.

0_91.text: Once it was a duty for all of us to look after the vulnerable when times were hard.

0_92.text: We paid taxes into a common fund to look after the poor, the weak, the old and the sick, and to educate the young.

0_93.text: This is what we did as citizens, bound together by what we share rather than separated by what divides us.

0_94.text: Now care has been outsourced to charity, to food banks.

0_95.text: Some think this is a sign of the Big Society, but we think it’s the sign of a failed society.

0_96.text: Individual charity is no substitute for collective justice.

0_97.text: For 40 years the rich and powerful have forced us to live in their fantasy world – a world that suits the minority not the majority.

0_98.text: This is a world imagined from the point of view of the healthy, the wealthy and the privileged.

0_99.text: Where there is a satisfying job just round the corner if only we could be bothered to look for it, where resources are limitless, and where the only obstacle to total fulfilment is the psychology of individual failure.

0_100.text: Meanwhile, in the real world where most of us live, we are young and old, sometimes poor and sick, jobs are scarce, the Earth groans under the weight of our demands, and the obstacles in the way of our flourishing can be stubborn and unyielding.

0_101.text: How should we organise life in this real world?

0_102.text: Do we want our security to depend on the underpaid zero-hours worker of an outsourced company, maximising shareholder profit?

0_103.text: No, we want well-trained, committed workers, properly paid and secure in their own lives – because our well-being is linked to everyone else’s.

0_104.text: Do we want a world in which privatisation is the solution for everything?

0_105.text: Or have we learnt from energy, water and rail that down that road lies private gain rather than the common good?

0_106.text: It’s public ownership and democratic control that lead to fairer services and better outcomes.

0_107.text: The market makes us impatient with the suffering of others, tolerant of inequality, prone to prejudice, suspicious of difference.

0_108.text: We know we can be cooperative, appreciative, understanding and fair.

0_109.text: We just need a world that encourages us to be these things.

0_110.text: Together we can create that world.

0_111.text: The challenges that lie ahead of us are unique in their combination: declining resources, global warming, deepening inequality, footloose capital.

0_112.text: But these problems have been created by us, so they can be solved by us.

0_114.text: And in this remaking we need finally to realise that consumer capitalism is the problem, not the solution.

0_115.text: The solution lies in a democratically managed economy that operates within the Earth’s resource limits.

0_116.text: We don’t want a privatised outsourced state, we want a green and democratic one.

0_117.text: We want a public National Health Service, not privatised healthcare.

0_118.text: The uncoordinated actions of millions of individuals, with unequal access to wealth and power and urged to maximise their own interests without regard for anyone else’s, will only deepen the crisis.

0_119.text: This is what’s on offer from the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats, from Labour and from UKIP.

0_120.text: We need a party prepared to challenge the damage this has done, a party that expects something better.

0_121.text: We need a party prepared for the real world.

0_122.text: We need a party for the common good.

0_124.text: Imagine having a secure, fulfilling and decently paid job, knowing that you are working to live and not living to work.

0_125.text: Imagine coming home to an affordable flat or house, and being valued for your contribution and character, not for how much you earn.

0_126.text: Imagine knowing that you and your friends are part of an economy that works with the planet rather than against it.

0_127.text: Imagine food banks going out of business.

0_128.text: Imagine the end of poverty and deprivation.

0_129.text: The key to all this is to put the economy at the service of people and planet rather than the other way round.

0_130.text: That’s what the Green Party will do.

0_132.text: The main issue for many at this election is the economy.

0_133.text: Many people have very practical worries: Is my job secure?

0_134.text: Will our family have enough this month to pay the bills and put food on the table?

0_135.text: Can we keep paying the mortgage or the rent?

0_136.text: Will we have to continue to work unreasonably long or unpredictable hours?

0_137.text: Is my pay fair compared with others?

0_139.text: Will I ever get a pension?

0_140.text: Will I ever get a job with a future?

0_141.text: Will I ever pay off my student loan?

0_142.text: Will I ever find a decent place to live?

0_143.text: Will the economy provide a decent livelihood long into the future for our children and grandchildren?

0_144.text: Our solutions to these worries are very different from the other parties.

0_145.text: The Coalition parties and Labour agree on one thing about the economy: it’s got to grow because growth is the answer to everything.

0_146.text: If the costs include ruining our climate and countryside by exploiting shale gas, tolerating massive inequality and the insecurity of zero-hours contracts or massive underemployment – then too bad.

0_147.text: We don’t agree with the growth objective.

0_148.text: Our economic policy promotes a fair, just and more equal society while recognising that we live on a finite planet.

0_149.text: It’s easy to forget the fact that everything we make and everything we buy comes from the Earth.

0_150.text: And we have only one of them.

0_151.text: If everyone on Earth consumed at the rate we do in the UK, we’d need nearly three planets to sustain us.

0_152.text: If it’s the average North American, then we’d need nearly four planets.

0_153.text: Greens are sometimes accused of being unrealistic about economics.

0_154.text: Nothing could be further from the truth.

0_155.text: It’s our opponents who are the fantasists, believing that continual growth is possible on a finite planet .

0_156.text: Greens are the realists, understanding that the planet imposes limits and focusing on essentials such as jobs, housing and the household budget.

0_157.text: The economy depends on society, which depends on the Earth and its resources.

0_158.text: That’s the order of things – not the other way round.

0_160.text: The aim of politics is to help us flourish, and by this measure growth has failed in recent decades.

0_161.text: The Office for National Statistics (ONS) tells us that Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per person has grown by more than three times since 1955, allowing for inflation.

0_162.text: Are we three or four times more content?

0_163.text: No, levels of life satisfaction have dropped in this period.

0_164.text: We’re told that growth has returned to the UK.

0_166.text: More than one in four children is growing up in poverty.

0_167.text: The bosses of the UK’s 100 biggest companies earn on average 143 times more than their staff.

0_168.text: The top 1% of the population has the same wealth as the bottom 55%.

0_169.text: Five families in the UK have the same wealth as 12 million UK citizens.

0_170.text: 913,138 people received three days’ emergency food from Trussell Trust food banks in 2013–14 compared with 346,992 in 2012–13.

0_172.text: By 2018, 2 million households are expected to spend more than half their disposable income repaying loans.

0_173.text: Household incomes adjusted for inflation are still on average 2% below what they were in 2009–10.

0_175.text: Government is run too much by Departments, which rarely take any notice of each other.

0_176.text: Greens like to join things up...

0_177.text: So what do social justice and greater equality have to do with health, education, opportunity, the numbers in prison, and even recycling?

0_178.text: This manifesto has many other policies designed to improve all these things.

0_179.text: But just making us more equal will improve all of them.

0_180.text: So it’s not the economy, stupid.

0_181.text: Or at least not one that grows forever.

0_182.text: The Green Party believes that equality is much more important than growth.

0_183.text: And growth doesn’t bring equality; in fact it helps to justify inequality.

0_184.text: The result of the corrosive trickle-down fantasy is plain: the sixth-richest society in the world is disfigured by high levels of deprivation.

0_185.text: And it’s not only those right at the bottom who have problems.

0_186.text: Despite the fact that household incomes are now back to 2007–08 levels, families on ordinary incomes have faced a real squeeze since 2009–10 as prices go up and incomes stagnate.

0_187.text: We will abandon GDP and the pursuit of growth as a measure of economic success.

0_188.text: We would use a measure of Adjusted National Product (ANP), which would take account of capital and environmental depreciation and include the value of many things not currently paid for, such as unpaid work at home.

0_189.text: Green councillors mobilise alternatives to payday lenders...

0_190.text: In a move to break people’s dependence on payday lenders, in Stowmarket, Suffolk, Councillor John Matthissen is leading a cross-agency project to launch a collection and information point for the local credit union.

0_191.text: Short-term economic stimulus We make an important distinction between short-term growth, or ‘regeneration’, and long-term dependency on continuing economic growth.

0_192.text: The measures we propose as alternatives to austerity will, by halting and reversing the cuts to public services, restore lost jobs and create new ones.

0_193.text: The increased economic activity will cause the economy to grow rather than shrink in the short term, restoring employment and living standards.

0_194.text: However, we see such short-term growth as transitional, as a side-effect of ending the failed austerity project.

0_195.text: We do not see it as a contradiction to adapting the economy for One-Planet Living in the longer term.

0_196.text: Alternatives to austerity There is an alternative to austerity.

0_197.text: The crunch of 2008 was the result of the pressures of our consumer society and an unregulated finance system; people borrowed too much and banks were too willing to lend.

0_198.text: Now people and businesses are paying down their debts, businesses contract haphazardly and workers are laid off.

0_199.text: The Coalition’s reaction was to use this as an excuse to impose austerity – in order to cut the debt, especially the government’s deficit – while doing little to strengthen the economy.

0_200.text: The winners are those who absorb corporate surpluses, the chief executives and the shareholders.

0_201.text: The biggest losers are the unemployed, the low paid and the vulnerable, especially those who depend on public services.

0_202.text: Labour plans to match the Tories’ ‘fiscal envelope’ for Departmental spending – code for more austerity.

0_203.text: We think the economy should work for us all.

0_204.text: We want a One-Planet economy that will address the challenge of climate change and unacceptable levels of inequality.

0_205.text: We have to throw off the shackles of market ideology and consider afresh what really needs to be done.

0_206.text: We need to: Ensure that everyone who wants one has a decent secure job paid at least a living wage.

0_207.text: So we have to encourage and create jobs.

0_208.text: In total, the policies in this manifesto will create over 1 million jobs.

0_209.text: See the section on Work in Chapter 9.

0_210.text: Address the issue of climate change.

0_211.text: We need huge investment in using energy more efficiently and generating energy sustainably.

0_212.text: This will not happen without public investment.

0_213.text: See Chapter 4 on Energy and Climate.

0_214.text: Stabilise and tightly regulate the financial sector, whose greed and recklessness have been a major cause of our recent economic difficulties and of growing inequality.

0_215.text: See the section on Finance in Chapter 9.

0_216.text: Provide equality and security in a mixed economy by committing to the common good, a larger public sector and higher taxation, funding our health, education and local services properly, and creating hundreds of thousands of jobs.

0_217.text: See the section on Taxes in Chapter 9.

0_218.text: Be prepared to borrow on good terms to fund investment rather than making closing the deficit the main objective of our economic policy.

0_219.text: The plans in this manifesto require borrowing of £338 billion (in real 2015 terms) over the Parliament as compared with the Coalition’s plan in the 2015 Budget to borrow £115 billion.

0_220.text: If monetary policy demands quantitative easing, we will spend that money directly on green investment.

0_221.text: However, the programme of public spending and taxation in this manifesto would show a surplus on the current account (that is, excluding investment) of 2.7% by the end of the Parliament.

0_222.text: Reject the dogma that everything is best done by the private sector.

0_223.text: A sensible economy is a mixed economy, where some things – health, education and public transport, for example – are better in community or public ownership.

0_224.text: See Chapters 6, 7 and 12 on Health, Education and Transport.

0_225.text: Support those without jobs and treat them with respect in a system that makes getting some work worthwhile `and provides pensions that allow older people to live with dignity.

0_227.text: Mobilise the talents and energy of everyone and serve everyone, `including the young and the old, men and women, those who are disabled and minority groups, including ethnic minorities and different sexual orientations.

0_229.text: Recognise that not everything that is valuable has a price attached to it.

0_230.text: ` Create a robust taxation system that promotes equality and sustainability.

0_231.text: Rein in huge companies that put shareholder returns ahead of the common good.

0_232.text: Foster institutional change in the economy that we want, with changes to company law and encouragement for small firms and mutuals.

0_233.text: See the Changing Economic Organisations and Small Firms sections in Chapter 9.

0_234.text: Create an efficient economy that encourages innovation and the use of science but does not rely on dangerous technologies.

0_235.text: See the Science section in Chapter 3.

0_236.text: Foster an economy that is open to Europe and the wider world, that accepts people will move from country to country and that is willing to assist countries poorer than ours.

0_238.text: Ensure that the Treasury’s priority objective is to deliver an economy with these aims.

0_239.text: How we will do this is set out in detail in the following chapters.

0_241.text: The third planet from the sun.

0_244.text: The only planet with liquid water at its surface.

0_245.text: The only planet in the solar system with 21% oxygen.

0_246.text: As far as we know, the only planet in the solar system that sustains life.

0_247.text: Imagine a political party that prioritises the protection of the land, the seas and their inhabitants.

0_248.text: Imagine one that believes that animals have a right to flourish and aren’t just a means to the end of human satisfaction.

0_249.text: Imagine one that believes the common good embraces other species and not just our own.

0_250.text: That’s what a real political party, the Green Party, does.

0_251.text: The Earth is our home, and this is what we are doing to it: We have lost half the wild animals on Earth in the past 40 years.

0_252.text: We lose between 200 and 100,000 species every year.

0_253.text: This is between 1,000 and 10,000 times faster than the natural extinction rate.

0_255.text: The other five occurred naturally; this one is down to us.

0_256.text: We have increased CO2 concentrations from a pre-industrial 280 parts per million (ppm) to about 400 ppm.

0_257.text: Global temperatures are due to rise between 1.5 and 4.8 degrees C by 2100.

0_258.text: And that’s just the internationally agreed range without feedback effects.

0_259.text: Many experts are predicting rises as high as 6 degrees C.

0_260.text: For the first time in the history of the Earth one species is changing it forever – the human species.

0_261.text: They call this new era the ‘Anthropocene’.

0_262.text: We now have our very own geological epoch.

0_263.text: This brings with it massive responsibilities, which no other party understands or acknowledges.

0_264.text: The rich and powerful, in particular, have spent too long treating the Earth like an indestructible storehouse, to be thoughtlessly pillaged of its natural resources.

0_265.text: UK biodiversity is threatened by development and agricultural practices such as intensive farming, the draining of wetlands and the deforesting of hills.

0_266.text: Genetic selection is causing endemic health and welfare problems in domestic and farmed animals.

0_267.text: Animal experimentation is still routine; millions of animals suffer pain and death every year in the UK.

0_269.text: Our attitude to the natural world is epitomised by the fact that some circuses still tour with wild animals, including zebras, lions, snakes, tigers and camels.

0_270.text: The Green Party will put policies in place that will stop us treating other species and the wider environment as a means to the satisfaction of humans only.

0_271.text: This is because the common good includes other species too.

0_272.text: We depend on them for our own welfare.

0_273.text: Every second breath we take is made possible by phytoplankton releasing oxygen into the oceans.

0_274.text: As the oceans acidify and heat up through global warming, their capacity to ‘fix’ CO2 and release oxygen is compromised.

0_275.text: This is interdependence at work, and we ride roughshod over it at our peril.

0_276.text: But we should also care for other species because the planet is their home too; we share it with them and we need to take their interests and well-being – as well as ours – into account.

0_277.text: Wildlife and open spaces We need to halt the damage to nature in the UK and return protection of our natural landscapes to a central part in our national life.

0_278.text: The time has come for a new legal framework for the protection of landscape and wildlife, and we would promote a new Nature and Well-being Act.

0_279.text: On landscape and habitats we will: Protect, expand, properly fund and improve non-car access to our National Parks.

0_280.text: Make good the Coalition’s unfulfilled promise to protect forests through a Forests Protection Bill.

0_281.text: Reduce dramatically the use of pesticides and prioritise non-chemical farming methods through improved agri-environment schemes, legislation, education and the promotion of good practice in all farming, as well as increased support for organic farming.

0_282.text: Secure protection of rural residents and communities from exposure to pesticides sprayed on nearby crop fields and prohibit the use of pesticides in the locality of homes, schools and children’s playgrounds.

0_283.text: Improve the management of woodlands through new planting and the local use of sustainable woodland products.

0_284.text: Aim to ensure through planning that everyone lives within five minutes’ walk of a green open space, and ensure local authorities have the resources to extend and maintain local parks.

0_285.text: Introduce a nature improvement area in every town, city and county.

0_286.text: Help bees by reducing pesticide use (banning neonicotinoids), ‘greening’ farming, improving planning guidelines to preserve/ create bee habitats and making bees a priority species in biodiversity strategies.

0_287.text: Promote landscape-scale conservation, using reform of the Common Agricultural Policy, improved agri-environment schemes and the planning system.

0_288.text: In particular, all farm payments should be designed to protect the soil, reduce flood risk, conserve wildlife, improve water quality, increase recreation and assist carbon capture.

0_289.text: We would also include protecting ecosystems in our aid for developing countries.

0_290.text: Repeal the National Planning Policy Framework and in particular its presumption in favour of development, and put planning back in the hands of local people and government, while requiring local authorities to map local ecological networks and work collaboratively to develop national spatial plans.

0_291.text: Increase the amount of land offered long-term protection through the European Union’s Birds Directive and Habitats Directive, make sure these directives are properly enforced and defend them in the EU against attempts to weaken them.

0_292.text: Work with local communities, scientists and conservation groups to expand the UK’s network of Marine Conservation Zones to create areas specifically for the protection of mobile species as well as reference areas off limits to fishing and other extractive activities.

0_293.text: Play our part in creating a Southern Atlantic Reserve and champion internationally the protection of the Arctic.

0_294.text: Produce a strategy for capturing carbon and reducing greenhouse gases through improved land management, for example by encouraging and preserving peatlands.

0_295.text: Because of the interaction between water supply and the wider environment, require Ofwat (the Water Services Regulation Authority) and the Environment Agency to work together to create a healthy water environment and long-term low prices for consumers.

0_296.text: In particular, build new reservoirs in the south and east of England.

0_297.text: Prohibit developers from being allowed to destroy unique habitats by way of biodiversity offsetting elsewhere.

0_298.text: Because 94% of the biodiversity for which the UK is responsible is found in our Overseas Territories, ensure that conservation of the environment of the Overseas Territories, including their marine areas, is funded to a level equal to their global significance.

0_299.text: We would also immediately extend ratification of the UN Convention on Biological Diversity to all uninhabited territories, and work with territory governments to agree a timeline for ratification of the Convention in all inhabited territories.

0_300.text: Greens in power carry out our policies The Green-led administration in Brighton has secured open access to more green space in perpetuity.

0_301.text: It declared over 800 acres of Council-owned downland and farmland as ‘open access land’, meaning residents can freely use land that was once closed to them.

0_302.text: It added another 670 acres in July 2014, protected in perpetuity.

0_303.text: Food, farming and fisheries Market forces and government policies have favoured increasing industrialisation of agriculture, mass-produced food and dependence on fossil fuels.

0_304.text: This comes with great ‘external costs’ to the environment, human health, farming people and animal welfare.

0_305.text: Soil erosion, depletion of water resources, pollution, loss of biodiversity and animal suffering are commonplace.

0_306.text: In addition, agriculture accounts for a significant proportion of greenhouse gas emissions, and pressure on land resources is linked with deforestation in many parts of the world.

0_307.text: But food supply and farming are not just another business, and we need to ensure: That nutritious food is available to everyone at prices they can afford; Decent rural livelihoods and support for rural communities; That there is national and international food security; That farming respects the environment and treats farm animals well.

0_308.text: To secure these objectives we will: Seek to reform the Common Agricultural Policy and reform our national agri-environment schemes to prioritise and support farmers who farm sustainably and enhance biodiversity on farmed land with a variety of farming styles, methods and scales.

0_309.text: Foster environmentally sustainable agriculture, land management and a secure food supply by properly supporting valid, rigorous and reliable research into all areas and types of farming including organic farming.

0_310.text: Encourage farming to operate in fair trade conditions, which guarantee a decent livelihood for farmers at home and also in countries that export food to the UK.

0_311.text: Protect productive farmland from development except for that associated with agriculture and those engaged in it.

0_312.text: In particular, review the current classification of farm land to maximise local production of food.

0_313.text: Work to reduce food imports and increase home and local food production where feasible.

0_314.text: Increase localisation of the food chain and encourage direct sales via local markets; support fair trade for farmers and enable them to gain independence from disadvantageous contracts with supermarkets by strengthening the powers of the supermarket ombudsman.

0_315.text: Help hospitals and schools and other food buyers in the public sector to lead the way in buying sustainable products, and encourage children to be involved in growing and cooking food.

0_316.text: Work to ensure sustainable fishing policies, leading to sustainable fishing communities, at both the national and European levels as appropriate.

0_317.text: In particular, fishing quota allocations should reward local sustainable fisheries.

0_318.text: Research, promote and support farming methods that reduce greenhouse gas emissions, enable carbon storage and have minimum impact on wildlife, as established by rigorous and reliable research.

0_319.text: In particular, we should encourage eating less and better meat.

0_320.text: Support a moratorium, at national and EU level, on the use of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) in all agricultural systems, including production of human food and animal feed, and on importation of GM food or feed.

0_323.text: Councillor Molly Scott Cato in Stroud secured £100,000 in the District Council budget to invest in local food production for everyone.

0_324.text: ‘In a rural area like Stroud, it makes sense to support local food producers so that everyone can eat food grown within the district,’ she said.

0_325.text: Molly was elected in 2014 as the new Green Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for the South West.

0_326.text: Animal protection We support calls for a new Commission on Animal Protection, which would cover animal protection issues in all the areas specifically addressed below.

0_327.text: In farming, we must move away from the intensification and industrialisation of animal farming.

0_328.text: Sustainable farming means animals freed from cages and returned to the land.

0_329.text: We will end factory farming and enforce strict animal welfare standards.

0_330.text: In particular we will work for: A complete ban on cages for hens and rabbits and on zero-grazing units for dairy cows.

0_331.text: Improved food labelling and better traceability of our food to prevent further food scandals such as the horse meat scandal; mandatory labelling of meat and dairy products as to method of production and method of slaughter.

0_333.text: Tougher regulations on animal transportation, including a maximum limit of 8 hours and an end to live export from the UK.

0_334.text: Action to stop the overuse of antibiotics in intensive animal farming, with mandatory targets and surveillance of the human health impacts.

0_335.text: A ban on the production and sale of foie gras.

0_336.text: A ban on the cloning of farm animals and on the sale of meat and milk from these animals.

0_337.text: Ending genetic selection for fast growth or high yields where this results in compromised welfare such as ill health or pain.

0_338.text: Protection for British farmers from low-welfare imports.

0_339.text: Joining up the policies So what do farming, health, insurance and carbon dioxide emissions have to do with each other?

0_340.text: Good farming respects ecology, promotes biodiversity and encourages us to get out and enjoy the wildlife and landscape, improving both our mental and our physical health.

0_341.text: And local food saves food miles, combating climate change, while good land management can retain water, reducing flooding and our insurance premiums.

0_342.text: Illegal wildlife trade is causing great suffering; it devastates species across the globe and is linked to other serious organised crimes.

0_343.text: Greens will implement: Increased support and resources to build expertise in wildlife crime within the justice sector, including: strengthening sentencing in this area, gathering data on the trade, ensuring police forces implement local strategies and ensuring funding of the Wildlife Crime Unit.

0_344.text: A ban on the import of exotic pets.

0_345.text: An end to the keeping of primates as household pets.

0_346.text: Enhanced public education and awareness to reduce demand.

0_347.text: Allocation of resources to support other countries in tackling poaching and human/wildlife conflict.

0_348.text: On other animal protection issues we would: Maintain and strengthen the ban on hunting with dogs and extend this ban to all hunting of all animals for sport or pleasure.

0_349.text: End the badger cull (see ‘Badger culls’ box).

0_351.text: End the practice of grouse shooting and other ‘sport’ shooting.

0_352.text: End the use of all animals in circuses.

0_353.text: End the use of the whip in horse racing and conduct a full review of the sport.

0_354.text: Take action over other sports or entertainment that cause suffering to animals.

0_355.text: Ensure UK taxpayers’ money is not used to fund bullfighting.

0_356.text: Ensure greater protection for racing greyhounds and initiate a formal independent review of the industry.

0_357.text: Ban the import of fur products.

0_358.text: Work for stronger international protection of endangered sea creatures, and an end to the killing of porpoises, whales and dolphins in all waters and keeping these animals for commercial purposes.

0_359.text: Badger culls – inhumane and unscientific The Green Party has been strongly opposed to the badger cull from the outset, saying that all the evidence showed it would be both inhumane and ineffective at tackling bovine tuberculosis.

0_360.text: The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) controversially went ahead with culling by ‘free shooting’ in Gloucestershire and Somerset in 2013.

0_361.text: The trial was a failure, being shown to be both inhumane and ineffective, as predicted.

0_362.text: The Coalition has nonetheless chosen to continue to pursue this strategy.

0_363.text: In October 2012 Green MP Caroline Lucas secured a major parliamentary debate to challenge the government’s badger policy and led MPs in a successful vote against it.

0_364.text: Greens want to see an end to all animal experimentation and will ensure that research funding is directed away from failing animal disease models and towards modern human biology-based techniques, which offering greater opportunities to cure disease and improve product safety.

0_365.text: We will work to end animal experiments but believe immediate action must be taken to Stop non-medical experiments, experiments using primates, cats and dogs.

0_366.text: End the use of live animals in military training.

0_367.text: Stop the breeding of and use of genetically altered animals.

0_368.text: End government funding of animal experimentation, including any that is outsourced to other countries.

0_369.text: Provide greater funding for non-animal research methods and link funding to a target for developing of humane alternatives to animal experiments.

0_370.text: Increase transparency and ensure publication of all findings of animal research, including negative findings.

0_371.text: Introduce a comprehensive system for reviewing animal experiments and initiate a comparison of currently required animal tests with a set of human biology-based tests.

0_372.text: On companion animals Greens will push to: Completely review and update existing dog legislation, particularly relating to dog control.

0_373.text: Ensure properly coordinated action on dog fighting.

0_374.text: Update the rules on selling animals and tackle problems associated with online advertising of pets and illegal imports.

0_375.text: Introduce mandatory licensing of breeders and control on genetic manipulation through breeding to prevent exaggerated characteristics likely to cause suffering.

0_376.text: End puppy farming by banning the sale of young puppies unless the mother is present.

0_377.text: Introduce regulations that make it illegal to use aversive training aids such as electric shock collars.

0_378.text: Greens in power carry out our policies In Brighton, the Green-led Council ensures that new Council tenancy agreements include a requirement that dogs living in council owned homes should be micro-chipped.

0_379.text: This has encouraged more tenants who own dogs to behave responsibly as their pets are much easier to trace.

0_380.text: Science and technology Greens are pro-science.

0_381.text: Our policies on everything from climate change to eradicating bovine TB are based on the best possible scientific evidence.

0_382.text: But just because science allows us to do something, that does not mean that we should do it.

0_383.text: We oppose nuclear power and the release of genetically modified crops into the environment.

0_384.text: We need to balance our scientific and technological abilities against the social, economic and ethical consequences of using them – including their impact on future generations and other species.

0_385.text: Greens will support the development of technologies that have strong social, economic and environmental benefits.

0_386.text: That is why we support investment in energy efficiency and the development of renewable energy//, which will be vital in helping to secure improvements in people’s quality of life and to combating climate change.

0_387.text: We would: Ensure that adequate government funding goes to research on major environmental issues such as climate change, pollution and biodiversity loss, and less is spent on military research.

0_388.text: Ensure that basic research is adequately funded and is not controlled by large corporations, and gradually increase public spending on scientific research from 0.5% to 1.0% of GDP over the next ten years.

0_389.text: Ensure that scientific research is conducted ethically, with regard in particular to human and animal welfare.

0_390.text: Publish freely the results of all publicly funded research.

0_391.text: Prevent the patenting of genes and living organisms.

0_392.text: What scientists say So... the Green Party... a party of sentimental tree-huggers?

0_393.text: Yes, we do love trees, and many of us take great moral and spiritual solace from the natural world.

0_394.text: But we are also a party of science, and we listen to scientists.

0_395.text: Here is what the Royal Society, the UK’s pre-eminent scientific body, said in its 2012 People and the Planet report (pp.

0_396.text: 7–8): ‘First, the world’s 1.3 billion poorest people need to be raised out of extreme poverty.

0_397.text: This is critical to reducing global inequality, and to ensuring the wellbeing of all people...

0_398.text: Second, in the most developed and the emerging economies unsustainable consumption must be urgently reduced.

0_399.text: This will entail scaling back or radical transformation of damaging material consumption and emissions and the adoption of sustainable technologies, and is critical to ensuring a sustainable future for all...

0_400.text: Third, global population growth needs to be slowed and stabilised, but this should by no means be coercive.’

0_402.text: In the General Election you can vote for the only real party of science or for the parties of neo-liberal economic ideology, which believe in the illusion that we can continue to expand forever on a finite planet.

0_403.text: Waste and recycling Reducing the amount of waste we produce and being more careful about how we dispose of it has benefits for our planet, our economy and society as a whole.

0_404.text: We want to move towards a jobs-rich circular economy with as much waste minimisation as possible.

0_405.text: We would: Reduce what we use, reuse it when we have finished with it and recycle as a last resort.

0_406.text: Provide the framework and the infrastructure to help people make more positive choices.

0_407.text: Use taxation and regulation to ensure that products and packaging are designed with a view to what happens to them when they stop being useful and packaging reduced.

0_408.text: We want waste designed out and fixing things – making them last – designed in.

0_409.text: Follow Scotland in banning waste food and other organic material being sent to landfill.

0_410.text: Increase national spending on recycling and waste disposal by about 50%, an extra £4 billion a year, so that we can do away with damaging incineration and landfill.

0_411.text: Aim to recycle 70% of domestic waste by 2020 as a move towards a zero-waste system.

0_412.text: CHAPTER 4 Imagine flicking a switch and knowing that the energy was coming from the sun, the wind, the earth and the tides; energy forever, not just for now.

0_413.text: Imagine not having to decide between ‘heating or eating’; no fuel poverty Imagine glancing out of the window and seeing a van arrive to insulate your neighbour’s house as part of a funded nationwide programme – reducing demand as well as creating supply.

0_414.text: Imagine your energy bill coming from a community-owned company or cooperative rather than from one of the ‘Big Six’.

0_415.text: Imagine being part of the company or cooperative yourself; energy security for us all rather than profits for the few.

0_416.text: This is all possible; this is Green Party energy policy.

0_417.text: Energy for all without climate change.

0_419.text: It keeps our houses warm, powers much of our transport and home appliances, and cooks our food.

0_420.text: Our lives depend on it and it takes up a large part of our spending, especially if we are poor.

0_421.text: Too many people suffer fuel poverty.

0_422.text: We get a bad deal on energy.

0_423.text: When wholesale prices go up, the prices for domestic electricity and for fuel at the pumps go up rapidly.

0_424.text: When wholesale prices go down, the retail prices seem to stick.

0_425.text: The big energy companies make huge profits but do not serve the common good.

0_426.text: We need to put this right and ensure that: Everyone is able to cook and keep warm; We are charged for what we use, and not penalised for using less; We are not cut off or forced to use pre-payment meters.

0_427.text: But burning fossil fuels for energy causes climate change.

0_428.text: If we are to secure a safe and habitable climate for current and future generations, we need a rapid shift to a zero-carbon energy system; we need to leave the vast majority of fossil fuel reserves underground and unburned.

0_429.text: Other ways of getting energy, such as nuclear power, pose other unacceptable risks.

0_430.text: So we have to build a secure and affordable energy system that meets our basic needs while protecting our environment.

0_431.text: We believe this requires an energy policy that: Reduces the amount of energy we need, mainly by improving energy efficiency.

0_434.text: Reorganises the energy generation and supply industry, in particular breaking the dominance of the Big Six suppliers.

0_435.text: Puts community, cooperative and locally owned clean energy generation and supply at the heart of our energy system.

0_436.text: We have to start with climate change, because this drives the degree of urgency with which we change our energy system.

0_437.text: Climate change The climate is the ultimate common good.

0_438.text: The effects of a rapidly warming climate will affect everyone, but poorer people, in the UK and worldwide, will be the hardest hit.

0_439.text: Many are already struggling to cope with rising sea levels, flooding, drought and extreme weather.

0_440.text: Climate change threatens to make parts of the world uninhabitable.

0_442.text: More intense weather events will further affect health and food production and make global conflict more likely.

0_443.text: The science makes it clear that, to avoid the risk of runaway climate change, we must leave around four-fifths of all existing fossil fuel reserves in the ground.

0_444.text: So the problem now is not too little fossil fuel but too much.

0_445.text: Exploiting new sources of unconventional fossil fuels such as shale gas and oil and tar sands is incompatible with tackling climate change.

0_446.text: We must reduce our dependency on oil, coal and gas as quickly as possible while developing a society that can thrive on renewable energy.

0_448.text: To have a reasonable chance of avoiding catastrophic climate change, we need a 90% reduction in greenhouse gases in the UK in the next 15–20 years and a zero-carbon economy by 2050 (see the box for how we derive these targets).

0_449.text: This is much more challenging than the 80% reduction in greenhouse gases by 2050 in the Climate Change Act 2008.

0_450.text: Although we celebrate, defend and uphold the Climate Change Act, it must also be strengthened.

0_451.text: A Green transformation would have huge benefits: more comfortable homes, better health, less pollution, lots of jobs, and far less dependency on foreign fuel imports.

0_452.text: The UK can and must do better:

0_453.text: The government’s climate change advisers say we are on track to miss even the government’s unsatisfactory carbon targets.

0_454.text: Progress on energy efficiency has plummeted.

0_455.text: The government’s Green Deal to save energy in our homes has been a disappointing failure.

0_456.text: The UK is 25th out of 27 in the European renewable energy league table, despite having some of the best resources for renewable energy in Europe.

0_457.text: We have the highest level of fuel poverty in Western Europe.

0_458.text: Why we need to do better than the Climate Change Act If the global average temperature rise can be kept below 2 degrees C, runaway or disastrous climate change can be avoided, though severe damage will occur in some parts of the world.

0_459.text: Many countries and civil society organisations argue that the international goal should be to keep to 1.5 degrees C of warming, highlighting the severity of the climate impacts we are already seeing.

0_460.text: All countries including the UK agreed at Copenhagen in 2009 to recognise the need to limit the average temperature rise to below 2 degrees C, despite the fact that the UK’s climate change target means that there is an almost two-thirds (63%) chance of exceeding this 2 degrees C. To meet the 2 degree C target, the world needs to limit total global emissions over the rest of the century to about 1,000 gigatonnes (Gt) CO2.

0_461.text: Current projections have us exceeding that figure by 2040, leading to devastating average warming of around 4 degrees C by the end of this century.

0_462.text: As the UK has about 1% of the world’s population, its allowable budget would amount to 10 Gt CO2.

0_463.text: But the UK is a relatively rich country that has benefited from the world’s highest cumulative historical emissions per person.

0_464.text: The Green Party therefore believes that the UK should plan to emit only half this amount by 2030 (which amounts to around 80 million tonnes CO2 a year by 2030), and have negligible emissions thereafter.

0_465.text: This translates into our target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to 10% of their 1990 levels by 2030.

0_466.text: This goes much further than the 80% reduction in greenhouse gases by 2050 mandated by the Climate Change Act.

0_467.text: Using energy wisely Renewables can supply all the energy we need for a comfortable standard of living, but only if we invest wisely and manage our demand more sensibly – by reducing energy waste and improving efficiency.

0_468.text: The Green Party would seek to cut energy demand by one-third by 2020, one-half by 2030 and two-thirds by 2050.

0_469.text: The UK already has the technology it needs.

0_470.text: What is lacking is the political will to build a cleaner, home-grown, more local, more affordable, more democratic and ultimately more reliable energy future.

0_471.text: Caroline Lucas and fuel poverty When joint chair of Parliament’s cross-party group on ending fuel poverty and promoting energy efficiency, Green MP Caroline Lucas was a leading advocate of urgent action to end the scandal of cold homes.

0_472.text: She initiated a debate in Parliament’s Westminster Hall about curbing the power of the Big Six energy companies and has asked parliamentary questions, lobbied ministers, spoken in debates and tabled amendments to legislation demanding action on warm homes and lower bills.

0_473.text: Caroline has campaigned for home energy efficiency to be made a UK National Infrastructure priority and to be given the necessary funding.

0_474.text: She has stood up in Parliament for an Energy Bill revolution – the creation of the world’s most ambitious home energy-efficiency programme, which would slash energy bills and carbon emissions, create over 100,000 jobs and help end the fuel poverty crisis once and for all.

0_475.text: Home energy improvement will be central to this drive to accelerate energy saving while ensuring energy is affordable to all.

0_476.text: We will: Provide a free nationwide retrofit insulation programme, concentrating on areas where fuel poverty is most serious.

0_477.text: This is designed to insulate 9 million homes in total and take at least 2 million homes out of fuel poverty, aiming for the Passivhaus ultra low-energy refurbishment standard by 2020.

0_478.text: It will offer up to £5,000 worth of free insulation, or other energy improvements such as solar photovoltaics (PV) if the insulation is already up to the standard, to every home in designated areas.

0_479.text: To reach Passivhaus standards, there will be the option of up to a further £15,000 in subsidised loans from the Green Investment Bank for each dwelling for further improvements.

0_480.text: This programme will invest £45 billion over the course of the Parliament (including investment in training and awareness), be delivered by local authorities and create well over 100,000 jobs.

0_481.text: It will become part of a new Green National Infrastructure programme.

0_482.text: Give tenants the right to require landlords to achieve the same improvement to the energy performance of their home, and require all private rented sector housing to meet Energy Performance Band C by 2025.

0_483.text: Require all new homes to be built to the Passivhaus standard.

0_484.text: Support this investment in insulating and building to Passivhaus standards with investment in training for the design and building industries, by creating a national college for training in energy home improvement, and building relationships with a network of affiliated facilities, including existing colleges and private training providers.

0_485.text: Invest too in energy awareness programmes so that people become as aware of the energy performance of their home (and of other buildings too) as they are now of the miles per gallon of their car.

0_486.text: Continue a fully funded Renewable Heat Incentive scheme.

0_487.text: Provide £4.5 billion over the Parliament to support research and development into less energy-intensive industrial processes.

0_488.text: Prioritise public over private transport, electrification of the transport system and access over mobility.

0_489.text: Give councils the power to insist that communal heating schemes, for example using waste heat from industrial sources, are implemented where practicable.

0_490.text: Establish mandatory standards for commercial building performance such as ISO 5001.

0_491.text: Use carbon taxes (based on the present system) to fund investment in energy-efficiency measures, and prepare for the following Parliament a carbon quota scheme to regulate the level of demand for energy.

0_492.text: Green councillors make home insulation happen...

0_493.text: Work began last year in Stroud on a five-year £12 million programme planned by Green councillors Phillip Booth and Simon Pickering to improve the energy efficiency of over 1,000 homes in the district.

0_494.text: New local jobs will be created for trades people to install insulation, solar panels and heat pumps.

0_495.text: The four Greens on Kirklees Council secured three years of free home insulation funding, against the active opposition of Labour councillors, who later tried to claim credit!

0_496.text: This saved householders around £76 per year at 2011 prices and cut emissions.

0_497.text: It also created 243 jobs in the local economy.

0_498.text: Carbon quotas – how they would work The fairest way to share emissions rights is equally.

0_499.text: So we support the idea of an economy-wide system of carbon quotas, with everyone guaranteed the same basic entitlement, regardless of wealth.

0_500.text: Those who use less than this could sell some of their quota to those who use more, rewarding their carbon thrift.

0_501.text: About half the available carbon units could be distributed, free of charge, to all adults in the country.

0_502.text: The rest of the carbon units could be sold by the government to companies and other organisations.

0_503.text: Whenever you bought fossil fuels or electricity your carbon account card would be debited.

0_504.text: You would be able to sell excess carbon units – or buy extra units if you need to.

0_505.text: Owning and controlling our energy system

0_506.text: Our vision for the energy system is a diverse mix of public and private participants, including community, cooperative and municipal generation, supply and distribution.

0_507.text: We will end the dominance of the Big Six energy companies.

0_508.text: We will stabilise the ‘policy landscape’ for renewable energy to provide certainty for investment decisions, including long-term targets and stable feedin tariffs.

0_509.text: We will: Maximise opportunities for community or municipally owned, or cooperative not-for-profit organisations to generate and supply electricity and heat at the retail level.

0_510.text: Set a target for at least 42 gigawatts (GW) of community power by 2020.

0_511.text: Require grid operators to give priority access to community energy projects at an affordable cost.

0_512.text: Split up the large vertically integrated companies so that they can’t both produce energy and supply it to consumers.

0_513.text: Secure public control over the strategic direction and policies of the National Grid.

0_514.text: Support long-term stable fixed-price feed-in tariffs for renewable energy generators.

0_515.text: Ensure that consumer energy tariffs are progressive, so small consumers pay less per unit than larger ones, that special needs are recognised, that people are not cut off when they can’t afford to pay, and that people are not forced to have prepayment meters.

0_516.text: Ensure that there is a single scheme of regulation for the entire industry, whose objectives include achieving climate change targets as well as protecting consumer interests.

0_517.text: Why we say no to fracking Fracking is a process where water, sand and chemicals are injected at high pressure into shale rocks under the ground to release shale gas or oil.

0_518.text: Three years ago we called for a moratorium on fracking-related activity while the environmental and economic impacts of drilling for shale gas were evaluated.

0_519.text: On that basis, we are now emphatic and unambiguous in proposing an outright ban on fracking and related extreme energy technologies (coal-bed methane and underground coal gasification, as well as hydraulic fracturing).

0_520.text: Fracking is incompatible with the UK’s climate change obligations.

0_521.text: There is already around five times more fossil fuel globally than we can safely burn if are to avoid dangerous climate change.

0_522.text: Encouraging a whole new fossil fuel industry is deeply irresponsible and undermines international efforts to secure a global climate agreement.

0_523.text: Fracking will put communities and our environment at risk.

0_524.text: There are serious and legitimate concerns about the potential for fracking to cause water contamination, air pollution and harm to wildlife and public health.

0_525.text: Fracking sites would entail mass lorry movements, blighting our countryside and villages.

0_527.text: The Green Party strategy for energy efficiency ensures that we can change to an energy system based mainly on electricity from renewables within 15–20 years (a little longer for transport).

0_528.text: This will require substantial investment over the period.

0_529.text: We also need to pay more attention to energy storage.

0_530.text: So we will: Invest substantial amounts of public money (up to £35 billion over the Parliament) in renewable generation and in the National Grid, if necessary, to make sure renewable generation grows quickly enough.

0_531.text: This would include both large-scale generation and small- and medium-scale renewable generation schemes funded through local authorities.

0_532.text: This capacity would not necessarily be publicly owned and would include community-owned schemes.

0_533.text: Give the Green Investment Bank full borrowing powers to help fund this investment.

0_534.text: Concentrate on expanding mature renewable technologies such as wind energy and solar PV in the period until 2030 and bringing down costs, in part by reducing planning constraints, including those for onshore wind.

0_535.text: Ensure that all schools, hospitals and other public buildings have solar panels by 2020.

0_536.text: Encourage all social landlords to develop plans to install solar panels on all suitable properties, building on Kirklees Council’s pioneering £10 million plan to install solar panels on 2,000 Council homes over the next two years.

0_537.text: Schemes such as these can save people on low incomes the equivalent of up to two weeks’ rent.

0_538.text: Set deployment targets to bring down costs and attract investment in manufacturing and supply chains, aiming for 42 GW of offshore wind by 2020 and 60 GW by 2030, and for 25 GW of solar PV by 2020.

0_539.text: Spend £2.5 billion over the Parliament on an intensive research and deployment programme for other renewables such as wave and tidal stream generators or other approaches, and also for storage technologies.

0_540.text: Phase out fossil-fuel-based generation, including the closure of all coal-fired power stations by 2023 at the very latest.

0_541.text: Phase out nuclear power within ten years.

0_542.text: Ban all UK fracking operations – following a growing number of nations worldwide – and withdraw all relevant licences as soon as possible.

0_543.text: Ban other new fossil fuel developments such as other unconventional fossil fuels and open cast coal.

0_544.text: End fossil fuel industry tax breaks, phase out other harmful fossil fuel subsidies (domestic and international) and use the money saved to help fund other parts of our energy programme.

0_545.text: Work with financial institutions, local councils and others to encourage divestment from fossil fuels and develop alternative investment in efficiency and renewables programmes.

0_546.text: Support the potential deployment of carbon capture and storage to existing biomass and gas power stations only as a transitional technology.

0_547.text: Develop biomass generation only where it can be done in a sustainable way giving regard to the environmental and human costs of some large-scale biomass fuel operations.

0_548.text: Set in law a decarbonisation target for the power sector of 25–50 grams of carbon dioxide per kilowatt hour by 2030.

0_549.text: Expand electricity storage capacity, including using the potential storage capacity of electric vehicles, and develop the commercial and regulatory framework to make this a reality.

0_551.text: Adapting to climate change Apart from rebuilding the UK’s energy system, we also need to adapt to the climate change that will take place as the effects of past emissions work their way through the system.

0_552.text: In the UK there will be wetter winters and hotter and drier summers.

0_553.text: We can expect greater instability, with more episodes of extreme weather, such as the heavy rain and floods of the 2013–14 winter.

0_554.text: We need to begin urgently to prepare for this by: Providing help for people and communities to prepare for an increasingly variable climate.

0_555.text: We would give an extra £1 billion a year to local authorities and the Environment Agency to spend on assisting communities with flood protection and on defending homes and public buildings, such as hospitals, from heat waves.

0_556.text: Obliging government departments and local authorities to consider climate change and carbon reduction in all their planning over a long time horizon of 50–100 years.

0_557.text: Specifically, local authorities should do so in all planning decisions.

0_558.text: Having the government act as an insurer of last resort where commercial insurance companies are refusing to provide flood cover.

0_559.text: Preventing new building on flood plains.

0_560.text: Encouraging storing water in uplands through full river system management – including wetland restoration, natural regeneration, allowing rivers to meander and allowing flooding upstream.

0_561.text: Water management needs to become part of the rules for farming subsidies.

0_562.text: Green councillor sets the pace on flooding..

0_563.text: Thanks to a lone Green councillor, who at the time held the balance of power, Islington became the first UK Council to set a minimum amount of ‘permeable’ land to prevent flooding.

0_564.text: Nuclear energy – it’s still no thanks

0_565.text: In recent years, the nuclear industry has tried to re-brand itself as ‘green’.

0_566.text: As the UK’s only environmental party, the Green Party needs to set out why it still considers that nuclear is no answer to either climate change or our energy needs.

0_568.text: Nuclear energy is neither zero carbon nor renewable and there is serious debate about whether it is even low carbon.

0_569.text: Uncertainties involved in carbon costing, radioactive waste management and the carbon costs of obtaining uranium mean that the carbon costs of nuclear are unknowable.

0_570.text: Unlike renewables, we simply cannot rely on it being low carbon.

0_571.text: In addition to its highly dubious ‘low-carbon’ credentials, nuclear energy is a seriously flawed policy in other ways: Nuclear energy is extremely expensive: not one nuclear plant has ever been built, anywhere in the world by private investors without huge public subsidies.

0_572.text: The Coalition government has agreed to guarantee EDF nearly double the current market electricity price at Hinkley, in addition to other financial backing not available to other low-carbon generators.

0_573.text: These subsidies would impose enormous and unjustifiable costs on householders and businesses.

0_574.text: Nuclear remains a uniquely dangerous form of energy.

0_575.text: If the new plant being built by EDF at Hinkley were to release an equivalent amount of radiation to Fukushima, and the wind was in the south-west, Bristol would need to be permanently evacuated.

0_576.text: No long-term solution has yet been found to the question of dealing with nuclear waste.

0_577.text: Wind power has been found to create around 12 times as many jobs as the same investment in nuclear, and solar power is estimated to create around 360 times as many jobs.

0_578.text: Investing in energy efficiency (e.g. insulation) creates even more jobs.

0_579.text: Renewables can provide the same ‘base load’ production as nuclear power at a lower cost without the risks.

0_580.text: Nuclear power diverts investment, skills and expertise away from securing the economic, employment and energy security benefits of home-grown renewables, smart grids and demand reduction.

0_581.text: The current UK nuclear programme is planned around a reactor design, the European Pressurized Reactor (EPR), which has an atrocious construction and cost record.

0_582.text: EPRs being built in France and Finland are years behind schedule and have huge cost overruns.

0_583.text: Even if nuclear were the answer, the EPR would still be the wrong plant to build.

0_584.text: CHAPTER 5 More equal societies almost always do better than unequal ones – and that’s true for the well-off as well as for the poor.

0_585.text: Almost every modern social and environmental problem – ill health, lack of community life, violence, drugs, obesity, mental illness, long working hours, big prison populations – is more likely to occur in a less equal society.

0_586.text: Imagine a world in which everyone is respected whatever their ethnicity, gender, age, religious belief or non-belief, sexual orientation, gender identity, class, size, disability or other status.

0_587.text: Imagine a world in which no one earns more than ten times what anyone else earns.

0_588.text: We’d all be healthier, happier and more confident.

0_589.text: This could be the real world the Green Party creates.

0_590.text: The Green Party is opposed to inequality not just because it is wrong in itself and because more equal societies are happier societies, but because it fosters inappropriate growth.

0_591.text: We are encouraged to measure our prosperity by comparing it with the material conditions of others.

0_592.text: Celebrity culture and the lifestyles of the rich create a climate of envy and a desire to match them.

0_593.text: This fuels consumption that satisfies pointless wants for some rather than vital needs for all.

0_595.text: It is claimed that: if the economy gets bigger some benefit will ‘trickle down’ to the poor and vulnerable; A rising tide floats all boats – forgetting that not everyone has a boat.

0_596.text: However, recent research by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) confirms that this theory is just wrong.

0_597.text: In a resource-constrained world, equality makes much more sense than inequality.

0_598.text: Our taxation, pay and social security plans will make the UK a materially more equal society.

0_599.text: Equality and diversity Equality is a matter not just of material goods but of treating people fairly – celebrating diversity rather than punishing it.

0_600.text: The Green Party aims to treat everyone equally and fairly.

0_601.text: We will: Reinstate the funding for the Equality and Human Rights Commission.

0_602.text: Make equality and diversity lessons mandatory in all schools, from the first year of primary education onwards, to combat all forms of prejudice and bullying, to promote understanding and acceptance of difference and to ensure community cohesion.

0_603.text: Continue to tackle institutional racism in the police force and the wider criminal justice system.

0_604.text: Require all police forces to have equality and diversity liaison officers whose remit is to tackle and take preventive action on crimes originating in discrimination against any group, and to treat crimes arising from such discrimination on a par with racist crimes.

0_605.text: Implement a UK-wide strategy to tackle violence against women, including domestic violence, rape and sexual abuse, female genital mutilation and trafficking.

0_606.text: Ensure that effective action is taken to prevent discrimination against people with disabilities.

0_607.text: Provide comprehensive training for teachers and educational staff on all diversity and inclusion issues.

0_608.text: Oblige schools to promote equal opportunities in their anti-bullying procedures and to monitor equality issues in teaching recruitment.

0_609.text: Work towards ending stigma against people with mental health problems, including discrimination in employment.

0_610.text: Progressively introduce anonymised CVs so that Black and Minority Ethnic and female candidates are not excluded before the interview stage because of their identity.

0_611.text: Ensure that the public sector does more to employ more Black and Minority Ethnic employees.

0_612.text: Strengthen Travellers’ rights to sites and guarantee proper protection of the nomadic lifestyle of Travellers while ensuring that the lifestyle of the settled population is also protected.

0_613.text: Enforce penalties against employers who continue to implement unequal pay.

0_614.text: Work vigorously towards ensuring that all levels of government and public bodies are representative of the diversity of the populations for whom they work.

0_615.text: Support proposals by the Speaker of the House of Common to set up an Equalities Committee.

0_616.text: Greens in power carry out our policies Stonewall put the Green-led Brighton Council in first place in their 2014 Education Equality Index.

0_617.text: Stonewall has described the Council as ‘leading the way’ in celebrating difference and supporting lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender students.

0_618.text: Brighton Council also introduced the landmark trans scrutiny panel, looking how to address transphobia in the city.

0_619.text: Of the 37 initial recommendations, 25 have started or been implemented, including addressing transphobia in schools, allowing genderless honorifics for Council documentation and easing access to healthcare for trans people.

0_620.text: Lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex and queer (LGBTIQ) people Despite recent modest advances, discrimination against LGBTIQ people remains in areas such as housing, education, employment and health.

0_621.text: The Green Party supports campaigns to advance LGBTIQ rights and aims to build a society where everyone is valued, respected and empowered, regardless of their sexuality or gender identity.

0_622.text: We will: Legislate to remedy inequality in pension inheritance for same-sex marriage partners and same-sex civil partners.

0_623.text: Consider reducing the 12-month blood donation deferral period for men who have sex with men, based on individual risk assessment where the donor is identified to be not at risk of passing infections into the blood supply.

0_624.text: Apologise to and pardon all 50,000–100,000 men convicted of consenting adult same-sex relations under anti-gay laws that have now been repealed.

0_625.text: Provide mandatory HIV, sex and relationship education – age appropriate and LGBTIQ inclusive – in all schools from primary level onwards.

0_626.text: Require every school to have an anti-bullying programme that explicitly combats homophobic, biphobic and transphobic bullying.

0_627.text: Combat homophobic, biphobic and transphobic violence by ensuring uniform legislation against all forms of hate crime.

0_628.text: End the cuts to the NHS, which have undermined HIV services and made it harder for trans people to access gender reassignment services.

0_629.text: End the detention of LGBTIQ (and other) asylum seekers and the culture of disbelief that often denies them refugee status.

0_630.text: Challenge criminalisation, discrimination and violence against LGBTIQ people in other countries and work in solidarity with campaigners there.

0_631.text: Press the Commonwealth to grant accredited status to a Commonwealth LGBTIQ Association and to urge all member states to end the criminalisation of homosexuality and to protect LGBTIQ citizens against discrimination and hate crime.

0_632.text: Joining up the policies Anti-discrimination policies on their own aren’t enough.

0_633.text: It’s vital to see the connections between one policy decision and its effects elsewhere in society.

0_634.text: Cuts and austerity measures have a disproportionate effect on LGBTIQ people because of higher levels of reliance on public services due to family estrangement, societal and workplace discrimination, and specific healthcare needs.

0_635.text: Likewise, cuts in youth, housing and social services are more likely to affect young LGBTIQ people, particularly those who are estranged from their families.

0_636.text: LGBTIQ people are more likely to face unemployment and the impact of this can be much greater because they may not be able to rely on wider social networks.

0_637.text: Cuts to services for older and disabled people will have a much greater impact on LGBTIQ people, who are less likely to have children and will be more reliant on public services.

0_638.text: So, restoring the public realm contributes to equality and diversity.
