0_639.text: Women Since 2010, recent progress in advancing women’s equality has been undermined and reversed Women are now: Poorer – nearly three-quarters of the government’s ‘savings’ have been paid for by women; Earning less – the value of low pay in particular is declining, and the pay gap between men and women in their twenties has doubled; Over-burdened – as support services have been slashed, women are left carrying the load; and More at risk of gendered violence – because funding for services that support survivors of sexual and domestic violence has been reduced.

0_640.text: This is all a consequence of deliberate government action.

0_641.text: The Public Sector Equality Duty, which assesses the impact of gove ivered, is designed to solve problems in isolation – the lack of a job or of a place to live, an illness – but problems usually arise together.

0_642.text: An alternative approach, based on Women’s Centres, has shown the potential to break down barriers and provide an effective holistic approach that facilitates resilience and recovery for women and their families.

0_643.text: The Green Party would fund the creation of a nationwide set of pilots, and if their early promise turns out to be fulfilled would intend expanding this to a universal nationwide scheme, run in the voluntary sector by women but given secure long-term core funding through local government.

0_644.text: We will also: Make equal pay for men and women a reality.

0_645.text: Require 40% of all members of public company and public sector boards to be women.

0_646.text: Listen to girls and young women about relationships education and about sexism in the media and make personal, social, health and economic education (PSHE) a compulsory part of the school curriculum.

0_647.text: Take steps to tackle media sexism, starting with working with retailers to stop lads mags and other pornography from being sold in supermarkets and newsagents.

0_648.text: Ensure that the laws to prevent discrimination against women on the grounds of pregnancy and maternity are properly enforced.

0_650.text: and make it illegal to stop nursing mothers feeding their babies in a public place.

0_651.text: Ensure consistent long-term funding for a national network of Rape Crisis Centres, spending up to £100 million on the network over the course of the Parliament.

0_652.text: Disability Instead of helping disadvantaged people, the Coalition has scapegoated and isolated them.

0_653.text: Private firms assess people on the verge of death as fit for work.

0_654.text: The ‘bedroom tax’ plays havoc with any person who is disabled and needs an extra room for equipment or a carer.

0_655.text: Austerity has brought cuts to disability benefits, harming the most vulnerable in our society.

0_656.text: The Green Party is committed to the social model of disability.

0_657.text: People who are disabled have a right to participate fully in society.

0_658.text: We will: Support the principles of, and enforce the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

0_659.text: End the pernicious system whereby an external contractor assesses whether people are fit for work and return to the system of relying on the judgement of GPs or other health professionals.

0_660.text: Increase the budget for Disability Living Allowance / Personal Independence Payments by around £1 billion a year.

0_661.text: Retain the Independent Living Fund, which enables over 18,000 severely disabled people to stay in their home instead of being in residential care, costing around £300 million a year.

0_662.text: Provide a further £0.5 billion for free social care for adults aged 18–65 who have a proven care need.

0_663.text: Increase the Carer’s Allowance by 50%, costing £1.2 billion a year (6.5 million carers save the state £119 billion), and provide carers with a legal right to 5–10 days paid annual leave.

0_664.text: Raise the profile of the Access to Work scheme among smaller firms and under-served disabled people, with far great transparency over how the scheme is administered.

0_665.text: Provide older carers with more generous and consistent support through a Citizen’s Pension.

0_666.text: Integrate health and care services so as to look after carers as well as those they care for.

0_667.text: Recognise the rights of children who are disabled, and their families, in education, in the transition to adult life, in childcare, in healthcare and in the benefits system.

0_668.text: Recognise fully the housing needs of people who are disabled, including support with planning and obtaining housing.

0_669.text: Make it a licensing condition for taxis that drivers have Disability Awareness Training.

0_670.text: Young people Young people face very practical immediate problems with getting a good start in life.

0_671.text: Decent jobs, jobs with a future and training, are hard to come by.

0_672.text: The lucky few can get an internship or take advantage of good connections, but overall social mobility is in reverse.

0_673.text: You can go to university, but only if you are prepared to saddle yourself with a huge debt.

0_675.text: And threats such as climate change and ever-rising levels of inequality will have a far greater impact on future generations.

0_676.text: Young people must be supported outside school as well as in it; online and offline.

0_677.text: They need places they can call their own, where they can safely play and explore.

0_678.text: This means playgroups for toddlers, safe streets for kids to play in, and youth centres for teenagers.

0_679.text: The Green Party would: Ensure that the UK’s child protection systems are effective at tackling child neglect and abuse early on, including changing the law so that emotional abuse is treated on a par with physical abuse and giving police and child protection professionals clear guidance to help them work effectively.

0_680.text: Set clear targets for ending child poverty, including ways to measure it and fund local authorities properly so they can focus on early support to help children, young people and their families.

0_681.text: Increase the current investment in young people’s services, providing a comprehensive and inclusive youth service, including youth clubs, youth councils and non-curricular education and training, costing an extra £1.1 billion a year.

0_682.text: ` Extend free local public transport to young people and students, spending up to £4 billion a year.

0_683.text: `This would encourage the habit of using public transport among young people early on, with a view to making this a behaviour for life.

0_684.text: ` Support 20 mph zones, cycle schemes and public transport to make our streets safe and useful for young people.

0_685.text: Raise the age of criminal responsibility from 10 to 14.

0_687.text: Reform the judicial system to create a strong statutory presumption against the imprisonment of young offenders.

0_688.text: Restrict police use of random stop and search powers, which especially damage police relationships with young people.

0_689.text: Make higher education free and end the student loan system.

0_690.text: End the exploitation of interns; ensure no unpaid full-time internship lasts more than four weeks.

0_691.text: Make renting affordable and possible again for young people through our housing policies, especially those on regulating the private rented sector and rents.

0_692.text: End the exploitation of young people in low-wage jobs through our living wage policy.

0_694.text: Do more for young people who have no family; a basic first step would be to pay foster carers a salary, costing about £0.9 billion a year.

0_695.text: Provide access to suitable emergency accommodation for the 200,000 young people who go missing every year if they are unable to return home safely.

0_696.text: Support the right of young people all over Europe to go to other parts of the EU to work and broaden their experience.

0_697.text: Provide more training and work experience for young unemployed people through expanding apprenticeships; specifically, provide an apprenticeship to all qualified young people aged 16–25 who do not have one and want one.

0_698.text: What Green councillors do for young people out of school..

0_699.text: In 2012, Green councillor Simon Grover persuaded Tory-run St Albans, Hertfordshire, to pledge to provide a youth centre in the town in the next five years.

0_700.text: In Malvern, Worcestershire, Green councillor John Raines led the campaign to allow the community to buy a Council-owned youth centre earmarked for demolition and housing development.

0_701.text: It is now thriving under community ownership.

0_702.text: Older people and pensions Age used to be respected.

0_703.text: Now there’s the beginning of a backlash against older people, particularly the baby boomer generation approaching their seventies.

0_704.text: They’ve had it easy, it’s said – secure jobs, final salary pensions, good health and a housing market that has rewarded them but made it almost impossible for today’s young people to get housed.

0_705.text: And, as a generation, they have despoiled the planet and their swelling numbers threaten to bankrupt our health and pension systems.

0_706.text: The real picture is more complex.

0_707.text: There are huge inequalities between older people, and many have had difficult lives.

0_708.text: The free university education of the past was a privilege for a tiny group of people.

0_709.text: Many more working lives were totally disrupted by Margaret Thatcher’s assault on manufacturing industry in the 1980s – these older people bear the scars of industrial diseases and health inequalities.

0_710.text: Many older women in particular have lead lives confined by lack of opportunity.

0_711.text: The Green Party’s policy for older people is simple.

0_712.text: First they are people, and they have the same rights and hopes as everyone else.

0_713.text: They should be treated fairly and equally in employment, education, healthcare and avenues for enterprise.

0_714.text: Ambition should not be shut off just because we get older.

0_715.text: Second, there are certain things they should be able to rely on without the indignity of means testing.

0_716.text: The most basic is a universal state pension.

0_717.text: We would introduce a Citizen’s Pension, paid to all pensioners regardless of contribution record from 2016, so no pensioner will live in poverty.

0_718.text: It will pay £180 per week to a single pensioner and £310 per week for a couple, taking all pensioners above the poverty line.

0_719.text: Future increases will be at the higher of the price increases of basic goods and services or average earnings.

0_720.text: The failure of private pensions – making pensions secure Private pension schemes have failed.

0_721.text: The £40 billion government subsidy given to private pension schemes in the form of income tax and National Insurance reliefs is huge.

0_722.text: The performance of the private pensions industry is dismal – the total paid out in private pensions each year is no more than the subsidy that the government gives the industry.

0_723.text: We will begin to reform this.

0_724.text: We would raise part of the money needed for the Citizen’s Pension by abolishing about half of the value of these concessions; the money is better invested in a better pension for all.

0_725.text: We would further limit the amount of relief an individual can get on contributions in any one year, so that more of the subsidy goes to the lower paid.

0_726.text: We would make saving for retirement safe and predictable, by offering a new state earnings-related pension scheme.

0_727.text: This would invest through the Green Investment Bank in long-term public assets such as the railways, renewable energy and the National Grid, social and affordable housing, projects sponsored by local authorities, and public facilities such as hospitals.

0_728.text: These assets offer a safe, long-term and predictable rate of return – ideal for pensions – and the pension fund will provide the savings needed to invest in these assets.

0_729.text: Such public assets would replace pension fund assets, many of which consist of shares in energy companies whose main assets are unusable fossil fuel reserves.

0_730.text: Employers would be obliged to offer and contribute to this pension scheme, as they are now with stakeholder pensions; the default would be for employees to be contracted in to the scheme, and a person’s contributions would be unaffected by changes of employer.

0_731.text: In addition we will: Provide free social care funded by taxation on the same basis as the NHS.

0_732.text: Keep the pensioners’ bus pass and Winter Fuel Payment.

0_733.text: Provide free prescriptions for all and abolish the TV licence, making the current concessions unnecessary.

0_734.text: Support enforcing the rights of older people through the Dignity Code.

0_735.text: Make sure that all pensioners living abroad receive the same pension and annual pension increase as those living in the UK.

0_736.text: Support 20 mph zones, cycle schemes and public transport to make our streets safe and useful for older as well as young people.

0_737.text: Keep the NHS a public service, comprehensive and free at the point of delivery, especially recognising that the current generation of older people have paid for it all their lives and are now beginning to need it.

0_738.text: As is traditional, we have listed here items that are specifically in the interests of older people.

0_739.text: But we hope and believe that many older people will vote with their children and grandchildren in mind as much as themselves, and that they will in particular have in mind the long-term threats to our climate and environment.

0_740.text: Green councillors look after older people...

0_741.text: In 2012, Green councillor David Brookes was appointed the elderly people’s champion for Lancaster City Council and has persuaded the Council to advertise almshouse charity vacancies on its lettings site and to devote a web page to events and issues for the elderly.

0_742.text: In Bradford, Greens secured £300,000 to fund free cavity wall and loft insulation for older residents.

0_743.text: Joining up the policies So what do health, food, equality and transport have to do with each other?

0_744.text: We all know that, to be healthy we need to eat well and take more exercise.

0_745.text: So if we promote healthy eating, local food, good free school meals and active transport, we will be healthier.

0_746.text: And if we are all more equal, not only will we be healthier but more of us will use public transport and standards will rise.

0_747.text: And if as a result we are healthier, we’ll be more inclined to get an allotment, walk to the bus stop and get a bus, reducing climate change-producing gases.

0_749.text: CHAPTER 6 Imagine a National Health Society.

0_750.text: Imagine living in a clean environment, with satisfying work, good housing, a balanced diet, a good education, active, safe and sustainable transport, and much greater equality.

0_751.text: This is well-being – so vital to good health.

0_752.text: Imagine being in no doubt that the health service is publicly funded, with free prescriptions, dentistry and chiropody; one in which you have a human relationship with your doctors and nurses, who make your care their principal aim.

0_753.text: A health service in which individual and local knowledge take the place of protocols and pathways, and free social and nursing care is provided for the elderly; one which prizes prompt and local access to care, and encourages a culture of prevention as well as cure.

0_754.text: Imagine a system that respects and trusts health professionals and gives them the time, space, training and rewards to do their job.

0_755.text: This could be the real health service; it is the Green Party’s joined-up approach to health and well-being.

0_756.text: We will end NHS privatisation The Green Party believes healthcare shouldn’t be bought and sold.

0_757.text: All the other parties have encouraged the marketisation and privatisation of provision and this has led to: Fragmentation of services, with patients falling into gaps between providers, and poor communication between clinicians; Outsourcing, with companies cutting corners to win contracts; Cherry-picking of profitable treatments by private providers, leaving the NHS to provide treatments that are not properly funded; and An increase in administration costs of 9% of the NHS budget.

0_758.text: We will maintain a publicly funded, publicly provided health service free at the point of use.

0_759.text: Money spent on health will remain in the public economy, supporting the NHS rather than going into private companies’ profits.

0_760.text: We will: Repeal the Health and Social Care Act 2012, and introduce an NHS Reinstatement Bill restoring the obligation upon the government to provide a comprehensive health service, abolishing competition and the purchaser–provider split , ending market-based commissioning and procurement, re-establishing public bodies, a role for not-for-profit organisations and public accountability, restricting the role of commercial companies, and repealing the right of the Secretary of State to close hospitals or departments without effective public participation.

0_761.text: Promote transparency by ending commercial confidentiality.

0_762.text: Carry out an investigation into the opaque system of patronage and lobbying that has characterised the privatisation of the NHS.

0_763.text: Require NHS staff to declare financial interests that conflict with their role.

0_764.text: Stop further private finance initiative (PFI) contracts and end the inappropriate sale of NHS assets.

0_765.text: Seek ways to buy out existing PFI contracts where that would represent good value for money, and set aside up to £5 billion over the Parliament to do so.

0_766.text: Restore the public sector ethos of partnership between staff and patients.

0_767.text: Caroline Lucas opposing the Health and Social Care Act 2012 in Parliament: ‘The Bill opens the way for private companies to determine much of English health care and takes away the government’s duties and powers, which is why I believe it should be opposed.’

0_768.text: ‘Either we want an NHS free at the point of delivery and with free eye tests and so forth or we do not.’

0_769.text: Caroline has since introduced the NHS Reinstatement Bill.

0_770.text: We will end Health Service austerity

0_771.text: The Coalition government has not increased funding to keep up with inflation and increasing demand – indeed it has continued ‘efficiency savings’.

0_772.text: And money has been diverted into the cost of reorganisation and into profits for the private companies now running many services.

0_773.text: The result is one in four people going to crowded A&E Departments because they could not see a GP quickly enough, and a crisis in mental health care.

0_774.text: International comparisons underline that we can spend more – we spend just 9.6% of GDP on health (including private healthcare), the French 11.7%, the Germans 11.5% and the USA an astonishing 17.6%.

0_775.text: We would: Immediately increase the overall NHS budget by £12 billion a year to overcome the current funding crisis, increase investment in mental health care and provide for free dentistry, chiropody and prescriptions in England.

0_776.text: Thereafter, increase the overall NHS budget annually in real terms by 1.2% to take account of our ageing population.

0_777.text: Together with the previous item this will raise NHS budgets by about £20 billion by 2020.

0_778.text: Increase alcohol and tobacco taxes to help fund the annual increases in NHS spending over the Parliament.

0_779.text: Provide free social care as well as free healthcare for older people along the lines of the report from the Commission on the Future of Health and Social Care in England (Barker report), at an additional cost of around £8 billion a year initially but rising to £9 billion by the end of the Parliament.

0_780.text: Provide free social care at the end of life, enabling dying people to choose where they die.

0_781.text: We would also: Provide accessible, local community health centres that provide a wide range of services, including out-of-hours care.

0_782.text: These will help people access healthcare quickly rather than being a replacement for GPs.

0_784.text: For most of us patient choice is much less important than getting good treatment at our local hospital or health centre – which is often, for many, the only practical choice.

0_785.text: Listen to and work in partnership with third sector organisations that are championing patient care.

0_786.text: Ensure that all cost-effective treatments are available to all patients who need them.

0_787.text: Work to ensure that cancer outcomes in the UK are as good as the best in Europe.

0_788.text: Build systems to measure and improve the ecological impact of healthcare, from carbon costings of treatments (building them into the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence guidelines), to setting targets on recycling in NHS Trusts, and the issue of waste disposal.

0_789.text: A colossal amount of material waste is produced through the disposable culture that has taken hold in the fight against hospital-acquired infections.

0_791.text: The market town of Stowmarket, Suffolk, became the first in the county to open a new NHS dentist surgery after a lengthy campaign by Green councillors.

0_792.text: We will act to prevent illness and expand primary and community care The Green Party takes a whole society approach to health.

0_793.text: We care about what happens before you access the NHS.

0_794.text: Get that right, and a lot else falls into place.

0_795.text: How to achieve this affects how we organise the health service.

0_796.text: Those involved in primary and community care – GPs, practice nurses, district nurses, health visitors, midwives, counsellors, pharmacists, occupational therapists and all the other community based professionals – are best placed to prevent ill health from developing in the first place.

0_797.text: They can carry out checks and give advice or treatment to people who, for instance, are stressed, obese, inactive, or alcohol or nicotine dependent.

0_798.text: Intervention by a trusted health professional can make the difference at an individual level.

0_799.text: This can often be linked to local services, such as advice centres, opportunities for physical activity, lunch clubs and so on.

0_800.text: And it’s primary care that is most important in dealing with problems before they become acute and require costly and distressing interventions such as admission to hospital.

0_801.text: Local health professionals can also manage chronic illnesses such as diabetes, respiratory and cardiac conditions and mental illness in ways that are both more patient centred and less expensive than hospitalbased care.

0_802.text: They are best placed too to integrate medical and social care.

0_803.text: Where parents want it and there are no medical complications, normal childbirth could take place at home, increasing satisfaction for the woman in labour and reducing costs for the NHS.

0_804.text: Similarly, many people would prefer to spend their last days at home rather than in hospital and a small increase in community care would save hospital beds and make the experience better for the dying patient, their family and friends.

0_805.text: We would therefore place more emphasis on prevention and on primary and community care and less on hospitals.

0_806.text: We would: Restore the proportion of NHS funding for primary care from the present 7% to 2005 levels (11%) and review the case for increasing it further; we would also ensure that the distribution of funding reflects the local need.

0_807.text: Always consider whether services currently offered in or by hospitals could be transferred to the community.

0_808.text: Look for low-tech, local solutions as well as technical advances.

0_809.text: Encourage cooperation between all the primary care providers, e.g. pharmacies and hearing, optical and old age care organisations.

0_810.text: Tackle air pollution, which causes an estimated 29,000 premature deaths each year in the UK.

0_811.text: UK and EU standards on air pollution are out of date, and we would follow more rigorous standards that respect World Health Organization guidelines.

0_812.text: Give special attention to the well-being of children from conception to 2 years old, the first 1001 days.

0_813.text: For example, there should be national investment in evidence-based parenting programmes in order to improve the life chances of children and the well-being of families, and a free and universal early education and childcare service should be introduced.

0_814.text: Extend VAT at the standard rate to less healthy foods, including sugar, but spend the money raised on subsidising around one-third of the cost of fresh fruit and vegetables.

0_815.text: This could prevent around 5,000 premature deaths every year.

0_816.text: Put a minimum price on alcohol of 50p per unit.

0_817.text: This will reduce the physical, psychological and social harm associated with problem drinking, and will have only a negligible impact on those who drink in moderation.

0_818.text: Put the UK at the centre of efforts to end the AIDS, TB and malaria epidemics and the threat they pose to the health of women, men and children living in poverty.

0_819.text: Treat drug addiction as a health problem rather than a crime, making drugs policy the responsibility of the Department of Health in order to ensure that resources are targeted at supporting, not punishing, drug users.

0_820.text: Adopt an evidence-based approach to the step-by-step regulation, starting with cannabis, of the drugs currently banned under the Misuse of Drugs Act as well as ‘legal highs’, with a view to introducing a system that reduces harms and brings the market under state control as a potential tax revenue generator.

0_821.text: A Royal Commission or similar body would be established to review currently controlled drug classifications, within a legalised environment of drug use.

0_822.text: Introduce a regime of presumed consent for organ donation, which respects the right of relatives to refuse consent.

0_823.text: Provide the right to an assisted death within a rigorous framework of regulation and in the context of the availability of the highest level of palliative care.

0_826.text: Green councillors will stand up to fast-food chains...After KFC applied to open a drive-through store close to a primary school in Solihull, Green councillor Andy Hodgson persuaded the Council to toughen up its planning rules to allow refusal of fast-food chains near schools.

0_827.text: We will restore a person-centred approach to the NHS The Green Party listens to knowledge and experience, not political dogma The introduction to this sub-section has been written by Dr Jillian Creasy, who worked as a GP in Sheffield for 25 years.

0_828.text: It draws on her real experience of the NHS over that time.

0_829.text: Jillian is also Green Party Health Spokesperson and candidate for Sheffield Central.

0_830.text: Patient care has been damaged by two policies: punitive governance based on arbitrary targets; over-management by numbers to achieve those targets, leading to a climate of fear among managers and frustration among professionals.

0_831.text: The NHS should have the needs of the patient at its heart.

0_832.text: Ultimately, healthcare is provided by a professional to a person in need.

0_833.text: Every interaction should begin by connecting with that person to really understand their needs.

0_834.text: Interventions – from simple advice or booking an appointment, to planning complex medical treatment – will then be more appropriate and efficient, of real value to the user and economic for the organisation.

0_835.text: The NHS has been subjected to 20 years of ideological tampering by successive governments (marketisation, targets and performance-related pay) to the point where professionals are often prevented from responding appropriately to an individual’s needs.

0_836.text: This has also driven up the cost of care.

0_837.text: Fragmentation of care, especially outsourcing, has led to a loss of continuity, so the human relationship between professional and patient is diluted.

0_838.text: Professionals can no longer make the overall care of the patient their primary aim.

0_839.text: Huge amounts of time and money are wasted on ‘failure demand’ – where the patient goes round in circles trying to get an answer to their problem and often has unnecessary investigations and treatment.

0_840.text: More problems are created by so-called ‘economies of scale’ where, in an attempt to emulate industry, common services have been merged into larger entities regardless of the nature of the variety of demand.

0_841.text: Individual and local knowledge are lost and problems are dealt with according to protocols and pathways, not what is best for the patient.

0_843.text: The system must be designed around what the patient needs, not what Monitor (the sector regulator for health services in England) or the Care Quality Commission demand.

0_844.text: Professionals must be given the time to care, rather than ticking governance boxes.

0_845.text: The ‘human-centred’ approach also applies to NHS staff.

0_846.text: The vast majority of NHS workers are highly committed, caring and careful individuals, but current systems often put them under stress and prevent them doing the right thing.

0_847.text: We need a culture in which all staff are able to shape the system they work in and to openly share learning from mistakes and ‘near misses’.

0_848.text: It should be a source of pride and joy, not fear and frustration, for those who work in it.

0_849.text: The Green Party would: Place the quality of patient care, especially patient safety, at the heart of the system.

0_850.text: Reducing costs would not be the primary driver of behaviour but would be the outcome of best practice.

0_851.text: Evolve the best system of care with the help of the service providers.

0_852.text: Engage, empower and hear patients and carers at all times, treating both with dignity.

0_853.text: Foster whole-heartedly the growth, development and training of all staff, including their involvement in improving the systems in which they work.

0_854.text: Embrace transparency in the interests of sharing best practice, accountability and cooperation.

0_855.text: Use quantitative data to better understand how the system is working, not to set targets, and to see them as a route to continuously improving patient care, not an end in themselves.

0_856.text: Ensure that there are clear lines of responsibility, especially for safety and interdepartmental cooperation.

0_857.text: Respect the NHS Pay Review Body and bring NHS pay back in line with inflation and negotiate improved conditions.

0_858.text: Expand the workforce to drive the wholesale improvement of mental health services.

0_859.text: The extra funding proposed for the NHS and social care will create a total of 400,000 jobs.

0_860.text: We will tackle the crisis of our time: Mental health There has been an alarming rise in mental health problems in recent years, especially among young people.

0_861.text: According to NHS England, mental illness accounts for 28% of illness but only 13% of NHS spending.

0_862.text: In the course of a year, one in four adults experiences some form of mental ill health If you have diabetes there’s a 92% chance you’ll get treatment.

0_863.text: If you have a mental illness, that chance goes down to 28%.

0_864.text: Around 70% of prisoners have two or more mental health conditions.

0_865.text: The government’s own Chief Medical Officer says mental health should be given greater priority.

0_866.text: It will take time to train more staff and expand services but the Green Party will put an end to mental health’s Cinderella status and achieve parity of esteem by 2020.

0_867.text: We will: Ensure that spending on mental health care rises within our overall commitment to increase real spending on health.

0_868.text: Ensure that no one waits more than 28 days for access to talking therapies.

0_869.text: Ensure that everyone experiencing a mental health crisis, including children and young people, should have safe and speedy access to quality care, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

0_870.text: The use of police cells as ‘places of safety’ for children should be eliminated by 2016, and by the end of the next Parliament should only occur for adults in exceptional circumstances.

0_871.text: Ensure that everyone who requires a mental health bed should be able to access one in their local NHS Trust area, unless they need specialist care and treatment.

0_872.text: If specialist care is required, then this should be provided within a reasonable distance of where the patient lives.

0_873.text: Implement a campaign to end the discrimination and stigma associated with mental health through supporting the Time for Change programme and offering employment support to those with mental health problems.

0_874.text: Invest in dementia services, ensuring that support is available for all affected by this debilitating disease, including families and carers.

0_875.text: Pay special attention to any mental health issues of mothers during and after pregnancy, children and adolescents, Black and Minority Ethnic people, refugees, the LGBTIQ communities and ex-service people and their families.

0_876.text: Improve access to addiction services, including both drugs and alcohol addiction.

0_877.text: Give higher priority to the physical healthcare of those with mental health problems.

0_878.text: Joining up the policies So what do mental health, drugs, crime and welfare have to do with each other?

0_879.text: Our current welfare system breeds desperation and stress, not security, causing mental health problems.

0_880.text: Ending workfare and making work pay better will bring security and encourage better mental health.

0_881.text: Mental health problems foster drug dependency and crime.

0_882.text: If we can improve mental health, drug use and crime rates will fall.

0_883.text: With lower drug use and crime, and a supportive welfare system, more people will find useful things to do, improving their mental health.

0_885.text: CHAPTER 7 Imagine free universal early education and childcare, with compulsory education starting at 7.

0_886.text: Smaller classes and free nutritious lunches.

0_889.text: Less teaching to the test and the abolition of SATS and league tables.

0_891.text: Apprenticeships for 16–25 year olds who want them.

0_892.text: The restoration of the Education Maintenance Allowance for 16–17 year olds and the abolition of university tuition fees.

0_893.text: Imagine schools and colleges fit for children and young adults Education is good for each of us, but it is also good for all of us – it’s a common good.

0_894.text: That’s why the Green Party will make education free for everyone up to and including university or equivalent.

0_896.text: Although the single most important factor for a child’s development is the learning environment at home, high-quality pre-school education can make a big difference.

0_897.text: The government has focused on lower-quality childcare, which has little or no effect.

0_898.text: Moreover, disadvantaged children who attend settings with children from mixed social backgrounds make more progress than those in settings serving mainly disadvantaged children.

0_899.text: These findings are why we want to create a universal high-quality early years education system used by everyone, to give every child the best possible start.

0_900.text: Great credit is due to the previous Labour government for its Sure Start children’s centres.

0_901.text: But too many of these have closed as a result of austerity.

0_902.text: Although support for childcare has grown under the Coalition, the government provides scant support to parents in the first two years of a child’s life, and too much of the emphasis for the next three years is on expanding free and subsidised childcare so that parents, especially women, can work.

0_903.text: Too little attention is paid to the child and to the value of early education.

0_904.text: The Green Party proposes to extend the education system to provide a free, universal and flexible system of good-quality early education and support for parents from birth until the age of compulsory education.

0_905.text: We would: Build a free but voluntary universal early education and childcare service for all children from birth until compulsory education age, which we would raise to 7 years.

0_906.text: Integrate this into the local education service, run by local education authorities, and build on existing infant schools.

0_907.text: Local authorities would be would be given freedom as to how to do so in the light of their local circumstances.

0_908.text: Ensure that the system includes children’s centres for the very youngest children and their parents, and childcare and early education for children from age .

0_909.text: Ensure that those who lead early years education are qualified teachers with qualified teacher status and with specialist knowledge of early years education; and ensure all other staff are qualified to level 3.

0_910.text: Encourage parents to participate in helping to run the service.

0_911.text: Ensure that parents would receive much increased Child Benefit from 2016 and would continue to receive Statutory Maternity and Paternity Pay.

0_912.text: We estimate that in the longer run this will cost around £8 billion a year over and above the cost of the existing free and subsidised schemes and tax concessions, which would be abolished.

0_913.text: Schools Teachers feel undervalued and their professionalism is undermined by a strict curriculum.

0_914.text: Two-fifths of teachers quit within five years of beginning their careers, ground down by an excessive workload, much of it unrelated to teaching.

0_915.text: The Green Party believes that children are over-assessed and teachers are over-regulated.

0_916.text: Teaching to the test is not satisfying teaching

0_917.text: and it’s boring for students, yet that’s what successive governments have obliged teachers to do.

0_918.text: We need to free teachers and pupils to rediscover the excitement of learning, released from the shackles of a system designed with only economic competitiveness and preparation for work in mind, and with excessive teacher workloads burdened by bureaucracy.

0_919.text: We are determined to make schools fit for children rather than the other way round.

0_920.text: In line with Green Party principles, decisions around education will be taken at the most local level possible, but in general we support: Democratic accountability and a key role for local authorities in planning, admissions policy and equality of access for children with special needs.

0_921.text: A comprehensive system of local schools offering mixed-ability teaching and staffed by qualified teachers, and the integration of grammar schools into the comprehensive system.

0_922.text: Restoring education current and capital funding to 2010 levels in real terms (costing around £7 billion a year) and distributing it fairly among local authorities, reflecting the core costs of education, pupil needs, the quality of existing school buildings and equity between school types.

0_923.text: With the new early education service above, and counting the expansion of apprenticeships below this, would create around a quarter of a million jobs.

0_924.text: Action to reduce teacher workload and introduce professional pay levels for all teachers.

0_925.text: Ending the marketisation and outsourcing of education.

0_926.text: Leaving local education authorities free to decide how much to allocate to current spending and how much to capital projects.

0_927.text: Class sizes of 20, costing £1.5 billion over the Parliament.

0_928.text: The integration of academies and free schools into the local authority system.

0_929.text: Academic learning from 6 years old, with earlier years education focusing on play, social cohesion and confidence-building, and compulsory education beginning at age 7.

0_930.text: The abolition of SATS and league tables and the evaluation of schools by parents, teachers and the local community, not Ofsted (the Office for Standards in Education, Children’s Services and Skills), which we would abolish, reducing the accountability-related workload.

0_931.text: A broad, balanced and enriching curriculum, including creative and vocational areas, and making PSHE (including sex and relationships education, and also first aid) compulsory, with a coherent 16–19 qualifications framework allowing a real choice of academic and vocational areas, or a mixture of them.

0_932.text: An increase in outdoor education and physical activity so children establish an early and strong relationship with their local environment.

0_933.text: The right for every child who is disabled to a mainstream education.

0_934.text: The removal of charitable status from private schools, with a view to absorbing them into the state system, but nevertheless ensuring that no schools are run for profit.

0_935.text: We will phase out public funding of schools run by religious organisations.

0_936.text: Schools may teach about religions, but should not encourage adherence to any particular religious beliefs.

0_938.text: Free nutritious lunches, with local and GM-free ingredients, and children involved in growing, preparing and cooking food where possible.

0_939.text: The number of infants eating school lunches since the current free meals were introduced has increased from just 300,000 to 1,640,530 now.

0_940.text: The extension will cost an additional £2 billion a year.

0_941.text: Ensuring that all schools that serve particular vulnerable communities, for example the Jewish, Muslim or Sikh communities, are adequately protected from sectarian attacks.

0_942.text: An end to the trend whereby parents have to buy as extras equipment needed at school or for participation on expensive school trips.

0_943.text: Caroline Lucas on personal, social, health and economic education In Parliament, Green MP Caroline Lucas led on making sure that all young people get taught high-quality PSHE (personal, social, health and economic education).

0_944.text: She introduced a Bill in Parliament to require all schools to teach the subject and for teachers to get proper training and support.

0_945.text: Good PSHE is key to ending violence against women and girls and also has significant knock-on benefits for both academic attainment and future employability.

0_946.text: Statutory PSHE is supported by the National Union of Teachers, Mumsnet, Stonewall, Girlguiding, Everyday Sexism and the Royal College of Nursing, among others.

0_947.text: Further education and skills training We will: Oppose the privatisation of further education and return further education colleges to the democratic control of local government.

0_948.text: Reverse the trend whereby 45% of apprenticeships, that is, jobs with structured training, are now taken by people over 25.

0_949.text: We would reinstate the government’s duty to provide an apprenticeship to all qualified young people aged 16–19 who do not have one and want one, but extend it to age 25, and increase funding for apprenticeships by 30%.

0_950.text: Restore the Education Maintenance Allowance for 16 and 17 year olds.

0_951.text: Provide the further education sector with £1.5 billion a year extra funding.

0_952.text: Connect universities with local schools and colleges through nationwide Widening Participation programmes.

0_953.text: Encourage local authorities to use some of the additional money we propose to give to them to restore a full range of local adult education programmes.

0_954.text: End the anomaly whereby schools and academies can reclaim VAT on goods and services whereas sixth form colleges and further education colleges cannot, by allowing the latter to claim, costing around £170 million a year.

0_955.text: Prioritise training in the skills needed to build a low-carbon economy.

0_956.text: Greens in power carry out our policies Education in Brighton & Hove was for long a major concern to parents in the city, but since the Greens came to office results have improved.

0_957.text: The 2013 GCSE results were the best ever, though they fell in 2014 after tougher marking was introduced across the country.

0_958.text: ‘A’ level results continued to improve in 2014.

0_959.text: And 80% of sixth forms and colleges are good or outstanding as judged by Ofsted.

0_960.text: Higher education Higher education is in crisis.

0_961.text: The fundamental purpose of universities should be to promote critical enquiry, social innovation and cultural renewal.

0_962.text: But these aims have been sidelined in an atmosphere of increasing managerialism and commercialisation.

0_963.text: Higher education is vital to our cultural health.

0_964.text: It should be concerned with public engagement and increasing social participation, not considered merely a production line for enhancing the earning power of individuals.

0_965.text: The current focus on research ‘outputs’– in the narrow definition used by the Research Excellence Framework – means that the crucial role of lecturers as teachers has been denigrated.

0_966.text: This emphasis needs to be reversed.

0_967.text: The Conservative-led Coalition and the Labour Party bear responsibility for the current system of university funding, which is largely dependent on tuition fees that now stand at £9,000 a year for undergraduates.

0_968.text: This was a betrayal of a promise and has blighted the future of thousands of young people who now graduate with a debt of at least £45,000.

0_969.text: With the removal of public funding from most undergraduate and all postgraduate courses, UK universities are now all but privatised.

0_970.text: The only people to benefit from the current system are university Vice-Chancellors and senior bureaucrats, who award themselves massive pay rises, while those on the ground who carry out teaching and research face ever more punishing terms and conditions of employment.

0_971.text: In practice, this severely compromises the quality of education through reduced student-contact hours with overstretched staff.

0_972.text: Zero-hours contracts are now commonplace and shocking disparities in pay characterise every campus, especially among service workers, who are commonly denied a living wage.

0_973.text: Conversely, university administrative departments continue to swell as money is routinely wasted on copying expensive private sector practices – including ludicrous rebranding exercises – in search of ‘market share’.

0_974.text: The future of the arts and the humanities has been endangered by a systematic denigration by the dominant political parties and university administrations alike, who create a perception of such courses as an expensive luxury without the vocational ‘use-value’ that renders them worth the financial risk.

0_975.text: The Green Party believes that the arts and humanities have an essential part to play in creating a more democratic, sane and participatory society.

0_976.text: The situation for mature students is even more dire.

0_977.text: Over the past five years, every continuing education department in the UK has been scaled back or closed down altogether, often as a managerial response to caps on students numbers and diminished funding for the sector as a whole.

0_978.text: Adults wishing to return to education are faced with a situation where short courses and part-time study are considered not cost-effective in market terms.

0_979.text: In December 2010, just after the trebling of tuition fees, Caroline Lucas MP argued that the costs of a free higher education could be met by increasing corporation tax for larger companies to the level paid in other G7 countries and ring-fencing some of that money.

0_980.text: Businesses depend enormously on graduates’ skills and knowledge, so it’s only fair that they invest in the higher education system from which they benefit.

0_981.text: Allied to this, the cost of studying the qualifications that universities stipulate as entry requirements is prohibitive.

0_982.text: An ‘A’ level for those who are not registered as school or college students attracts a fee of several hundred pounds.

0_983.text: Access to education diplomas are also meshed within a loan system for those over the age of 24, and uniformly cost in excess of £3,000.

0_984.text: The part-time and short courses for which non-traditional applicants can enrol are often hugely expensive, especially when measured against the contact-time with lecturers.

0_985.text: ‘Lifelong Learning’ is a phrase that is much used by politicians and education professionals.

0_986.text: Giving people the opportunity to be ‘second chance’ learners should be a crucial part of what universities offer to wider society.

0_987.text: Countering the monetisation of higher education across the entire sector is vital to reverse the destructive and wasteful market model of university education.

0_988.text: The Green Party would address this through:

0_990.text: We appreciate that the current level of applications to study at university reflects the paucity of other opportunities available to young people.

0_991.text: This is part of a wider social problem that must be tackled To be saddled with a huge debt for the right to access higher education at the beginning or middle of adulthood is neither ethical nor sustainable.

0_992.text: Because of the way the student loans system works this would cost about £4.5 billion over this Parliament, and in the long run around £8 billion a year.

0_993.text: Cancelling student debt issued by the Student Loans Company and held by the government.

0_994.text: Taking account of the loans that it is expected would never be re-paid, the total value of these loans is estimated to be around £30 billion.

0_995.text: Assuming that these loans would be paid off over the next 25 years, and taking account of interest, this amounts to around £2.2 billion a year in revenue that the government would not receive.

0_996.text: Reintroducing student grants costing £2.2 billion over the Parliament.

0_997.text: In the longer run we would support student living costs through the Basic Income.

0_998.text: In the longer term, considering scrapping fees for academic postgraduate courses.

0_999.text: Restoring access to lifelong learning by supporting mature students and their families.

0_1000.text: We will reverse the 20-year programme of dismantling the lifelong learning sector.

0_1001.text: Reintroducing the block grant to universities.

0_1002.text: It is essential that teaching and learning can be supported effectively across the sciences and the humanities.

0_1003.text: Encouraging universities and pension funds such as the Universities Superannuation Scheme to divest from fossil fuel companies.

0_1004.text: This would follow the example of the University of Glasgow.

0_1006.text: We are committed to ending the scandal of Vice-Chancellors paying themselves £300,000 a year while cleaners on the national minimum wage have to resort to food banks.

0_1008.text: Greens in Brighton have made it standard practice for apprenticeships and training schemes to be included in all Council construction contracts.

0_1012.text: It doesn’t have to be this way.

0_1013.text: The Green Party has policies to make housing affordable and sustainable, to make sure there is enough to go round, and to provide better quality and greater security in the private rented sector.

0_1014.text: A secure and affordable place to live is one of our most basic human needs.

0_1015.text: But houses and flats are now sites of speculation rather than simply somewhere to call home.

0_1016.text: They were at the heart of the crash seven years ago, when reckless lending left banks unable to support themselves.

0_1017.text: We need to return housing to its original purpose: providing us – each and every one of us – with affordable and sustainable shelter.

0_1018.text: There are three reasons for the current chaos and unfairness: A misplaced faith in the market as the way to meet housing needs, where the market for houses has too often reflected a desire to make an investment rather than buy a place to live, and prices have risen faster than inflation; A lack of investment in public housing for at least 20 years, following Right to Buy and restrictions on what local authorities can do; and A private rented sector where too often people have insecurity of tenure and are being charged extortionate rents for unsatisfactory housing.

0_1020.text: In July 2014 Caroline Lucas MP introduced a Housing (Affordability, Supply and Tenant Protection) Bill to highlight the problems faced by private tenants.

0_1021.text: The Bill required the Secretary of State to commission a programme of research into reducing rent levels in the private rented sector, improving terms and conditions for tenants, increasing housing supply, and providing a large-scale programme of sustainable council housing in England.

0_1022.text: Caroline has published a Housing Charter, suggesting how these national policies would help in Brighton.

0_1023.text: You can find it here: http://www.carolinelucas.com/assets/files/localparties/brighton/publications/Caroline/Caroline%20Lucas%20Housing%20 Charter%20(2).pdf; or http://tinyurl.com/m8xh4g3 The housing market: House price stability House prices continue to rise quicker than wages and inflation, and first-time buyers find it almost impossible to buy a home.

0_1024.text: If wages had gone up by as much as house prices since 1997, the average person would be earning almost £30,000 more a year.

0_1025.text: When house prices crash there are consequences for the whole economy.

0_1026.text: The Green Party will aim for house price stability by making property investment and speculation less attractive and by increasing housing supply.

0_1027.text: We will: Give the Bank of England the powers it has requested to limit the size of mortgages in relation to the property value and the borrower’s income.

0_1028.text: Take steps to ensure that development is more evenly distributed across the whole of the country, so reducing pressure on housing in the South East in particular.

0_1029.text: Make ‘buy to let’ less attractive, so reducing pressure on house prices, by removing tax incentives, including the deduction of mortgage interest as an expense, and reforming the ‘wear and tear’ allowance.

0_1030.text: Introduce new higher Council Tax bands for more expensive homes, with higher rates for empty homes.

0_1031.text: Scrap the government’s Help to Buy scheme, which does nothing to help those in the greatest housing need and contributes to excessive demand, saving £600 million a year.

0_1032.text: Take action on empty homes to bring them back into use.

0_1034.text: Halve this number through Empty Property Use Orders.

0_1035.text: Gradually phase out Stamp Duty Land Tax and consider a Land Value Tax.

0_1036.text: Minimise encroachment onto undeveloped ‘greenfield sites’ wherever possible by reusing previously developed sites that have fallen into disuse.

0_1037.text: Reduce VAT on housing renovation and repair work (including insulation) to 5%, costing £1.6 billion a year.

0_1038.text: At present there is no VAT on constructing new dwellings but there is VAT at 20% on converting and renovating old buildings to be used as homes.

0_1039.text: This encourages new building at the expense of saving land and using what we have.

0_1040.text: Introduce the right to rent (where local councils step in to help those in difficulty with their mortgage to rent their home).

0_1041.text: Onethird of mortgage borrowers are expected to struggle if interest rates increase by 2%.

0_1042.text: Break up the big builder cartels and diversify the house-building industry so that more homes are built by small- and medium-sized builders and by community-led and cooperative initiatives.

0_1043.text: In the short term we would achieve this by measures including bringing transparency to the land market, the transfer of public land into community land trusts, and parcelling big regeneration sites into smaller plots through the Custom Build model.

0_1044.text: Public housing: Providing 500,000 new social rented homes

0_1045.text: Successive governments’ affordable and social housing policies have failed.

0_1046.text: There is not enough housing for those unable to afford either to buy or to pay market rents.

0_1047.text: The time has come to reverse the decline of council housing, started by the ‘Right to Buy’.

0_1048.text: We would: Provide 500,000 social rented homes to high sustainability standards by increasing the social housing budget from £1.5 billion a year to £6 billion a year in the lifetime of the Parliament, removing borrowing caps from local councils, and creating 35,000 jobs.

0_1049.text: Devolve Housing Benefit budgets to councils, so they can design packages that improve access to housing in their local market and enable them to provide more council housing.

0_1050.text: End mass council house sales and the Right to Buy at a discounted price.

0_1051.text: Provide more rights for homeless people, giving local authorities the same duties with regard to single people and childless couples as to families, and ending the practice of declaring people ‘intentionally homeless’.

0_1052.text: Aim to end rough sleeping completely, and give public authorities a duty to prevent it.

0_1053.text: Oppose new arm’s length management organisations and ensure genuine tenant participation in existing ones.

0_1054.text: Greens in power carry out our housing policies In Green-led Brighton:

0_1055.text: In November 2012 Brighton Council introduced a new licensing scheme by which private landlords letting a property for sharing by three or more people must bring it up to an agreed standard.

0_1056.text: More than 1,500 licences were applied for by April 2014.

0_1057.text: By July 2014 the Green-led Council had brought some 416 council homes and more than 460 empty private homes back into use.

0_1058.text: By November 2014 Greens had overseen the delivery of 389 affordable homes (as part of wider residential and mixed developments).

0_1059.text: Another 130 are due to be completed before May 2015.

0_1060.text: In the Green Party’s term of administration it will have overseen the building of 639 homes.

0_1061.text: A further 681 affordable homes, including more than 200 new council homes, are in the development pipeline.

0_1062.text: For the first time in living memory, communal heating bills in some Brighton & Hove Council blocks have fallen as Council tenants benefit from a major programme of energy efficiency retro-fitting.

0_1063.text: Make renting normal and not a rip-off

0_1064.text: There is a place for a private rented sector.

0_1065.text: But experience shows that it needs to be well regulated and the difference in power between landlord and tenant corrected.

0_1066.text: We would: Reform the private rented sector by introducing a ‘living rent’ tenancy (including five-year fixed tenancy agreements), smart rent control that caps annual rent increases linked to the Consumer Price Index, security of tenancy and local not-for-profit letting agencies, and abolishing letting agents’ fees and insurance-based deposit schemes.

0_1067.text: Set up a Living Rent Commission to explore whether controls could bring rents more in line with local average incomes.

0_1068.text: Introduce a mandatory licensing scheme for landlords.

0_1069.text: Abolish landlord perks, such as tax deductions against a variety of expenditures, including mortgage interest relief.

0_1070.text: Ending mortgage interest tax relief alone will raise £5.8 billion a year.

0_1071.text: Increase the supply of small lets by raising the tax-free amount under the Rent a Room Scheme to £7,250 a year.

0_1072.text: Abolish the ‘bedroom tax’, which has saved less than £400 million a year.

0_1073.text: A Department for Work and Pensions report found that more than half of affected tenants have cut back on essentials, and only 1 in 20 has downsized.

0_1074.text: Bring Housing Benefit for all age groups back in line with average market rents, so that it provides all citizens with the means to meet their housing costs, costing £2.3 billion a year.

0_1075.text: Subject the Shared Accommodation Rate to a comprehensive review to ensure it reflects the real cost of renting shared properties.

0_1076.text: Change the definition of affordable rented housing to depend on local median incomes and not on local market rents.

0_1077.text: The ‘bedroom tax’ The ‘under occupancy charge’ – the bedroom tax – came into effect in April 2013.

0_1078.text: It affects nearly 500,000 people – the equivalent of a city the size of Leicester.

0_1079.text: Two-thirds of those affected are disabled.

0_1080.text: Cash-strapped housing associations have spent millions helping affected tenants.

0_1081.text: By February 2014, two-thirds of residents hit by the bedroom tax were in rent arrears.

0_1082.text: The Tories devised it, the Lib Dems backed it and Ed Miliband took a year to decide he didn’t like it.

0_1083.text: Green MP Caroline Lucas has voted against the bedroom tax at every opportunity.

0_1085.text: In Solihull, Green councillor Chris Williams publicised the plight of a woman who had just had a heart transplant and her 14-yearold daughter who were forced to live in a private hotel for 18 months with rats running through their room as they slept.

0_1086.text: Since then Solihull has reduced the use of B&Bs to house the homeless.

0_1087.text: CHAPTER 9 Imagine a world of sustainable prosperity for all, one in which secure, satisfying, decently paid jobs are the norm.

0_1088.text: Where the power to create money is taken out of private hands and democratised for public benefit.

0_1089.text: Imagine going to a People’s Bank, confident that it is working for you rather than for its shareholders.

0_1090.text: Imagine that you and everyone else are being taxed with fairness and sustainability in mind, and that tax is actually collected.

0_1091.text: Imagine working in a more mixed and localised economy.

0_1092.text: Imagine a revival of workers’ rights and vibrant trade unions.

0_1093.text: Imagine knowing that almost half of national income is spent on the common good – on the ties that bind us together – rather than on paying down debts you didn’t cause.

0_1094.text: This is the common wealth we create by working together, sharing the fruits of our work fairly and building the infrastructure of our common life.

0_1095.text: Right now, society is too unequal, too much valuable work goes unrecognised, and our infrastructure is not fit for a common and sustainable life.

0_1096.text: The Green Party’s proposals will make for a fairer and more sustainable society.

0_1097.text: Work People want to work and the Green Party believes in helping make that happen.

0_1098.text: We also believe everyone should be properly paid for the work they do, ending working poverty and the job insecurity that has people lining up outside food banks and left at the mercy of payday lenders.

0_1099.text: We don’t just need jobs, we need more worthwhile secure jobs.

0_1100.text: Under the Coalition, 1 million jobs have been lost from the public sector – from the NHS, from schools and colleges, from local government, from the institutions that bind us together, from front-line services.

0_1102.text: The Coalition claims to have created 2.5 million jobs in the private sector to compensate.

0_1103.text: But: Many job-market casualties have turned to self-employment, where life can be precarious and salaries low (there has been a 20% fall in the salaries of the self-employed since 2007, compared with a 6% fall in employee earnings); 15% of the workforce is self-employed.

0_1104.text: For some this is by choice, for others it is because they can’t get better work; Many new jobs are insecure, poorly paid and with contracts that fail to balance the rights and responsibilities of employers and employees; The young in particular suffer, with one in three young workers now on low pay; and They’ve redefined some jobs out of the public and into the private sector.

0_1105.text: In place of this workplace lottery, the Green Party proposes a package for sustainable prosperity : ending austerity, expanding and renewing public services such as social care, transport and social housing, investing in energy conservation and sustainable resource use, and promoting green public works for environmental benefit.

0_1106.text: This will create 1 million new satisfying jobs and training places within a year.

0_1107.text: Green councillors support the living wage...

0_1108.text: In Lewisham, Norwich, Lancashire, Camden, Worcester, Stroud and Brighton & Hove, minority Green councillors successfully campaigned for a living wage to help tackle poverty.

0_1109.text: We will: Increase the minimum wage so that it is a living wage.

0_1110.text: We propose a minimum wage target for everyone who is working in the UK of £10 per hour by 2020.

0_1111.text: In 2015 this would mean a minimum wage of £8.10 an hour generally (and £9.40 in London), saving £2.4 billion a year in tax credits and generating an additional £1.5 billion a year in income tax and National Insurance.

0_1112.text: This would be offset by £0.7 billion a year additional costs in the public sector.

0_1113.text: Revive the role of democratic trade unions, including the right to belong to a union and have the employer recognise it, and the right to take industrial action, including strikes and peaceful picketing.

0_1115.text: Apart from improving the quality of our lives, this would combat unemployment by sharing available work out more equitably.

0_1116.text: Provide a comprehensive nationwide system of good-quality pre-school early education and childcare, free at the point of delivery.

0_1118.text: End the exploitation of interns, and ensure no unpaid full-time internship lasts more than four weeks.

0_1119.text: Make equal pay for men and women a reality.

0_1120.text: Introduce a maximum pay ratio of 10:1 between the best paid and the worst paid in every organisation.

0_1122.text: We will set up a full investigation into blacklisting in the construction industry and consider the creation of a new criminal offence.

0_1123.text: Give workers a greater say in the running of their companies, including employee-elected directors in medium and larger companies.

0_1124.text: Reduce Employment Tribunal fees so that tribunals are accessible to workers.

0_1125.text: Greens in power carry out our policies The Green-led administration in Brighton cut the chief executive’s salary and raised the pay of the lowest grades, bringing the ratio between the highest and lowest paid Council staff to just over 10:1.

0_1126.text: Finance The UK finance industry is a disaster area.

0_1127.text: Far from generating genuine wealth, its recklessness and greed created the greatest recession since the 1930s, which in turn contributed to the present regime of austerity and cuts to public services.

0_1128.text: It has presided over other failures, from the mis-selling of endowment mortgages and payment protection insurance, to the appallingly low returns and high charges of the state-subsidised private pensions industry, its failure to mobilise long-term finance for renewable energy and its collusion in and creation of a whole industry of tax avoidance and evasion.

0_1129.text: Meanwhile, those who work in the industry at senior level show no signs of remorse and continue to pocket huge salaries and bonuses.

0_1130.text: Finance needs root and branch reform.

0_1131.text: We would: Move towards creating all national currency through a national monetary authority, answerable to Parliament.

0_1132.text: The power to create money must be taken out of the hands of private banks.

0_1133.text: Detailed proposals are set out in the ‘Regaining control of our money’ box.

0_1135.text: Retail banks should be required to limit their role to taking deposits and making loans that facilitate economic activity; investment banks should take the form of partnerships rather than limited companies.

0_1137.text: Act to control payday lenders and offer alternatives (see the ‘Greens in power’ credit union box).

0_1138.text: We will use the government-owned Royal Bank of Scotland to create a network of local banks for every city and region, ensuring that each bank is a People’s Bank, obliged to offer cheap basic banking services.

0_1139.text: Invest £2 billion in a network of community banks, mutually owned and serving local areas or particular groups.

0_1140.text: Expand the role and the funds of the Green Investment Bank by offering green Individual Savings Accounts and pensions, allowing the bank to borrow and boosting the equity in the bank by £9 billion over the Parliament.

0_1141.text: Introduce a Robin Hood tax (a financial transaction tax) to reduce destabilising speculation (see the ‘Taxes’ section below for details).

0_1142.text: Work for the abolition of the City of London Corporation and the special statuses it enjoys.

0_1143.text: Greens in power carry out our policies The Green-led administration in Brighton invested £100,000 in a local credit union, partly to help it set up an online system for residents to access loans, making the credit union as accessible as high-interest payday lenders.

0_1144.text: It also banned such lenders from advertising on Council billboards.

0_1145.text: In 2013 Green MP Caroline Lucas worked with East Sussex Credit Union to show ministers how to help credit unions fulfil their potential by, for example, ending the restrictions that put them at a competitive disadvantage when compared with banks.

0_1146.text: Regaining control of our money One of the most fundamental tasks of government is maintenance of the currency.

0_1147.text: Without stable money accepted by all we can’t buy and sell things or plan for the future.

0_1148.text: Inflation in particular makes it hard to take the long-term view that the environmental crisis demands.

0_1149.text: Most people believe that our money is currently created by the nationalised Bank of England.

0_1151.text: A pound in your bank account is no more than a promise by the bank to pay you that pound; you don’t actually own any publicly created money.

0_1152.text: In fact, commercial banks create new money (in the sense of money in bank accounts) whenever they make loans, and that money disappears when the loan is paid back.

0_1153.text: The fact that the size of our money supply – the total amount of money in circulation – is dependent upon millions of separate commercial lending decisions by banks makes it hard to maintain economic stability.

0_1154.text: During the great recession of the past few years, the unwillingness of banks to make new loans and the desire of people to pay down their debts has meant that the money supply has shrunk, and the government has had to resort to the emergency policy of printing money (called ‘quantitative easing’) to prevent an even worse slump.

0_1155.text: We believe that the time has come to recognise that the creation of currency and the control of the money supply is far too important to be left to profit-seeking private sector banks and should be brought back under the democratic control of the state.

0_1156.text: Quantitative easing was but a first step.

0_1157.text: Commercial banks should be no more than the custodians of publicly created money in current accounts, and the creation of that money should become the function of a new monetary authority, independent of day-today government control.

0_1158.text: This policy would protect ordinary bank accounts, and allow banks to fail safely separate ordinary and investment business provide some control on overall lending and debt This would be a massive and complex change to our banking system, with many ramifications, and its implementation, involving many years of consultation, legislation and the creation of transitional arrangements, would not be appropriate for one Parliament.

0_1159.text: But we would take the first steps of preparing detailed proposals and consulting upon them, and Green MPs will press this issue in the next Parliament.

0_1160.text: The change to the new system would create a new and substantial cash flow for the government, which could be spent on social and environmental priorities and assist in paying down the national debt.

0_1161.text: Changing economic organisations Most economic activity takes place in limited companies, many of them vast multinational organisations.

0_1162.text: The way they are run has a huge effect on our lives, yet their workers, customers and suppliers have no say in them.

0_1163.text: Even shareholders are often remote, and their connection with a company, and responsibility for what it has done, can be severed overnight by the simple act of selling their shares.

0_1164.text: The economy would be better, more stable and more responsive if there was (a) much greater diversity of economic models and (b) more control by those most directly involved in some of the economic organisations we already have.

0_1165.text: We would: Encourage small firms, which are more embedded in their local communities and provide less opportunity for creating huge disparities of income and wealth.

0_1166.text: Amend company law to ensure that medium and large companies take account of and report on the environmental and social impact of their activities.

0_1167.text: Amend company law to ensure that medium and large companies have employee and consumer representatives on their boards.

0_1168.text: Ensure that Companies House actually collects data due from companies and has accurate data on their beneficial ownership.

0_1169.text: Set local authorities free to run local enterprises for their own communities.

0_1171.text: Introduce a cooperative development fund managed by community banks to finance new and expanding cooperatives, alongside a much more comprehensive nationwide network of cooperative development bodies providing the necessary education, training and legal support.

0_1172.text: Grant employees the legal right in certain circumstances to buy out their companies (funded by the Green Investment Bank) and turn them into workers’ cooperatives; or, for example, grant the right to turn sporting clubs, in particular football clubs, into community and supporter cooperatives by giving powers for season ticket holders backed by the local community to take over the running of a club.

0_1173.text: Expand cooperative education, teaching young people the history of cooperatives as well as how to set them up in practice//. We will ensure business qualifications will give the same emphasis to cooperative and mutual business models as to other private enterprises.

0_1174.text: Small firms and the local economy The UK economy needs to be more local.

0_1175.text: Transporting basic foodstuffs all over the planet when they can be grown and sold near to home adds to greenhouse gas emissions and reduces security of supply.

0_1176.text: Local businesses are more responsive to local communities and are often better employers than remote, large ones.

0_1177.text: Income differences are smaller in small firms.

0_1178.text: If poorer people are better off, they tend to spend their extra income locally.

0_1179.text: So Greens champion small businesses and the local economy, and our Green MP Caroline Lucas was an official Parliamentary champion of the Federation of Small Businesses.

0_1180.text: We will: Make it easier for small businesses to employ people and contribute towards paying the living wage by using receipts from a wealth tax to reduce employers’ National Insurance in the longer run to 8%.

0_1181.text: Improve the competitive position of small firms, maintaining corporation tax for small firms at 20% while raising that for larger firms to 30%.

0_1182.text: Increase access to finance by investing £2 billion in a network of community banks, mutually owned and serving local areas or particular groups.

0_1183.text: Reduce the tax on conviviality and help small businesses in the tourism and restaurant businesses by lowering VAT to the reduced rate (5%) for cooked food, entertainment and accommodation, costing £6 billion a year.

0_1184.text: Keep trade local by allowing local authorities to favour local procurement to help their local economy.

0_1185.text: Ensure that legislation requiring that small businesses should be paid on time is properly enforced.

0_1186.text: In the longer run, simplify PAYE through our Basic Income proposals.

0_1187.text: Encourage greater diversity among entrepreneurs, including young people, women, ex-service people, the previously unemployed, people who are disabled and older people.

0_1188.text: Ensure that the great majority of honest small businesses can compete fairly with the less scrupulous by cracking down on tax evasion, especially in the informal economy and through non-payment of VAT.

0_1189.text: Give BT and other public telecommunications operators an obligation to provide affordable high-speed broadband-capable infrastructure to every small business.

0_1190.text: Green MEP lobbies for VAT exemption for small firms ` Molly Scott Cato MEP has been lobbying in Europe for VAT exemption for micro-businesses.

0_1191.text: `This follows new European VAT rules on digital products sold in the EU making VAT chargeable in the place of purchase rather than in the place of supply.

0_1192.text: Microbusinesses are now therefore obliged to collect VAT from up to 28 different EU states at 75 different rates.

0_1193.text: Rules designed to ensure that corporations pay fair taxes have entangled many tiny enterprises, and the complexity of administration involved is putting them at risk.

0_1194.text: Molly has called for a VAT exemption for businesses with a turnover of less than €100,000 across the whole of Europe.

0_1195.text: Many micro-businesses have welcomed her intervention; small businesses are responsible for around 80% of jobs across the EU.

0_1196.text: Taxes Tax is not a punishment and it is not stealing by the state.

0_1197.text: It is our money, spent on our behalf by the government we elect.

0_1198.text: Tax redistributes wealth and pays for services that are important to us all.

0_1199.text: There are services we share but don’t always use, such as roads, healthcare and schools.

0_1200.text: We don’t all drive, we don’t all go to the doctor and we don’t all have children.

0_1201.text: But we know these things are important for our common life: sharing these things binds us together.
