0_1203.text: And, to be fair, taxation needs to be progressive, taking proportionately more from those most able to pay.

0_1204.text: What should we spend, and on what?

0_1205.text: How much should we decide together to spend on the common good, and how much should be left for individuals to spend for themselves?

0_1206.text: The pressure in the UK in recent years from the main three parties has been for the state to tax less and spend less, culminating in the dismantling of public services in the name of austerity.

0_1207.text: But we need to put this in a wider context, in both space and time.

0_1208.text: Different countries spend different amounts of their national income on public goods.

0_1209.text: The table below compares the Green Party plan, set out in this manifesto, of 45% of GDP spent on public goods with other European countries and the USA, and with the planned decline in investment in the public sphere in the UK.

0_1210.text: Every percentage drop represents an assault on the ties that bind us together, on support for those who most need it and on investment in a democratic, just and sustainable economy.

0_1211.text: And the level of spending on the common good has changed over time, responding to changing circumstances.

0_1212.text: In 1900, UK government spending was just 14% of GDP.

0_1213.text: Much of that was defence; there was no welfare state.

0_1214.text: Spending climbed to 57% in 1918, the last year of the First World War.

0_1215.text: During the inter-war years spending fell back to around 27%, only to climb to a new peak of 70% at the end of the Second World War.

0_1216.text: With the creation of the welfare state, spending fell back less after the Second World War, and has moved between 38% and 46% in the past 20 years.

0_1218.text: After George Osborne’s 2014 Autumn statement, the Director of the independent Institute for Fiscal Studies asked ‘How will these cuts be implemented?

0_1219.text: Is this a fundamental reimagining of the role of the state?’

0_1221.text: The Coalition used to say that it was cutting out of necessity.

0_1222.text: But this pretence was dropped in 2013 when David Cameron admitted that his commitment to cuts was ideological and permanent: ‘We are sticking to the task...

0_1223.text: this... means building a leaner, more efficient state.

0_1224.text: We need to do more with less.

0_1226.text: Now we know what this means: more for the rich, less for the poor.

0_1227.text: There are three reasons for a fundamental shift to increased taxation and spending: To reverse the politically inspired, damaging and unnecessary cuts in public services we have faced in recent years; To improve these services in key areas such as early education and social care for older people; To meet the challenge of building an entirely new sustainable economy in a world where the private incentives of the market are simply not up to the job.

0_1228.text: Almost half our income for the common good?

0_1229.text: That’s what sustainability and equity require.

0_1230.text: So the first purpose of taxation is to pay for the things we do in common, and to redistribute income and wealth between us.

0_1231.text: But there is a second purpose.

0_1232.text: Taxing something discourages us from buying or doing it.

0_1234.text: Exempting the tax on something encourages us.

0_1235.text: The exemption of aviation from fuel taxes was instituted long ago in the early days of flying to encourage aviation.

0_1236.text: We need to use taxation to encourage sustainability and discourage unsustainability.

0_1237.text: Finally, for a tax system to be seen to be fair, everyone must pay their tax.

0_1238.text: The tax gap – that is, tax that is illegally evaded, legally avoided by exploiting loopholes, or for which collection is abandoned – is estimated to amount to more than £120 billion a year.

0_1239.text: That’s more than the deficit, expected to be £75 billion in 2015.

0_1240.text: It’s more than 30 times the total of benefit fraud, and twice the net cost of a Basic Income scheme.

0_1241.text: The Green Party is the only party with the political will to make the system fair, to collect unpaid taxes and to challenge powerful tax dodging both in the grey economy and by huge corporations.

0_1242.text: Recent governments can’t be serious about collecting tax fairly and efficiently when HMRC staff have been cut from 93,000 in 2004 to just 52,000 in 2015.

0_1243.text: Tax dodging Caroline Lucas MP secured a debate with the Exchequer Secretary to the Treasury (Mr David Gauke) in order to champion a Fair Tax Mark, much like the Fair Trade Mark, to be awarded to companies that take their tax responsibilities seriously.

0_1244.text: Meanwhile, in Europe, Molly Scott Cato MEP worked with other Greens on the European Parliament’s Economics Committee to ensure that there will be a full parliamentary inquiry into the scandal of corporate tax avoidance, ensuring that multinational companies will pay the taxes governments need to pay for infrastructure and public services.

0_1245.text: Also, as a member of the European Parliament’s tax working group, Molly Scott Cato is working to achieve an end to the exemption of aviation fuel from taxation.

0_1246.text: Green MPs will lead on bringing a Tax Dodging Bill before the next Parliament.

0_1247.text: That’s the Green Party’s tax policy in a nutshell: tax for fairness and to redistribute income and wealth, and tax for sustainability.

0_1248.text: To make taxation fairer we would: Introduce a wealth tax of 2% a year on the top 1% (see the ‘Wealth tax’ box) to raise about £25 billion a year by the end of the Parliament.

0_1249.text: We accept that such a tax would need to be phased in gradually and that the potential yield is uncertain.

0_1250.text: We would tie the yield on the wealth tax to our proposals to lower employers’ National Insurance (see below); to the extent that revenues from the wealth tax grow, employers’ National Insurance will be reduced.

0_1252.text: We would steadily increase staff in HMRC by 15,000 per annum over the Parliament, in particular reopening local offices.

0_1253.text: This would cost successively an additional £1 billion each year and is estimated to bring in cumulatively each year an additional £6 billion, still only one-quarter closing the tax gap, and collecting an extra £30 billion a year by the end of the Parliament.

0_1254.text: Introduce an urgent programme of legislation, starting with a Tax Dodging Bill designed to reduce the tax gap and establish a general anti-avoidance principle.

0_1255.text: Our plans include obliging banks to provide information about companies automatically to HMRC, and abolishing the rule that allows non-domiciled residents not to pay tax on foreign income.

0_1256.text: Consider making the £2 billion industry of designing, promoting and selling tax avoidance schemes illegal.

0_1257.text: Introduce a Robin Hood tax of 0.1% on transactions in bonds and equities and 0.01% on derivatives, replacing the existing stamp duty on share transactions.

0_1258.text: This would raise up to £20 billion a year later in the Parliament and would help stabilise financial markets.

0_1259.text: Reform Council Tax by asking people in bigger homes to pay more and those in smaller ones less, and adding two additional bands at the top for the biggest homes worth more than around £2 million and £4.5 million.

0_1260.text: Under these proposals two-thirds of people would pay less, with the more substantial increases for those in homes worth more than £1 million.

0_1261.text: Overall this would be revenue neutral.

0_1262.text: Make preparations to replace both Council Tax and the Uniform Business Rate by a system of Land Value Tax, where the level of taxation depends on the rental value of the land concerned.

0_1263.text: The rates would be decided locally with no caps, and subject to a degree of equalisation between richer and poorer areas, and would be kept and spent locally.

0_1264.text: Transition to Land Value Tax could begin by the last year of the Parliament, and then extend over the following 10 years.

0_1265.text: Further details are in the ‘Land Value Tax’ box.

0_1266.text: Abolish the employees’ National Insurance upper threshold.

0_1267.text: This would raise £28 billion a year in a full year from those on higher incomes above £42,380, but we would phase this increase in, with the first half of it in 2016–17.

0_1268.text: Raise the additional (top) rate of income tax to 60%.

0_1269.text: This will help bring down the maximum salary ratio in any workplace from the best paid to the lowest paid to no more than 10:1 and also act as a disincentive to paying excessive salaries.

0_1270.text: It would raise approximately £2 billion a year.

0_1271.text: Not allow corporation tax relief on any part of a salary that exceeds the maximum allowed by the 10:1 ratio in that company, to make it harder for companies to pay excessive salaries.

0_1272.text: Increase corporation tax from 20% to 30%, yielding around £12 billion a year in a full year.

0_1274.text: Abolish the capital gains tax personal allowance, raising around £3.8 billion a year.

0_1275.text: Fundamentally reform inheritance tax and turn it into an accessions tax.

0_1276.text: At present, inheritance tax is one of the easiest taxes to both avoid and evade, and the very rich usually find ways of paying very little.

0_1277.text: We would make the level of the tax depend on the wealth of the recipient, not the donor, so that all bequests to individual recipients who have less than £200,000 would be tax free.

0_1278.text: This would encourage people to spread their wealth more widely.

0_1279.text: Counter avoidance by abolishing the seven-year rule and making all gifts by living donors subject to a similar accessions tax, with exemptions for small annual amounts as at present.

0_1280.text: In addition we would tighten up the tax treatment of certain trusts widely used for inheritance tax purposes.

0_1281.text: A wealth tax Most of the emphasis on inequality is about inequality of income.

0_1282.text: But there is even more inequality in the ownership of accumulated wealth – property, pension rights, stocks and shares, and other assets.

0_1283.text: The top 10% of households hold nearly half the UK’s wealth, the top 1% hold at least 12.5%.

0_1284.text: Many other countries – France, Switzerland, the Netherlands, Spain and Norway for example – levy annual wealth taxes of up to 2%.

0_1285.text: The Green Party is part of a movement to build a global wealth tax, the only sure way to counter avoidance and evasion of such taxes The introduction of automatic information exchange for income tax purposes from 2016 from tax havens will make it easier to trace hidden wealth.

0_1286.text: We would introduce a tax of 2% a year on the 1% of the population whose wealth exceeds £3 million.

0_1287.text: There will be an exemption for farmers with agricultural land worth less than £10 million.

0_1288.text: For those with little income and a rather illiquid asset such as a house, arrangements could be made to defer the tax until the sale of the house.

0_1289.text: In a full year this tax could raise £25 billion.

0_1290.text: To tax for sustainability we would commit the UK economy to a long-run plan to reduce the use of natural resources through the introduction of resource and pollution taxation.

0_1291.text: In particular we would: Begin a major ecological shift in the taxation of companies by removing disincentives to employ people.

0_1292.text: Specifically we would reduce employers’ National Insurance contributions by the same amount as the yield from the wealth tax above.

0_1293.text: In the long run this will remove £25 billion a year from a tax on jobs, enabling the tax to be reduced from 13.8% of pay to around 8%.

0_1294.text: Reintroduce the fuel duty escalator, raising £2.2 billion in 2015 and an additional £2.2 billion in each successive year through the Parliament.

0_1295.text: Put aviation on a level playing field with other modes of transport by making it subject to fuel duty and VAT, raising £16 billion in a full year.

0_1296.text: If outdated international law makes this impossible, introduce a flight tax dependent on distance and aircraft type that has the same overall economic effect.

0_1297.text: Reduce VAT on housing renovation and repair work (including insulation) to 5%, costing £1.6 billion a year.

0_1298.text: At present there is no VAT on constructing new dwellings but VAT at 20% on converting and renovating old buildings to be used as homes.

0_1299.text: Reduce VAT on the tourism industry (meals and drinks out, accommodation and also live performances) to 5%, putting the UK on a level playing field with our international competitors and costing around £6 billion a year.

0_1300.text: Tax plastic bags and unnecessary packaging, raising perhaps £1 billion by 2020.

0_1301.text: Levy eco-taxes on non-renewables or pollutants, in particular pesticides, organo-chlorines, nitrogen and artificial fertilisers and phosphates, raising £1 billion by 2020.

0_1302.text: Introduce new taxes on the use of water by businesses and on waste heat from power stations, raising £3 billion by 2020.

0_1303.text: Increase alcohol and tobacco duties by a successive £1.4 billion every year in the Parliament.

0_1304.text: Land Value Tax Land Value Tax is a system of local taxation where the landowner pays a proportion of the rental value of the land itself, but not of buildings or improvements upon it, in tax each year.

0_1305.text: It has many advantages: It taxes the value of land and rents, which derive from nature and the efforts of the wider community and not from any effort by the landowner, rather than taxing wages and profits, which derive from labour and capital; It is hard to avoid because land cannot be hidden or moved; It dampens speculation in land and land hoarding; It favours tenants in particular, since the tax cannot be passed on from the landowner, and would substitute for Council Tax, which tenants have to pay; and It discourages landowners from not using derelict or vacant land.

0_1306.text: The land would be valued at the value that could be obtained if sold for the current planning permitted use.

0_1307.text: Commons, urban open space, some nature reserves and land used in common such as roads would be exempt.

0_1308.text: The rate would be set by the local authority.

0_1309.text: Special arrangements would allow those with land but a low income to pay their Land Value Tax upon the sale of their land or upon their death.

0_1310.text: A Land Value Tax set at around 2% of total land values would raise about the same amount as Council Tax and Uniform Business Rate combined.

0_1311.text: Moreover, 83% of properties would attract lower bills for Land Value Tax than for Council Tax (and many of these would be paid by the freeholder rather than the tenant).

0_1312.text: Joining up the policies So what does taxation have to do with equality and sustainability?

0_1313.text: It can be used to promote both, rather than promote things we don’t want.

0_1314.text: It’s folly to give capital allowances to investment in coal-fired generation, or VAT concessions to new buildings rather than reusing old ones.

0_1315.text: It’s unjust to spend billions on tax relief on pension contributions used overwhelmingly by the rich, or not to use inheritance tax to encourage people to spread their wealth.

0_1316.text: Taxation is not just a matter of getting in the money for the common good; we can use it to shape behaviour.

0_1318.text: CHAPTER 10 Imagine a tax and benefit system so simple that we could all depend on a small basic income depending on our age, and then, when we did paid work, we simply got taxed at a higher rate the more we earned...

0_1319.text: Introduction – what we have now In the world of the current government, social security means exactly the opposite of what it says on the tin.

0_1320.text: Living on benefits is to experience constant insecurity, wondering if payments will stretch to cover today’s food, next week’s school bus, next month’s electricity bill.

0_1321.text: It’s to experience discrimination, as society is divided into strivers and scroungers, the deserving and the undeserving poor, taxpayers and those on benefits It’s to be subject to delayed payments and sanctions, which push you to the food banks.

0_1322.text: It’s to lose up to four weeks’ payments simply for missing an interview.

0_1323.text: Worst of all, the benefits system takes no account of people’s real lives.

0_1324.text: You can pay more in transport costs to attend compulsory sessions at the Job Centre than you receive in benefits.

0_1325.text: All the while, more and more people fall through the cracks in a social security system that, thanks to ideology and incompetence, offers no security.

0_1326.text: Being on benefits creates a poverty trap that discourages employment or increased hours of work.

0_1327.text: Yet work in today’s UK doesn’t pay either.

0_1328.text: It’s why, for the first time, there are more people living below the poverty line in working families (6.7 million) than in workless and retired families combined (6.3 million).

0_1329.text: It’s why one of modern UK’s growth industries is payday loan sharking.

0_1330.text: And it’s one of the reasons why nothing short of a Green revolution in how we think about social security will do.

0_1331.text: The Coalition government has introduced more work-for-benefits schemes, tougher rules on claiming benefits and more sanctions.

0_1332.text: Job Centre staff are encouraged to do whatever it takes to get people off the dole and deny them the money to which they are entitled.

0_1333.text: Employment and Support Allowance is a disgrace, with harsh, inaccurate fitness-for-work assessments that are frequently overturned on appeal.

0_1334.text: Claimants suffer because of huge delays in assessment of Personal Independence Payments.

0_1335.text: The Coalition’s flagship policy, a so-called simplification of the system, Universal Credit, is a disaster waiting to happen.

0_1336.text: Implementation dates are constantly revised and the computer systems are never quite ready.

0_1337.text: Although Universal Credit claims to improve incentives to work, if you earn an extra £100, £65 will be deducted from your benefit.

0_1338.text: This is higher than the 45% tax charged on incomes over £150,000, yet we are told that, if we increase that top rate, high earners will lack incentives to work or will leave the country.

0_1339.text: So should we be surprised if many on benefits decide not to work?

0_1340.text: In a sensible world, we’d have much lower deductions from earnings for those who earn least.

0_1341.text: Instead of entrenching the difference between being in and out of work, which is what mainstream welfare tries to do, the Green Party will work to eliminate it altogether.

0_1342.text: Green MP Caroline Lucas and welfare reform

0_1343.text: In the last Parliament, Green MP Caroline Lucas took a stand against the removal of the link between benefit levels and inflation, the government’s welfare reforms, the widespread scapegoating of the poor and disabled, and the myth that welfare and other public spending was the cause of the economic recession.

0_1344.text: Here are some of her comments: ‘As well as being callous and cruel, the bedroom tax is counter-productive.’

0_1345.text: ‘If our priority is fairness, we should be seeking savings from those who can afford it, not penalising the poorest and pushing them into ever more precarious misery.’

0_1346.text: ‘The government’s misguided austerity programme is leading to social devastation and is economically illiterate.’

0_1347.text: A radical long-term plan to reform the tax and benefits system The Green Party thinks the time has come to reconsider the whole tax and benefits system and to rebuild it from the ground up – a system not built on punishing and isolating people, making them jump through hoops to get hand-outs from the state, but one that goes back to the founding principles of the welfare state, in the belief that, as members of society, we have a shared responsibility for one another’s well-being in times of need and a shared commitment to helping others play the most active role they can in our society.

0_1348.text: The idea in a nutshell is this.

0_1349.text: Scrap most of the existing benefits apart from disability benefits and Housing Benefit.

0_1350.text: Abolish the income tax personal allowance.

0_1351.text: Then pay every woman, man and child legally resident in the UK a guaranteed, non-means-tested income, sufficient to cover basic needs – a Basic Income.

0_1352.text: For those who earn, the Basic Income compensates for the loss of the personal allowance.

0_1353.text: Children will receive a reduced Basic Income, Child Benefit.

0_1354.text: Pensioners will receive their Basic Income at a higher level, as a Citizen’s Pension.

0_1355.text: The advantages are many and we support the principle of a Universal Basic Income because it has the potential to: Act as a springboard rather than a safety net; people can take jobs without fear of prosecution for working while on benefits; Prevent people falling into absolute poverty rather than trying to help them when they are already there; Reward people for all the work that’s done outside the formal economy, and most of this work is done by women; Encourage more of this unpaid activity, much of which – such as food growing, fixing things that have gone wrong, converting older buildings, protecting the natural environment – is a vital part of a transition to a more sustainable economy; Avoid the poverty trap in which an increase in wages leads to a massive loss of benefits; Make everyone who earns, however little, a citizen who contributes to society by paying taxes, giving almost everyone a stake – raising the personal allowance takes us in precisely the wrong direction; Be simple to administer and easy to understand.

0_1356.text: Basic Income would be a massive change to the entire UK tax and benefits system.

0_1357.text: We recognise that it would not be practicable or right to carry out that change within a single Parliament.

0_1358.text: We are publishing alongside but separate from this manifesto a detailed set of proposals for a comprehensive Basic Income scheme.

0_1359.text: It contains full details of the scheme itself, costings and proposals on how to pay for it, and an initial analysis of how the scheme would affect the net income of different groups.

0_1360.text: We would use the forthcoming Parliament to Consult upon this scheme, Have government departments carry out and commission research (including research into behavioural changes and how Basic Income would affect those on the lowest incomes and child poverty), and Draft appropriate legislation, with a view to implementing the full scheme in the following Parliament.

0_1361.text: There are further things we would propose to do in the forthcoming Parliament as steps towards this major reform: Reform the existing working-age benefits regime.

0_1364.text: Working-age benefits A major problem with existing working-age benefits and tax credits is the poverty trap.

0_1365.text: We would be prepared to invest up to £30billion over the Parliament to reduce the amounts that people lose from their benefits when they move into paid work and to fund the other changes to the benefits regime set out in this section.

0_1366.text: In complex ways, eligibility for some benefits (e.g. Jobseeker’s Allowance) is lost altogether once a person is employed for a certain period, or reduced pound for pound if certain small disregarded amounts are exceeded.

0_1367.text: Some other benefits (e.g. Housing Benefit) are reduced in a different way, by withdrawal rates that allow those earning to keep a small part of what they earn and not lose all of it.

0_1368.text: We would make small changes in the direction of allowing those who earn some income from paid work to keep more of that income, starting with increasing the disregards for Income Support and Jobseeker’s Allowance (JSA).

0_1369.text: Initially we would increase the income disregarded on JSA for all categories of client to £50 a week, with similar increases for those on Universal Credit.

0_1370.text: It is not possible to be precise about how much the increased costs of such moves would be offset by more people on benefits taking up employment or working for longer hours.

0_1371.text: Depending on results, we are prepared to invest up to £30 billion on such employment-stimulating measures over the Parliament.

0_1372.text: We would also explore the introduction of a more generous treatment of earnings within Universal Credit for all claimants, whatever their housing circumstances.

0_1373.text: We would also: Halt implementation of the Universal Credit programme and carry out a thorough review of its structure and implementation, including the treatment of earned income, and removing conditionality.

0_1374.text: End work-for-benefits programmes, or workfare, and ensure a fair choice of waged work opportunities or voluntary training for jobseekers.

0_1375.text: Ensure that all those on training or work placements as part of the benefits regime are either in college-based training or at work earning at least the minimum wage.

0_1376.text: Review the harsh systems of sanctions and benefits caps introduced by the Coalition government and its predecessors.

0_1377.text: Consider offering more personalised job-seeking support for people with mental health problems.

0_1378.text: Restore Council Tax Benefit at the equivalent of 2012–13 levels for low-income householders, costing around £500 million a year.

0_1379.text: ` Cancel the Department for Work and Pensions contracts with the private sector for benefit entitlement assessment.

0_1380.text: Restore the link between state benefits and earnings; ensure state benefits rise as fast as prices or wages, whichever of those grows more.

0_1381.text: Abolish childcare tax credits and tax reliefs in the light of our proposals for free universal early education and childcare.

0_1382.text: Pay students maintenance grants until Basic Income is introduced.

0_1383.text: Raise the minimum wage and outlaw exploitative zero-hours contracts, so that the jobs taken by unemployed people are above a minimum standard.

0_1384.text: Child Benefit Bringing up a child is expensive.

0_1385.text: It is also vital work on behalf of society as a whole; those of us without children will depend on the children of others when we grow older.

0_1386.text: It is right that society as a whole makes a contribution, as is recognised by our free state education system.

0_1387.text: But that system needs two extensions: a free universal early education and childcare service (see Chapter 7 on Education), and a more realistic level of Child Benefit.

0_1388.text: We will: Raise Child Benefit as from 2016 from £20.70 a week for the oldest or only child and £13.70 a week for additional children in 2015–16 to £40 a week for each child.

0_1389.text: Pay for the £15.5 billion net cost of this by using this much of the £28 billion raised from those on higher incomes by abolishing the National Insurance upper threshold.

0_1390.text: Citizen’s Pension The bedrock of our pension policy is the Citizen’s Pension, which, unlike the new flat-rate pension, would be paid to all pensioners regardless of contribution record, and to existing as well as new pensioners, so no pensioner will live in poverty.

0_1392.text: It will pay £180 a week to a single pensioner or £310 for a couple, taking all pensioners above the poverty line.

0_1393.text: Increases will be at the higher of the increases in the prices of basic goods and services or in average earnings.

0_1394.text: The existing State Pension and Pension Credits cost £90 billion a year, while the new pensions above will cost £116 billion.

0_1395.text: The net cost is therefore £26 billion.

0_1396.text: We will fund this by reducing tax and National Insurance incentives for private pensions by onehalf, raising £20 billion (see the ‘Older people and pensions’ section in Chapter 5) and using a further £6 billion available from abolishing the National Insurance upper threshold (see the ‘Child Benefit’ section above).

0_1397.text: Joining up the policies So what do housing, pensions and investing in a new sustainable economy have to do with each other?

0_1398.text: Pensions need sound, long-run infrastructure to invest in, such as energy generation and social housing.

0_1399.text: And, if the pensions system is broken, people will invest in houses instead, pushing up prices and rents.

0_1400.text: So, if we create a new pensions system investing in the things we need, and discourage the things such as mortgage interest relief for landlords that encourage investment in housing, 501then we reduce the money chasing existing housing, and prices and rents fall.

0_1402.text: CHAPTER 11 Imagine being part of another kind of coalition.

0_1403.text: Not the grubby one that’s handed democracy over to the private sector, but one made up of elected politicians determined to govern for the common good, a revitalised local government, a regulated private sector, the third sector and non-profits – and you and me.

0_1404.text: Imagine a voting system in which your vote actually counts.

0_1405.text: Imagine more decisions being taken where they really matter – locally.

0_1406.text: Imagine going to your reopened public library, strolling round your well-tended local park, taking your child to a school brought back under local authority control, and visiting an elderly relative in a local authority care home staffed by trained and well-paid carers.

0_1407.text: Imagine the end of cronyism, corruption and the ‘Westminster bubble’.

0_1408.text: Imagine Parliament belonging to the people...

0_1410.text: We elect politicians to govern in our name, not to hand power over to huge corporations acting in shareholder interest.

0_1411.text: Successive governments, and particularly the current one, have outsourced government to the unaccountable private sector.

0_1412.text: This hollowing out of government is based on dogma – that the private sector does things better than the public sector.

0_1413.text: Successive scandals and failures of provision have proved this dogma wrong.

0_1414.text: But still the contracts get handed out, with the private sector taking all the profit and the taxpayer – you and me – shouldering all the risk.

0_1415.text: Government has been put out to tender.

0_1416.text: Corporate interests, heading a coalition of the rich and powerful, have ruled the roost for too long.

0_1417.text: This has brought politics and politicians into disrepute.

0_1418.text: When things go wrong, the government blames the companies to which it has outsourced its work, and politicians are accused of being on the make.

0_1419.text: Some are, as we found out during the expenses scandal.

0_1420.text: But many aren’t, and the Green Party will lead a revolution in standards, putting politics back in the hands of the people and governing for the common good.

0_1421.text: It is well placed to do this.

0_1422.text: The Green Party has made electoral gains at local, national and European level.

0_1423.text: Our councillors, our MP and our MEPs work effectively for the people who voted for them.

0_1424.text: The biggest lesson of the Scottish referendum was that, when people are given the responsibility for making big decisions, they grab it with both hands.

0_1425.text: The Green Party will turn the tide on apathy and disillusionment by making these opportunities the rule rather than the exception.

0_1426.text: A Green government would: Regulate the private sector in the common interest, including curbing excessive pay for executives and senior managers.

0_1427.text: Introduce a Public Service Users Bill to bring back into public ownership sectors of the economy on which we all depend.

0_1428.text: Recognise that, if government is small, society doesn’t automatically become big – the third sector needs strong, enabling government.

0_1429.text: Treat citizens as grown-ups, capable of recognising the common good and acting on it.

0_1430.text: Not accept the dogma that government cannot lead or innovate and has no entrepreneurial drive.

0_1431.text: We will set creative government free.

0_1432.text: Recognise that efficiency in public services does matter, provided it is not at the cost of poor service or exploitation of staff.

0_1433.text: We would expect to find very modest savings of 0.3% over 50% of the government’s operations each successive year.

0_1434.text: In contrast, the Coalition has too often described actual cuts in public services as efficiency savings.

0_1435.text: Green MP Caroline Lucas and the Public Service Users Bill

0_1436.text: In January 2014, inspired by We Own It, Green MP Caroline Lucas presented in Parliament a plan to defend our public services.

0_1437.text: Her Public Service Users Bill would: Make public ownership the default option before any service is sold off.

0_1438.text: Ensure people are asked – and genuinely listened to – before any service is put out to tender.

0_1439.text: Give the public a right to recall private companies if they’re running our services poorly.

0_1440.text: Make private companies running public services more transparent.

0_1441.text: A new constitutional settlement UK politics is rooted in the past and has lost touch with the present.

0_1442.text: Our Parliament looks back to feudal times rather than forward to democratic times; we cling to 18 as the age of political maturity despite young people’s growing sophistication and capacity to make decisions for themselves; we legitimise corruption through unfair funding of political parties; our MPs pay more attention to their parties than to the people when it comes to voting – constituents need to be re-empowered.

0_1443.text: To put this right the Green Party will: Move towards a written constitution with a Bill of Rights.

0_1444.text: Bring in proportional representation (PR) using the Additional Member System for parliamentary elections and continue fixedterm Parliaments.

0_1445.text: Only the 200,000 votes in marginal seats really counted in the last election – that’s less than 0.5% of those eligible to vote.

0_1446.text: We would make everyone’s vote count.

0_1447.text: Introduce the right to vote at 16.

0_1448.text: Reform the House of Lords to become a fully elected body chosen by PR; but, to promote its independence, members should be elected for only one fixed term of ten years, with half the House being elected every five years.

0_1449.text: Bring in a fair system of state funding for political parties so there’s no longer a need for reliance on private and trade union donations, which can have a corrupting effect.

0_1450.text: Ensure that all lobbying, and in particular corporate lobbying, is registered and fully disclosed, including lobbying of elected politicians and of civil servants.

0_1451.text: Immediately repeal the unsatisfactory Lobbying Act, so that civil society organisations can campaign properly.

0_1452.text: Retain the principle that human rights are the common property of the whole world by keeping the Human Rights Act and retaining the UK’s membership of the European Convention on Human Rights and the Council of Europe.

0_1453.text: Aspire to a 50:50 Parliament by 2025 with equal numbers of women and men.

0_1454.text: Introduce referendums on local government decisions if called for by 20% of the local electorate.

0_1455.text: Introduce recall referendums on MPs and other representatives if 20% of electors request it.

0_1456.text: Make equality before the law a fundamental constitutional right.

0_1457.text: But this is only a reality if all can afford to use the law.

0_1458.text: We would restore the cuts to Legal Aid, costing around £700 million a year.

0_1459.text: Localisation The Scotland independence referendum put decentralisation back on the political agenda – a cause that Greens have championed for years.

0_1460.text: We have long argued that nothing should be decided at a central level that can be decided at a local level.

0_1461.text: We need to improve the way the UK is governed, passing power back to the people, back to where they live and work.

0_1462.text: Local councils have been starved of the funds they need to do their job.

0_1463.text: That is why requests for social care go unheeded, libraries are shut and public parks neglected.

0_1465.text: Local democracy is withering and dying because councillors are hemmed about by regulation and their functions have been systematically removed over the past 30 years.

0_1466.text: Local Government Secretary Eric Pickles has virtually abolished onshore wind energy by overriding local planning and halting turbine projects.

0_1467.text: We will fund local government properly and extend its functions, reviving local democracy.

0_1468.text: We will: Money Provide a £10 billion a year uplift in local authority budgets to allow local authorities to restore essential local services, creating more than 200,000 local jobs.

0_1469.text: Add further higher bands to Council Tax to allow authorities to raise more on the largest homes.

0_1470.text: Not cap what local authorities are allowed to raise in Council Tax, allow local councils to conduct revaluations and to set their own multiplier rates, provided they are more progressive, and not require a Council Tax referendum when they do so.

0_1471.text: Ensure that grant funding is sufficient to pay for all statutory services that councils are required to provide.

0_1472.text: To fund discretionary activities, we would allow local authorities to set local business rates, and then distribute the whole of Council Tax receipts and Business Rate receipts between local authorities on a basis decided by a Commission independent of central government set up by local authorities themselves.

0_1473.text: Also allow local authorities to levy new local taxes, such as local tourist taxes, empty homes levies, supermarket taxes or workplace parking levies, and to set rates for and keep part or all of some taxes collected locally, such as income tax and VAT, and distribute them as above.

0_1474.text: Allow local authorities freedom to set local fines, fees and charges.

0_1475.text: Put these taxation arrangements beyond future Whitehall revision by giving formal constitutional protection to local democracy and tax-raising powers.

0_1476.text: Scrap the New Homes Bonus and add the money to the Revenue Support Grant.

0_1477.text: Not start any new private finance initiative projects and set local authorities free to borrow to fund local capital investment in social housing, electricity generation and distribution, and local public transport.

0_1478.text: Set up a fund of up to £5 billion over the Parliament to buy out existing PFI projects where it is a good deal to do so.

0_1479.text: Democracy Restore local authority control over education, with full delegation of the appropriate budgets.

0_1480.text: Allow local authorities to run local public transport and other local services such as domestic and commercial waste disposal, community energy schemes and local food production entirely as they wish, including using publicly owned and run services and employing social enterprise and voluntary sector organisations.

0_1481.text: Keep trade local by allowing local authorities to favour local procurement to help their local economy.

0_1482.text: Give local authorities powers to encourage local live performance in the arts by moving funding from the regional to the local level and modifying regulations so that small-scale live performance in pubs and similar venues is not stifled.

0_1483.text: Create an Assembly for Cornwall, with similar powers to the Welsh Assembly.

0_1484.text: Work for the abolition of the City of London Corporation and the special statuses it enjoys.

0_1485.text: Residents will decide on the future governance arrangements for the local functions exercised by the Corporation, with the same division of roles between the local and the strategic as in any other part of London.

0_1486.text: Planning Require local authorities to set out a local carbon plan showing how their area will meet overall greenhouse gas reduction targets.

0_1487.text: Put planning back in the hands of local government by: repealing the National Planning Policy Framework and in particular its presumption in favour of economic development; restricting the ability of the Secretary of State to call in planning applications; restricting the right of applicants to appeal only where there has been an error in the planning process; strengthening local authorities’ powers to prevent changes of use for important community facilities such as local shops, pubs and meeting halls; giving local authorities planning powers to support local shops and businesses through planning policies including business conservation areas, ensuring basic shops are available within walking distance in all urban areas, restricting the number of payday lenders and restricting the power of supermarkets; and introducing a community right of appeal where a development is non-compliant with a neighbourhood plan or local plan.

0_1488.text: Support preservation of the historic environment, in part by being flexible about how older buildings reduce their energy use.

0_1489.text: Constitutional Convention The Green Party supports calls for a Constitutional Convention led by citizens – a People’s Convention.

0_1490.text: We’d use that opportunity to make the case for the changes detailed above.

0_1491.text: Parts of England, based on groups of local authorities, could come together to exercise greater powers; these might amount to existing regions, or possibly city regions.

0_1492.text: The process must be driven by the bottom up decisions of local authorities, not by top down direction.

0_1493.text: The Convention would also consider further devolution to Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales.

0_1494.text: As set out above, we favour much greater devolution to and tax-raising powers for local authorities, with this settlement put beyond future Whitehall revision by giving formal constitutional protection to local democracy .

0_1495.text: Any constitutional changes should be subject to referendums.

0_1496.text: Wales Greens have long supported the process of devolution in Wales.

0_1497.text: We believe that the people of Wales should enjoy the degree of autonomy, perhaps including full self-government or independence, that they wish to have, as expressed in a referendum.

0_1498.text: Up until any such referendum, Greens in Wales will focus on improving and maximising the potential of the current devolution settlement.

0_1499.text: Reflecting the devolved status of Wales within the UK, the Wales Green Party has an autonomous status within the wider party and publishes independent policy statements and its own manifesto covering all areas of devolved power.

0_1500.text: These include matters such as health, education, transport and housing.

0_1501.text: Greens in Wales would: Increase real power at all levels, from local councils up to the Welsh Assembly.

0_1502.text: Increase the number of Assembly members.

0_1503.text: Push for the National Assembly to become a Parliament with powers equal to those in Scotland.

0_1504.text: One benefit of these increased powers would be the ability for Wales to fully realise its potential as a producer of clean renewable energy.

0_1505.text: Greens recognise that cultural diversity is as vital as ecological biodiversity in maintaining and enriching a healthy and fair society.

0_1506.text: We would promote and protect this cultural diversity at a grassroots level with the promotion of community radio, television, live arts, etc. in both the Welsh and English languages.

0_1507.text: Wales Green Party policies would help create the strong local sustainable economies and thriving communities necessary for the future of the Welsh language and the nation’s rich cultural diversity.

0_1508.text: Information and digital rights We live in the information age and we know that information is power.

0_1509.text: But how should information be controlled?

0_1510.text: What information should be available, and to whom?

0_1511.text: The Green Party supports a world of open, freely flowing information.

0_1512.text: We don’t want disproportionate or unaccountable surveillance or censorship.

0_1513.text: We want a transparent state, but we want control over the data that our digital lives create.

0_1514.text: We need copyright laws that reward creators but that are consistent with digital technologies.

0_1515.text: Above all we want democratic political control of this technology We would consider combining elements of the policies below into a comprehensive Digital Bill of Rights.

0_1516.text: We would: Oppose any case for secret unaccountable mass surveillance of the type exposed by Edward Snowden.

0_1517.text: We do accept that government law enforcement agencies may occasionally need to intercept communications in specific circumstances.

0_1518.text: Such specific surveillance should be proportionate, necessary, effective and within the rule of law, with independent judicial approval and genuine parliamentary oversight.

0_1519.text: Replace the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000, which has failed to regulate the deployment of undercover police; to support the confidentiality of journalistic sources; // to support legal confidentiality; and to enshrine an open and effective right of redress.

0_1521.text: Follow human rights judgments limiting surveillance and data retention in full.

0_1522.text: Support the EU’s proposals to strengthen data protection laws against opposition from large US data-driven companies.

0_1523.text: Limit the censoring or takedown of content or activity to exceptional circumstances, clearly set out within a comprehensive legal framework.

0_1524.text: Make copyright shorter in length, fair and flexible, and prevent patents applying to software.

0_1525.text: Introduce a more satisfactory law on so-called malicious comments made on social media than the blanket and crude section 127 of the Communications Act 2003.

0_1526.text: Oppose the privatisation of data held by the government that should be open to all, such as the Postcode Address File, or by companies providing public services, such as data on the progress of buses that can be used by Smartphone apps to predict waiting times.

0_1527.text: Oppose the sale of personal data, such as health or tax records, for commercial or other ends.

0_1528.text: Use government purchasing power to support open standards in information technology.

0_1529.text: Media, sports and the arts How politics is reported is vital for our democracy – active citizenship has to be informed citizenship.

0_1530.text: Public support for the arts is part of a civilised society.

0_1531.text: We would: Tighten the rules on cross-media ownership and ensure that no individual or company owns more than 20% of a media market.

0_1532.text: Support the recommendations of the Leveson Inquiry into press ethics and for the cross-party Royal Charter.

0_1533.text: But if this is not supported by all the major newspapers we will support legislation to implement the Leveson system of independent press self-regulation.

0_1534.text: Maintain the BBC as the primary public service broadcaster, free of government interference, with funding guaranteed in real terms in statute to prevent government interference.

0_1535.text: Increase government arts funding by £500 million a year to restore the cuts made since 2010 and reinstate proper levels of funding for local authorities, helping to keep local museums, theatres, libraries and art galleries open.

0_1536.text: Reduce VAT to 5% for live performances.

0_1537.text: Work to support fair pay productions in the arts.

0_1538.text: Support initiatives to make the arts and sports accessible to all.

0_1539.text: Set targets for participation in sports by women, ethnic minorities and disabled people in particular.

0_1540.text: Make sure all children get at least a half-day equivalent of sports in school and encourage both the use of schools sports facilities by the community and participation in regional and national sporting events by our young people.

0_1541.text: Ensure that all have digital access and give BT and other public telecommunications operators an obligation to provide affordable high-speed broadband-capable infrastructure to every household and small business.

0_1542.text: This in particular will encourage video-conferencing, helping to reduce both business and family travel.

0_1543.text: Strengthen controls on advertising directed at children.

0_1544.text: Value the contribution made by civil society organisations both here and abroad.

0_1545.text: In particular, we would repeal the Lobbying Act 2014 (see the ‘Green MP opposes the Lobbying Bill’ box below).

0_1546.text: Support state funding of political parties.

0_1547.text: Give fair representation to political parties in televised debates.

0_1548.text: Caroline Lucas opposes the Lobbying Bill

0_1549.text: At every stage of the Lobbying Bill’s progress through Parliament, Green MP Caroline Lucas was at the forefront of attempts to stop the Bill becoming law.

0_1550.text: She was one of a group of MPs who tabled an amendment to reject the Bill outright and was a vocal critic of moves to drastically curtail the debate we need for a healthy democracy.

0_1551.text: Caroline campaigned for legislation that would shine a real light on lobbying activity and criticised the Coalition’s proposals for letting most corporate lobbyists off the hook, at the same time as effectively gagging the activities of civil society groups speaking out on anything from housing policy to wildlife conservation.

0_1552.text: She tabled an amendment to the Bill that would have opened up to proper scrutiny how much is spent on lobbying – as well as who is doing it.

0_1553.text: She called for details to be made public about when staff transfer between the civil service and the private sector.

0_1554.text: And she has stood up in Parliament time and again to reiterate the Green Party’s commitment to repealing what’s dubbed the Gagging Bill.

0_1555.text: Imagine being able to leave your car in the garage – or not needing one at all... because reliable, affordable public transport, coupled with safe, clean, welcoming streets for walking and cycling, meets your transport needs.

0_1556.text: Could that not be the real world?

0_1557.text: Like so much else, the UK has got transport upside down.

0_1558.text: The big picture is a world of finite resources, especially the type that runs much of our transport – petroleum.

0_1559.text: This is running out, and we know we need to leave much of what is left in the ground.

0_1560.text: We have to create a transport system based on sustainable alternatives.

0_1561.text: We also have an increasingly car-dependent population because the cost of public transport has risen faster than wages and faster than the total cost of driving, and in many areas public transport is so scarce that people have little alternative but to get around by car.

0_1562.text: This has led to a public health crisis caused by rising levels of physical inactivity and health-damaging air pollution.

0_1563.text: We also face an increasing toll of death and injury on the roads, particularly among pedestrians and cyclists who face unacceptable danger in our vehicle-dominated and congested towns, cities and villages.

0_1564.text: Our privatised railways are fragmented and uncoordinated, ticket prices are high and unpredictable, and timetables do not connect seamlessly with buses at stations.

0_1565.text: This means rail fails to play its full part in delivering an effective alternative to the private car.

0_1566.text: Long-distance travel by air is one of the most energy-intensive and polluting forms of transport and causes health-damaging local pollution near airports.

0_1567.text: Aviation fuel goes untaxed and there is no VAT on tickets, amounting to a £16 billion a year subsidy in the UK.

0_1568.text: We need a shift in priority, removing subsidies from air travel to invest in public transport that supports the common good.

0_1569.text: In the long run we have to create a transport system that is socially just and addresses health inequality by prioritising affordable access to services by walking, cycling and public transport, by reducing road danger, by cleaning up our air and by minimising congestion.

0_1570.text: This transport system should use electricity, not oil, and make our towns, cities and villages into more liveable, socially inclusive places.

0_1571.text: Against this backdrop, mainstream transport policy, which urges us to travel further and faster than ever before, is senseless, yet this is what all parties except the Green Party offer you.

0_1572.text: The key to getting this right is to manage demand rather than increase it; that is, to reduce the need to travel in the first place.

0_1573.text: We need to: Reduce the distances travelled, reduce the number of journeys made by car and switch as many journeys as possible to walking, cycling and public transport; Encourage alternatives to travel, such as video-conferencing; Integrate different transport options and provide seamless door–to-door journeys; Prioritise everyday access for everybody wherever they live to local facilities such as the shops, the doctors’ surgery, schools and workplaces; and Enable more people to get to where they need to go while using a car less.

0_1574.text: Green Party transport policy prioritises in this order, building from the bottom up: walking and disabled access to all other forms of transport; cycling; public transport (trains, light rail/trams, buses and ferries) and rail- and water-borne freight; light goods vehicles, taxis and low-powered motor cycles; private motorised transport (cars and high-powered motor cycles); heavy goods vehicles; and aircraft.

0_1576.text: Green councillors were instrumental in bringing in 20 mph limits on many residential roads in Norwich, Islington and Leicester, as well as a default 20 mph limit on all residential roads in Lancashire and in Brighton & Hove.

0_1577.text: Bringing the railways into public hands For trains to play their part in the total journey experience, they need to connect seamlessly with buses and convenient walking and cycling routes to local centres of habitation.

0_1578.text: The Green Party is committed to bringing rail services into public ownership and control.

0_1579.text: The current fragmented structure does not put the passenger and the total journey experience at the centre of planning and has created a costly, wasteful, uncoordinated outcome.

0_1580.text: Recent experience in running the East Coast Main Line within the public sector has shown that both quality and receipts to the Treasury go up when a rail service is run in this way, whereas experience on the West Coast Main Line in the private sector shows that the franchise system is costly, wasteful and not fit for purpose.

0_1581.text: The Green Party will consult widely on the organisational details of a rail operation in public ownership and how it will link to democratic accountability at the regional and city-region geographical scales.

0_1582.text: Diesel exhaust emissions are a known human carcinogen and diesel trains do not perform as well as electrified rail operations in terms of passenger comfort, acceleration and deceleration, and the ability to make more stops at intermediate stations with minimal impact on overall journey time.

0_1583.text: The Green Party wants to see electrification of the railway system to achieve levels to be found in Germany (59% of track electrified) or Sweden (73% electrified).

0_1584.text: The UK has 34% of its track electrified.

0_1585.text: High levels of electrification reduce health-damaging air pollution, reduce greenhouse gases and deliver a much-improved passenger experience.

0_1586.text: Electrification will also require new rolling stock and the Green Party will promote the design and manufacturing of this new stock in the UK, contributing to job creation in those regions with higher than average unemployment.

0_1587.text: Putting this plan into action for the common good means bringing the railways back into public ownership – making them belong to you and me, run by rail workers for passengers.

0_1588.text: On 26 June 2013, Green MP Caroline Lucas published a Private Members’ Bill to do just this, a policy supported by 66% of the British public.

0_1589.text: The privatised railways cost over £1 billion a year in: Interest payments; Debt write-offs; The costs of railway fragmentation; The profit margins of tiers of contractors and sub-contractors;  Payments to shareholders; and Bonuses paid to railway bosses (up to 166% of annual salaries).

0_1590.text: Between 1997 and 2013, rail fares leapt by 22%, while road users have experienced a 9% drop – exactly the wrong priority.

0_1591.text: Rail isn’t really ‘private’ anyway – 60% of the network is owned by state-backed foreign companies.

0_1592.text: And this ‘private’ system takes £4 billion in public subsidies every year.

0_1593.text: Labour’s response is to require the state to bid for franchises it already owns – at millions of pounds a time.

0_1594.text: As Caroline says, a privatised railway ‘is a blatant transfer of public money to private interests at the expense of the taxpayer and rail passengers’.

0_1595.text: Bringing the railways back into public ownership would cost very little if it was done as existing franchises fell due for renewal.

0_1596.text: This will: Save money; Mean a better deal for passengers; Allow local authorities to plan and run local services; Increase the scope for the democratic involvement of local communities in planning and running railways; and Reduce congestion and improve safety.

0_1597.text: In addition on the railways, we would not support HS2 (the proposed high-speed network).

0_1598.text: The money to be spent on this hugely expensive project, which at best will reduce journey times for a few passengers, would be much better spent on improving the conventional rail connections between various major cities, improving the resilience of the existing network to climate change and reopening lines and stations that have been closed.

0_1600.text: The major challenge for our transport system is to decarbonise it and end its reliance on fossil fuels.

0_1601.text: We would: End the wasteful and destructive national major roads programme, saving £15 billion over the Parliament.

0_1602.text: Spend part of this £15 billion on improving and subsidising public transport, with an average fare reduction of 10% costing £8 billion over the Parliament, fixing potholes in existing roads and investing in walking and cycling.

0_1604.text: In particular, we would ensure that pedestrians and cyclists get their fare share of road space and would spend at least £30 per head on them over every year of the Parliament.

0_1605.text: Funding should be allocated flexibly to make safe, convenient routes that address the needs of pedestrians and cyclists while reducing any risk of conflict between them.

0_1606.text: Support the re-regulation of bus services to provide a better, more reliable service.

0_1607.text: End the favourable tax treatment of aviation and have a separate target for aviation emissions of below 37.5 million tonnes

0_1609.text: Stop airport expansion, in particular no new runways at either Heathrow or Gatwick, and ban night flying.

0_1610.text: Invest in electric vehicle charging points for buses and taxis, and for cars where there are gaps in the network of public and community transport.

0_1611.text: Incentivise consolidation of white van deliveries so that last-mile deliveries can be made by cargo bikes and electric vehicles in local areas.

0_1612.text: Affordable public transport Instead of prestige projects such HS2 and new runways, we need to prioritise local transport and make sure it is accessible to everybody.

0_1613.text: The Green Party would: Prioritise affordable local public transport, accessible to all, including those with disabilities.

0_1614.text: Support free local transport for pensioners, including the existing local bus pass scheme and the Freedom Pass in London.

0_1615.text: Extend free local public transport to young people and students, costing around £4 billion a year.

0_1616.text: Develop regional smart payment systems with integrated ticketing, like the London Oyster system.

0_1617.text: Extend networks of public transport to include rural areas.

0_1618.text: A step change in road safety The numbers of people killed or seriously injured on the UK’s roads have fallen in recent years.

0_1619.text: But they are still appallingly high: 1,713 people died on the roads in 2013, and 21,657 were seriously injured, far worse than for other modes of transport.

0_1620.text: We will: Work for a road transport system that results in zero deaths or serious injuries by systematically reducing sources of danger on the roads.

0_1621.text: Reduce both collisions and fuel use by bringing down speed limits, in particular to 20 mph in residential areas, including main roads where people live, work and shop; enforce speed limits with speed cameras and policing.

0_1622.text: Change the culture of road justice and civil compensation with a road danger reduction approach.

0_1623.text: A greater duty of care should be expected of drivers in reducing injury and intimidation of vulnerable road users.

0_1624.text: Motor vehicle drivers should be presumed liable for injuries to pedestrians and cyclists.

0_1625.text: If the casualty has contributed to the collision, compensation may be reduced, but not when the victim is a child, elderly (70+) or impaired.

0_1626.text: Reduce the alcohol limit for drivers to as close to zero as is practicable.

0_1627.text: Require newly manufactured lorries to be equipped with best practice technology to make sure that drivers are fully aware of the presence of all pedestrians and cyclists.

0_1628.text: Pedestrian and cyclist fatalities and serious injuries when involved in collisions with lorries are predictable, preventable and unacceptable.

0_1629.text: The technology already exists and is in use in several countries and consists of a mixture of in-cab screens linked to cameras, multiple wing mirrors and physical modification to prevent people being dragged under the vehicle.

0_1630.text: Lorries already in use must be retro-fitted with the same equipment and lorries not so equipped will not be allowed into our towns and cities.

0_1631.text: Reduce lorry activity and road freight volume by improving rail freight services, reducing the number of empty or partially loaded trips, and using cargo bikes for last-mile deliveries to replace some white van trips.

0_1632.text: Towns and cities for people We need to rescue our towns and cities from traffic and turn them back into places where we want to be.

0_1633.text: The Green Party will support an Active Travel Bill for England in order to achieve this.

0_1634.text: Make streets healthy and safe places for people to cycle and walk and for children to play, while building physical activity into their daily journeys.

0_1635.text: Help schools and workplaces to support active travel to and from work, and encourage local authorities to assist this by linking their public health and transport functions.

0_1636.text: Ensure that all planning decisions have to take into account the active travel and public transport implications.

0_1637.text: Make public transport more convenient by integrating ticketing with smart regional ticketing systems such as the LondonOyster card.

0_1638.text: Introduce road-pricing schemes such as the London congestion charge and road-user tolls for heavy lorries.

0_1639.text: Begin consultation with a view to developing a framework for the progressive elimination of diesel exhaust emissions.

0_1640.text: A major cause of air pollution is emissions from diesel vehicles (cars, buses and trains).

0_1641.text: We recognise the latest scientific evidence of the harmful effect of diesel on human health.

0_1642.text: Introduce Ultra Low Emission Zones to ensure air pollution reduces to comply with EU limits.

0_1643.text: Reduce the need for car parking spaces by reducing car dependency and transferring trips, where appropriate, to walking, cycling and public transport.

0_1644.text: Car parking is expensive to provide, can obstruct pedestrians and people with disabilities if it takes place on pavements, and takes up valuable road space that could be reallocated to pedestrians and cyclists.

0_1645.text: Reduce parking spaces in new developments and increase rates of walking, cycling and public transport by strengthening planning law to make best practice travel plans mandatory for workplaces, homes and other destinations.

0_1646.text: Eliminate pavement parking and, in close cooperation with waste collection and emergency services, make sure that these essential services have unimpeded access to all addresses.

0_1647.text: Ensure that parking policies in residential areas deliver a high-quality street environment and reduce the numbers of those who are clogging up residential streets as part of a commuter trip or other activities not related to a visit to an address in that street.

0_1648.text: Parking charges of all kinds in public car parks and streets will be proportionate to the full cost of providing that facility.

0_1649.text: Provide cycle parking throughout towns and cities at locations where there is demand and invest in on-street secure cycle storage in residential streets.

0_1650.text: A rural transport revolution Approximately 20% of the UK population live in rural areas and many of these are retired and may have to adjust to a lifestyle without a car for health and income reasons.

0_1651.text: It is essential that rural areas get the best possible deal for widening transport choices.

0_1652.text: The Green Party does not accept that there is a fundamental and intractable rural transport problem.

0_1653.text: Rural transport in many parts of Germany, Austria and Switzerland is of a very high quality and the quality is based on careful planning, coordination and investment and recognition that, although a car will be needed for a proportion of journeys, it is not the default option.

0_1654.text: The small village of Gempen in Switzerland, with a population of about 800, has ten buses each day that connect with tram and train services at the next-larger settlement (Dornach).

0_1655.text: We will: Make sure that rural areas are not neglected when transport budgets and planning for our cities and city regions are under discussion.

0_1656.text: Develop networks of community and public transport to provide regular links to onward transport networks.

0_1657.text: Introduce speed limits of 20 mph in villages and 40 mph on rural roads.

0_1659.text: Lancaster Greens helped to deliver the Cycling Demonstration Town project with more than £4 million external funding for safer routes and cycling promotion.

0_1660.text: Greens in power carry out our transport policies In Green-led Brighton, the Council has: Introduced the largest connected 20 mph zone in the country, and casualties fell by 19%; Built a new cycle hub at the station; Introduced cycle priority at junctions, proper cycle lanes and cycle contraflow lanes; Introduced the first ‘floating’ bus stop, resulting in: bus usage increasing by almost 9% over two years, falling nitrous oxide and carbon dioxide emissions, an 11% increase in daily cycle journeys between 2009 and 2012, and falling road casualties, with 200 fewer killed and injured in 2013 than in 2011.

0_1661.text: CHAPTER 13 Imagine the UK as a good global neighbour, committed to peacemaking and to helping create the conditions for a flourishing life for everyone on the planet.

0_1662.text: This is a UK bent on resolving conflicts rather than making them worse, determined to listen as well as to speak.

0_1663.text: How about the chance to vote for a Europe of self reliance rather than free trade and indiscriminate growth?

0_1664.text: Imagine a climate change agreement that is both just and effective.

0_1665.text: Picture a world where the big decisions are made by democratically elected governments and not by private corporations – picture the end of talk of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP)...

0_1666.text: We live in an interconnected world, which brings huge benefits as well as drawbacks.

0_1667.text: Decisions that we make affect people in other countries, and events in other countries affect us.

0_1668.text: In particular, UK foreign and military policies over many years have contributed to challenges to our security today: By using up global resources or polluting the air or water that we all share; By influencing how much we pay for diminishing natural resources and how much we get paid for our labour; By driving displacement; By creating insecurity at home and abroad.

0_1669.text: Greens are internationalists and want to live in a world that is just and fair, secure and peaceful, and where human rights are universally respected.

0_1670.text: We will make the UK a force for international good, respected throughout the global community, with coherent foreign policies based on building effective and cooperative security relations across the world.

0_1671.text: All countries deserve a voice in global decision-making, and we want to use ours to support the following: A new, holistic and consistent approach to peace and defence, which is focused on genuine peacekeeping and respect for the sovereignty of peoples around the world.

0_1672.text: A fundamental restructuring of our global economy, with power held at the local and regional level and only passed upwards when international cooperation is necessary.

0_1673.text: We call this ‘subsidiarity’ – this principle is the basis of our approach to the European Union and other international organisations.

0_1674.text: Writing off and writing down unpayable international debt, avoiding paternalistic aid, and securing the rights of First Nations peoples.

0_1675.text: Trade that supports the well-being of workers that can be achieved without breaching sustainability limits is useful, but a blind commitment to ‘free’ trade is not.

0_1676.text: A global policy of Contraction and Convergence in which rich countries’ use of finite energy resources contracts, while that of poorer countries expands, to converge on an equitable and sustainable per capita sharing of global energy, designed to keep within 2 degrees C of warming.

0_1677.text: Only in this way can poor countries improve living standards while the world as a whole avoids hitting resource and climate limits.

0_1678.text: Making UK foreign policy genuinely independent, based on the principles of shared responsibility, cooperative security and human rights.

0_1679.text: We will: Work to reform the United Nations and associated bodies, to reflect better the needs and interests of all countries, and make the UN more representative and effective through abolishing permanent seats on the UN Security Council (UNSC).

0_1680.text: Seek negotiated settlements to a range of conflicts around the world and block sales of weapons and military equipment that increase misery and death for non-combatants and have particularly destructive impacts on vulnerable peoples, notably women and children.

0_1681.text: Outlaw the use of torture, the sale of torture equipment and the rendition of people to countries where torture is not prohibited, and enforce the laws against it.

0_1682.text: Take proportionate measures to protect against terrorism, ensuring that civil liberties are not undermined in the process , that communities are not scapegoated and that action reflects a genuine assessment of the threat to our security.

0_1683.text: We need targeted policing and security service activities, not mass surveillance, prisons that rehabilitate those convicted of terrorism offences and effective programmes to prevent radicalisation and to deradicalise individuals.

0_1684.text: Uphold the principles of freedom of speech and peaceful protest, including support for vulnerable communities of all religious faiths and none.

0_1685.text: In relation to specific international challenges around election time: We opposed military interventions in Afghanistan, Libya and Iraq, and will oppose all future interventions that lack a sufficient moral, legal and democratic mandate or when military action risks being counter-productive, for example by providing fertile recruitment, fundraising and propaganda opportunities.

0_1686.text: We will instead advocate for regional solutions to conflicts and for the UK to take a lead in advancing diplomatic, economic and political solutions to the threats posed by terrorist groups such as ISIS and Boko Haram.

0_1687.text: We would provide humanitarian support for the millions of refugees displaced by these conflicts.

0_1688.text: We seek a just, sustainable and peaceful solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict, based on mutual recognition of the rights to independent statehood for Palestinians and Israelis.

0_1689.text: We condemn human rights violations by both parties and the oppression and disproportionate use of aggression by the Israeli government against the people of Gaza.

0_1690.text: We seek to suspend the EU– Israel Association Agreement.

0_1691.text: `We condemn state-sanctioned breaches of human rights by countries such as China, Syria, Sudan and Pakistan, as well as by individuals or organisations, `and we advocate the use of sanctions and legal action via the International Criminal Court for those violating international human rights standards.

0_1692.text: We would work to support a negotiated settlement between Russia and Ukraine, while developing a new security structure for the region involving the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe, with opposition to arms transfers and military interventions in regional and internal conflicts.

0_1693.text: International agreement on climate change A global climate disaster can be prevented only if the whole world works together.

0_1694.text: The Green Party will make it its main foreign policy priority to secure a major new international agreement, in particular at the UN meeting in Paris in December 2015, with a wide-ranging workable plan to arrest climate change and share global resources more evenly.

0_1695.text: The basis of this agreement should be Contraction and Convergence (C&C).

0_1696.text: C&C means: Allowing countries that currently emit very little carbon dioxide to increase their emissions, using their energy resources to reduce poverty and improve their people’s well-being.

0_1697.text: Requiring all other countries to reduce their emissions to a small per capita limit, fixed to be consistent with a global limit that keeps temperature rises below 2 degrees C. Recognising the special responsibility of countries such as the UK that have become wealthy from 200 years of fossil-fuelbased industrialisation.

0_1698.text: Some of this wealth will need to be shared with poorer countries that have left their fossil fuels in the ground and their forests still standing.

0_1699.text: In these ways, by an agreed date, every citizen of the world will have a fair and equal share of global emissions potential.

0_1700.text: Being rich will no longer permit people to unfairly affect the whole world’s atmosphere and climate.

0_1701.text: Security and defence The UK’s recent history has been scarred by involvement in ill-advised military interventions that have undermined our national and international security.

0_1702.text: The Green Party opposed these interventions, which have brought havoc to Iraq and Libya and only fragile gains in Afghanistan, as well as driving an increased terrorist threat closer to home – all at the cost of many precious lives and vast amounts of money and other resources that could have been better used for other needs.

0_1703.text: Green MP Caroline Lucas challenged the PM in the debate on 26 September 2014 on military action in Iraq ‘Will the Prime Minister recognise that killing extremists does not kill their ideas?

0_1704.text: On the contrary – it can often feed their ideas, and for that reason the former MI6 head of counter-terrorism has said that getting Saudi Arabia and Iran around a negotiating table would be far more effective than bombing.

0_1705.text: Why are we not hearing far more from this Prime Minister about the political and diplomatic solutions to this situation, rather than reaching for the military solution, which could undermine them?’

0_1706.text: We will restructure and update the UK’s security and defence establishments and services so that they contribute to the international good.

0_1707.text: We will: Pursue a policy of ‘defensive defence’, which threatens no one yet makes it clear that threats and attacks will be resisted.

0_1708.text: Take a leading role in preventing violent conflict, genocide and war crimes overseas through (i) helping to develop local capacities to avoid, manage and resolve conflicts; and (ii) enhancing the UK’s well-respected role in genuine peacekeeping and the protection of non-combatant communities.

0_1709.text: Develop policies and programmes for ‘environmental defence’ and disaster mitigation and relief, drawing on the skills and activities of our current military forces and increasing gender representation and training to equip the UK to contribute more effectively in these kinds of human security emergencies.

0_1710.text: Diminish dependence on arms sales through a halt to government subsidies and introducing a strict licensing regime to prevent sales of weapons and military equipment to undemocratic regimes and those that violate human rights (including, at the present time, Israel and Saudi Arabia).

0_1711.text: Look after veterans and their families.

0_1712.text: International disarmament and security agreements The Green Party will ensure that UK security and defence policies are consistent with international law, including international humanitarian law, and that the UK implements in good faith all relevant obligations in the following international treaties: the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, the Outer Space Treaty, the Biological Weapons Convention, the Chemical Weapons Convention, the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty, the Mine Ban Treaty, the Cluster Munitions Convention, the Arms Trade Treaty, the UN Programme of Action on Small Arms and Light Weapons, and the Geneva Protocols.
