0_1713.text: We will: Enhance UK cooperation with civil society and international agencies to implement relevant UN Security Council Resolutions, including UNSC Resolutions 1325, 1820 and 1889, dealing with the role of gender violence in war and the necessity to involve women at all levels in preventing war and building peace and security.

0_1714.text: Save a massive £100 billion over the next 30 years by cancelling Trident replacement and decommissioning existing nuclear forces and facilities.

0_1715.text: Enhance international security and non-proliferation by initiating and/or joining negotiations on a universally applicable nuclear abolition treaty to prohibit the use, deployment, development, production, stockpiling and transfer of nuclear weapons and requiring their complete elimination.

0_1716.text: Initiate and/or join negotiations on new international treaties and laws to prohibit the development, deployment and use of autonomous weapons (such as ‘killer robots’), depleted uranium weapons, weapon systems that are intended for use in and from outer space, and weapons that leave explosive remnants and toxic legacies in war-affected communities, while mandating the protection of civilians from any new weapons developments for the future.

0_1717.text: Green MEP Keith Taylor and Palestine Keith Taylor is a member of the European Parliament’s delegation to Palestine and has visited the Occupied Territories.

0_1718.text: As part of his work, Keith has called for Israel to end its practice of detaining Palestinians without charge, and has supported his constituents in boycott campaigns relating to goods made in illegal Israeli settlements.

0_1719.text: Keith has long campaigned for the recognition of Palestine and has put his name to a successful Resolution calling on the European Parliament to recognise Palestine as a state.

0_1720.text: Joining up the policies So what do war, terrorism, food policy and the oil industry have to do with each other?

0_1721.text: If we didn’t depend on oil from the Middle East, we wouldn’t need to invent reasons to go to war there when supply lines are threatened.

0_1722.text: If we weren’t involved in wars in the Middle East, terrorism here would lose its raison d’être.

0_1723.text: With less fossil fuel we would have to expand renewables and grow more of our own food, making us far less vulnerable to blockade in any future war.

0_1724.text: Security policy is not just about tanks, it’s also about acting responsibly and building resilience at home.

0_1726.text: Europe The Green Party recognises that the UK is part of Europe and that we cannot cut ourselves off from our geography or its political realities.

0_1727.text: Our message on Europe is positive, not based on fear and nostalgia.

0_1728.text: Much EU action has been progressive: safeguarding basic rights, peace and security achieved through mutual understanding, environmental protection, the spread of culture and ideas, and regulation of the financial system.

0_1729.text: And in other areas, such as welfare policy, open discussion and coordination are useful.

0_1730.text: However, we prioritise local self-reliance rather than the EU’s unsustainable economics of free trade and growth.

0_1731.text: We would not adopt the Euro, which cannot work properly without much deeper political integration, and this would be contrary to our policy of subsidiarity.

0_1732.text: We support the proposal to have an in–out referendum so that the British people can have their say.

0_1733.text: This is because much has changed since the UK joined the Common Market in 1974.

0_1734.text: Endless debate on membership is a diversion from more important matters, such as ending inequality and adapting our economy to One-Planet Living.

0_1735.text: So it’s yes to Europe, yes to reform of the EU but also yes to a referendum.

0_1736.text: This is the policy that led to the election of an additional Green MEP, Molly Scott Cato, in the South West last year.

0_1737.text: Migration Migration is a fact of life.

0_1738.text: People have always moved within countries and between countries.

0_1739.text: Much of the UK’s language, culture and way of life has been enriched by successive new arrivals over thousands of years.

0_1740.text: Most families living here will have members of their extended family who live abroad or include members who were born abroad – 5 million British citizens live abroad, around 2 million of them in the EU.

0_1741.text: We take it for granted that we can move to live where we like within our country, and increasingly within Europe and further afield, as others do.

0_1742.text: Much of the time, migration is voluntary, is on a relatively small scale and is a positive benefit for all concerned.

0_1743.text: But, increasingly, people are being forced to move because Climate change affects their environment so that it can no longer support them; The economic opportunities in their home country are so limited that they leave home to work abroad; or War, natural disasters or political repression lead them to become refugees.

0_1744.text: These pressures lead to growing numbers of people seeking to come to the UK from the EU and elsewhere.

0_1745.text: But it is wrong to scapegoat immigrants for problems with housing, education, health or local authority services.

0_1746.text: These problems are the result of successive governments’ policy failure, which the rest of this manifesto is designed to put right.

0_1747.text: The Green Party believes that, in the medium to long term, we must reduce the pressures that lead to involuntary migration.

0_1748.text: We will Seek through our international policies to reduce war and discourage repressive regimes that lead to the creation of refugees.

0_1749.text: Make a global deal on climate change a priority of our foreign policy, and help poorer countries cope with the climate change.

0_1750.text: Seek to promote ecologically sustainable development in the poorer parts of the world, so that there is greater equality between the richer and poorer nations.

0_1751.text: Promote policies in the EU that improve opportunities across the Union and refocus on social and environmental benefits, rather than economic liberalisation.

0_1752.text: We accept that these policies will take time to work and that we must address immigration as it is here and now.

0_1753.text: Some controls on immigration will be needed for the foreseeable future; for now, we reject an open borders approach.

0_1754.text: We also reject the imposition of an arbitrary numerical cap on net migration.

0_1755.text: The latter in particular is impossible to achieve (especially given that there is no control on the numbers emigrating) and leads to many individual injustices.

0_1756.text: Any controls must respect the following principles: Mutual legal obligations within the EU on freedom of movement.

0_1757.text: International obligations to accept refugees, whether seeking sanctuary from wars, political repression or climate change.

0_1758.text: Respect for the integrity of families.

0_1759.text: The arrival of a grandmother might well have no direct economic effect, but her contribution to family life may contribute hugely to our society.

0_1760.text: We would in particular abolish the policy that requires a British citizen to have an income of at least £18,600 a year before their partner can come to live in the UK, which discriminates against poorer people, make it much easier for adult dependants, mainly elderly parents, of British citizens to come and live here.

0_1762.text: Foreign students contribute hugely to our education system, both financially and in terms of the wider perspectives they bring.

0_1763.text: They also take back to their home countries skills that they have learnt here that will be valuable at home and positive attitudes towards the UK.

0_1764.text: In particular we would allow students to work in the UK for two years after graduation; widen the Youth Mobility Scheme to allow those from poorer countries to participate.

0_1765.text: No priority simply for economic reasons.

0_1766.text: We would in particular aim to retain more of those trained in the UK in the health service so that we have less need to take health service workers from countries that can ill afford to lose them.

0_1767.text: We would also: Review the rules for those wishing to set up or do business here to ensure they are not discriminatory against smaller businesses.

0_1768.text: Not simply accept people just because they are rich.

0_1769.text: The London housing market in particular has been gravely distorted by the number of rich migrants buying property, bidding up prices all along the housing chain.

0_1770.text: Ensure that no prospective immigrant is held in detention.

0_1771.text: As a matter of urgency, the administrative detention of children and pregnant women should cease immediately.

0_1772.text: Review the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002, particularly with regard to issues of access to legal advice, childcare and levels of subsistence allowance, and reintroduce Legal Aid for reasonable levels of immigration and asylum work.

0_1773.text: In addition, once immigrants have arrived, we would: Assist integration by making available free or affordable English or Welsh language lessons to all new immigrants who want them, costing about £200 million a year.

0_1774.text: Open up ways for existing irregular migrants who have been here for three years to become legal.

0_1775.text: In particular, a legal status must be provided for people who have not succeeded in their claim for humanitarian protection but who cannot be returned to their country of origin owing to the political situation there.

0_1776.text: Ratify the International Labour Organization’s Convention on Domestic Workers.

0_1777.text: Review asylum procedures to ensure that destitution plays no role in the asylum process by allowing those seeking sanctuary to work.

0_1778.text: Ensure that those who have been trafficked are not subject to summary deportation; we must protect the victims of trafficking.

0_1779.text: They should receive a temporary right to stay and have the same right to apply to remain as others seeking to migrate.

0_1780.text: Trade, aid and grassroots development People around the world have their own strategies and priorities for improving their lives and communities.

0_1781.text: ‘Development’ should not be directed by rich countries, which too often have their own business interests in mind.

0_1782.text: Instead we need to provide the political space, democratic voice and appropriate resources to enable people in all countries to pursue their own chosen directions in ways that work for them.

0_1783.text: International trade can benefit or harm the world’s people, depending on its nature.

0_1784.text: Genuinely fair trade, alongside sustainable haulage practices, can bring benefits for all of us.

0_1785.text: But ever-growing trade, over ever-growing distances and with the sole aim of making a profit can make life difficult for workers and is a sure-fire way of exceeding the limits of our finite planet.

0_1786.text: Similarly, the world’s current structure of international institutions and trade rules can put less developed economies at a disadvantage, while making it easy for global corporations to buy up their land and resources.

0_1787.text: We need to work with others around the world to reform and reinvent these institutions so that they facilitate greater global equality and justice.

0_1788.text: The Green Party will: Advocate for ambitious sustainable development goals, including a commitment to end AIDS, TB and malaria; action to eliminate violence against women and girls; and practical measures to eradicate poverty and reduce inequality.

0_1789.text: Take real action to end tax evasion and avoidance and transfer mispricing by transnational corporations, which steals resources especially from poorer countries.

0_1790.text: Support global efforts to develop a fairer global tax system.

0_1791.text: Put a stop to the corporate takeover of African food by ending UK funding of the G8’s New Alliance for Food Security and Nutrition.

0_1792.text: Promote fair trade, in particular seeking to ensure that workers in poor countries receive decent pay and conditions within International Labour Organization (ILO) standards.

0_1793.text: Initiate democratic discussions, alongside international trade unions, citizen groups and the ILO, to investigate the potential for a global minimum wage to address in-work poverty and exploitation.

0_1794.text: Ensure UK companies operating abroad respect international human rights and environmental standards and do not encourage corruption, enforcing the UN Convention against Corruption and the OECD Anti-Bribery Convention, and reporting fully upon their activities.

0_1795.text: Ensure that every country has the political space to make its own democratic choices, without pressure to prise open its economy for ‘free’ trade.

0_1796.text: In particular, we oppose the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (see ‘The Green Party opposes the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership’ box).

0_1797.text: Ensure that trade deals allow poor countries to control their economies; we will take the UK out of trade agreements that go against this.

0_1798.text: Support the rights of indigenous people to control their own lands and resources.

0_1799.text: The world has become a very unequal place.

0_1800.text: Rich countries such as the UK have benefited from global flows of wealth while poorer countries and groups have tended to lose out.

0_1801.text: Some transfers of resources from rich countries to poorer ones are therefore needed in order to redress the balance and allow poorer countries to improve living standards.

0_1802.text: We will: Fight for the writing-off of international debts for the poorest countries and limiting repayments for other low-income countries, to ensure they can fund decent public services for their people.

0_1803.text: Increase the overseas aid budget from 0.7% of GDP to 1.0% of GDP over the Parliament, costing around £6 billion a year in 2019.

0_1804.text: Aid will not be tied, and will be distributed in ways that are focused on poverty eradication supporting grassroots initiatives, women’s rights and environmental sustainability while respecting local priorities.

0_1805.text: Help poorer countries to fund climate change adaptation and build resilient communities through the UN Adaptation Fund.

0_1806.text: We recognise that the UK owes them a climate debt for our disproportionately high emissions and contributions to global pollution and climate damage.

0_1807.text: The Green Party opposes the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) TTIP is globalisation in its worst form, designed to submit democratically elected governments to the will of private corporations.

0_1808.text: Companies will be able to take legal action against governments that they think threaten their profits.

0_1809.text: National policies in EU countries for health, environmental, consumer and social protection could be challenged by companies from anywhere in the world in private international tribunals, run by corporate lawyers.

0_1811.text: Attempts to bring the National Health Service and the railways back into public ownership could be financially penalised or blocked; Authorisations for genetically modified organisms may be accelerated at European level and risk assessment standards lowered; and Regulation of banks and the financial industry would be harder, if not impossible.

0_1813.text: Imagine crime falling year on year because the causes of crime are being dealt with – unemployment, insecurity at home, school exclusions, inequality, mental health issues, drugs.

0_1814.text: Imagine a prison population at the European average rather than way over it.

0_1815.text: Picture prisons in public hands and actually rehabilitating prisoners.

0_1816.text: Have you been a victim of crime?

0_1817.text: Picture restorative justice, which gives you a voice and helps the offender to take responsibility and make amends.

0_1818.text: It’s been said that, the more dysfunctional a society is, the more laws it has.

0_1819.text: Here is how dysfunctional the UK has become: Under Margaret Thatcher there were 1,724 new laws per year; Under John Major there were 2,402 per year; Under Tony Blair, 2,663 per year.

0_1820.text: The UK imprisons more people than any other country in Europe.

0_1821.text: Under the Coalition, the prison population reached an all-time high of 88,179 in December 2011, and the number of front-line prison officers dropped by 30% between 2010 and 2013.

0_1822.text: This is a picture of a very uneasy society.

0_1823.text: The context of crime Crime has a context: 60% of offenders have no qualifications at all; 48% have literacy skills below those expected of an 11 year old; 65% have numeracy skills below those expected of an 11 year old; 67% were unemployed at the time of imprisonment; 49% of prisoners ran away from home as a child; 41% were excluded from school; 71% suffer from two or more mental disorders; 70% of offenders had been drinking at the time the offences for which they were imprisoned were committed; There is more crime in more unequal societies.

0_1824.text: So: education, employment and security for all – this is the heart of Green Party crime policy.

0_1825.text: We would: Treat drug addiction as a health issue (see Chapter 6 for our health policy).

0_1826.text: Restrict police use of random stop and search powers, which damage police and youth relations.

0_1827.text: Improve the design of our cities to provide safer streets and public spaces.

0_1828.text: Focus on crime prevention measures, including more community policing under local democratic control, more local police stations and the return of bus conductors and others who have an important effect on social order.

0_1829.text: Oppose the privatisation of policing and establish a Royal Commission on Policing as a first step towards delivering a service that’s fit for purpose.

0_1830.text: Provide proper funding for Women’s Refuges for survivors of domestic violence and make domestic abuse a specific criminal offence.

0_1831.text: Work to change attitudes towards rape, including improving initial responses to women, early evidence collection and access to justice.

0_1832.text: Abolish Police and Crime Commissioners, and return control of the police to local government.

0_1833.text: Green London Assembly Member Jenny Jones saves Police Road Safety Unit In 2009, Jenny fought the closure of the Metropolitan Police Commercial Vehicle Education Unit, which instructs HGV drivers on road sharing and awareness of vulnerable road users.

0_1834.text: Restorative justice and offender rehabilitation Once people have offended, what next?

0_1835.text: Punishment for its own sake (retributive justice) gets us nowhere, and that’s why the Green Party would greatly expand the use of restorative justice, with the offender making up to the victim and the community.

0_1836.text: This gives victims a voice and helps offenders to see the effects of what they have done.

0_1837.text: This should enable us substantially to reduce the numbers in prison and reduce reoffending.

0_1838.text: In particular, we believe there are far too many children in the penal system.

0_1839.text: What happens when prisoners are returned to the community?

0_1840.text: Nearly 50% of adult offenders released between April 2011 and March 2012 reoffended.

0_1841.text: This is a real indictment of what happens to people in prison.

0_1842.text: The Green Party would: Oppose the privatisation of the probation services.

0_1843.text: Provide access to real work and education, the work to include repairing damage done by crime.

0_1844.text: Provide access to artistic and creative facilities.

0_1845.text: Provide access to literacy and numeracy classes from the first day of imprisonment.

0_1846.text: Operate a smaller prison system, saving £5.5 billion over the course of the Parliament.

0_1847.text: Grant prisoners the right to vote.

0_1848.text: Oppose the use of the death penalty abroad.

0_1849.text: Greens in power carry out our policies Restorative justice works.

0_1850.text: In Green-led Brighton, the number of young people entering the criminal justice system in the city fell over the three successive years to October 2013 as the Council’s youth crime prevention team joined with police to help young people understand the impact of their behaviour and make amends.

0_1852.text: It does all join up – One fine day in April 2019 You leave work at 5 pm on the dot, and check the bus stop’s electronic display – your bus home is due in 3 minutes.

0_1853.text: It glides to a stop, electric motor whirring quietly, and you beep on with your smartcard.

0_1854.text: The buses are not-for-profit now, and cheaper than they were four years ago.

0_1855.text: You grab a seat and dig out your phone to check your bank balance because today is pay day!

0_1856.text: You’re working as a cleaner at the hospital, so with the £9.60 minimum wage you get around £1,500 a month before tax.

0_1857.text: The rent controls that were recently brought in mean you don’t pay too much to your landlord and, since your home was super-insulated through the Green Warm Deal, your gas bill’s not much either.

0_1858.text: With all that, you’re getting by pretty comfortably, and managing to save up a bit to buy a house.

0_1859.text: The bus stops by your son’s nursery, where all the kids go free, and he comes tumbling out giggling.

0_1860.text: Together you walk round the corner to your gran’s new council house for a cup of tea.

0_1861.text: Her carer stays to chat for a few minutes before heading off to visit his next client.

0_1862.text: He says that since social care is free now, and much better funded, he’s finding the work a lot more rewarding and might make a career of it.

0_1863.text: Your gran is cheerful too, happy to be back on her feet after her recent stay in hospital, and glad the whole thing was noticed early and dealt with quickly so she can get on with her life.

0_1864.text: Later, back at home, a child from down the road knocks on your door to ask if your daughter can play out at the park.

0_1865.text: They are friends from school, the only two kids out of the 20 in their class who have packed lunches now that school dinners are free.

0_1866.text: They head off to the park’s new play area, promising to pick up some milk at the Post Office on their way back.

0_1867.text: You sit down at your laptop and start planning your next holiday, two weeks on the beach in Cornwall.

0_1868.text: It’s a long trek, but the train tickets cost less than you expected and there’s a local line that gets you practically to the campsite gate....

0_1870.text: In 2010 the major election issue was the economy, and in particular the state of the public finances.

0_1871.text: The Coalition parties pledged to close the deficit – the gap between government spending and government income.

0_1872.text: They have not done so; the gap between spending and income in 2009 of 11% of GDP has narrowed, but was still 5% in 2014.

0_1873.text: This is hardly surprising because the other parties’ election manifestos gave no costed plans for how they would reduce the deficit.

0_1874.text: They made promises but gave no details.

0_1875.text: We were treated to post-election surprises such as increased VAT and huge cuts to essential public services such as benefits, libraries, children’s centres and mental health support.

0_1876.text: By contrast, the Green Party produced a worked-out financial plan in its 2010 manifesto.

0_1877.text: Again in this manifesto, we are providing a costed plan for how we would protect and improve our NHS, schools and public services, and pay for them with fairer, more progressive taxation.

0_1878.text: We use current government data and show exactly how we would do things differently.

0_1879.text: In this financial plan, we take no account of any extra money that could be available to government as a result of ‘Regaining control of our money’ (see the box in Chapter 9) – instead, these plans are based on the real-world current economic environment and on strict assumptions about the effects of changes.

0_1880.text: Although it has not been our prime objective to end the current account deficit (that is, including expenditure other than investment) by the end of the Parliament, these plans show how we would do it.

0_1881.text: After a brief note on territorial coverage, there are three sections – our basic economic assumptions, our plans for spending and our plans for taxation.

0_1882.text: We conclude with the overall effect on government finances and on the gap between spending and income.

0_1883.text: We are publishing separately an illustrative costing for Basic Income.

0_1885.text: This is the manifesto of the Green Party of England and Wales.

0_1886.text: Separate sister Green parties cover Scotland and Northern Ireland.

0_1887.text: Many public services are devolved, with the Scottish Parliament, the Welsh Assembly or the Northern Ireland Assembly taking responsibility.

0_1888.text: However, most decisions on government expenditure and on taxation are ultimately taken on a UK basis, this is a UK general election and, despite the fact that this Green Party covers only England and Wales, and to maintain consistency and comparability, all the figures in this chapter are UK figures.

0_1889.text: Economic assumptions The most important assumption is what the government assumes about the growth of the economy.

0_1890.text: If the economy grows, the revenues from taxation will be larger.

0_1891.text: Both Labour and the Coalition made optimistic assumptions about growth in 2010.

0_1892.text: We based our 2010 calculations on lower growth assumptions.

0_1893.text: In the event, the economy barely grew in the middle of the period and, although we were less wrong than Labour or the Coalition, we were still some way out.

0_1894.text: Many of the Coalition’s problems have their origin in this extraordinary optimism about growth.

0_1895.text: The figures are as follows: The Coalition is once again assuming growth of around 12% over the Parliament, at around 2.5% each year.

0_1896.text: We expect growth to slow a little over the Parliament.

0_1897.text: The figures are: Using these figures we can then work out our prediction for real GDP in each of the five years of the Parliament.

0_1898.text: All our figures throughout this manifesto, for both spending and revenues, are in real 2015 terms.

0_1899.text: Our government spending figures are worked out as follows.

0_1900.text: We use the current government plans for real terms spending in 2015 as a baseline (that is, we repeat the same figure for each year), so we are not taking into account the Coalition’s overall plans to cut public spending up to 2018.

0_1901.text: We then express what we’d do differently in terms of how much we’d increase or reduce each item relative to this baseline figure.

0_1902.text: In most cases there is some phasing of expenditure, recognising in particular that our changes cannot realistically start with a full year’s spending in 2015.

0_1903.text: Our additional expenditures include a line for changed interest on the national debt.

0_1904.text: Like the Coalition, we would fund the continuing deficit by borrowing.

0_1905.text: If we reduce the deficit more slowly than the Coalition’s plans, we would pay extra interest on the accumulated debt, and this line reflects that.

0_1906.text: Our proposed savings are as follows:

1_25.text: We have a plan for every stage of your life: FOR THE BEST START IN LIFE we will continue to increase spending on the NHS, provide 7-day a week access to your GP and deliver a truly 7-day NHS – so you know you will always have access to a free and high quality health service when you need it most.

1_26.text: FOR YOUR SCHOOL YEARS we will maintain the amount of money that follows each child into school, ensure there is a good primary school place available for every child and lift the cap on university places – so you have the skills you need to succeed.

1_27.text: TO SECURE YOUR FIRST JOB we will create 3 million new apprenticeships; take everyone earning less than £12,500 out of Income Tax altogether and pass a law to ensure we have a Tax-Free Minimum Wage in this country; and continue to create a fairer welfare system where benefits are capped to the level that makes work pay – so you are rewarded for working hard and doing the right thing.

1_28.text: AS YOU RAISE YOUR FAMILY we will extend the Right to Buy to Housing Association tenants, build 200,000 new Starter Homes – 20 per cent below the market price, for first-time buyers under 40 //– and provide 30 hours of free childcare to working parents of three and four year-olds// – so you are able to work while having the security of your own home in which to raise your family.

1_29.text: WHILE YOU GROW OLDER we will not raise VAT, National Insurance contributions or Income Tax but we will raise the 40p Income Tax threshold to £50,000 and take the family home out of tax by increasing the effective Inheritance Tax threshold for married couples and civil partners to £1 million – so you can keep more of your income and pass it on to future generations.

1_30.text: AND WHEN YOU RETIRE we will continue to increase the Basic State Pension by at least 2.5 per cent through the triple lock, give you the freedom to use your pension savings as you want and pass them on tax-free

1_31.text: and we will cap the amount you can be charged for your residential care – so you can have the dignity and security you deserve in your old age.

1_32.text: The next Conservative Government will secure a better future for you, your family and Britain.

1_33.text: Foreword Over the last five years, we have put our country back on the right track.

1_34.text: Five years ago, Britain was on the brink.

1_35.text: As the outgoing Labour Treasury Minister put it with brutal candour, ‘there is no money’.

1_36.text: Since then, we have turned things around.

1_37.text: Britain is now one of the fastest growing major economies in the world.

1_38.text: We are getting our national finances back under control.

1_39.text: We have halved our deficit as a share of our economy.

1_40.text: More people are in work than ever before.

1_41.text: Britain is back on its feet, strong and growing stronger every day.

1_42.text: This has not happened by accident.

1_43.text: It is the result of difficult decisions and of patiently working through our long-term economic plan.

1_44.text: Above all, it is the product of a supreme national effort, in which everyone has made sacrifices and everyone has played their part.

1_45.text: It is a profound Conservative belief that our country is made great not through the action of government alone, but through the flair, the ingenuity and hard work of the British people – and so it has proved the last five years.

1_46.text: We can be proud of what we have achieved so far together, and especially proud that as we have taken hard decisions on public spending, we have protected the National Health Service, with 9,500 more doctors and 6,900 more nurses, and ensured generous rises in the State Pension.

1_47.text: Our friends and competitors overseas look at Britain, and they see a country that is putting its own house in order, a country on the rise.

1_48.text: They see a country that believes in itself.

1_49.text: But our national recovery remains a work in progress.

1_50.text: It is fragile, and with the wrong decisions, it could easily be reversed.

1_51.text: So the central questions at this election are these: how do we maintain our economic recovery, upon which our ambitions for our country depend?

1_52.text: And how do we make sure that the recovery benefits every one of our citizens, at every stage of their lives?

1_53.text: This Manifesto sets out our plan to do just that.

1_54.text: It is a plan for a better future – for you, for your family.

1_55.text: It is a plan for every stage of your life.

1_56.text: For your new-born baby, there will be the world's best medical care.

1_57.text: For your child, there will be a place at an excellent school.

1_58.text: As you look for your first job, we are building a healthy economy that provides a good career for you with a decent income.

1_59.text: As you look for that first home, we will make sure the Government is there to help.

1_60.text: As you raise your family, we will help you with childcare.

1_61.text: And as you grow older, we will ensure that you have dignity in retirement.

1_62.text: Throughout, we will make sure that if you or your family fall ill, you will always be able to depend on our cherished National Health Service to give you the care you need.

1_63.text: And in an increasingly dangerous and uncertain world, we will fulfil the most basic duty of government – to defend our country and keep it safe.

1_64.text: But all of these things depend on a strong and growing economy.

1_65.text: So as you consider how to vote, I hope you will ask this: which party is best placed to keep our economy strong?

1_66.text: The team which has delivered the growing economy we have today, which created more jobs since 2010 than the rest of the European Union put together; or the party which left behind a ruined economy just five short years ago?

1_67.text: Now is a time to build on the progress we have made, not to put it all at risk.

1_68.text: This Manifesto is our plan of action – our plan to take our amazing country forward.

1_69.text: Above all, it is a plan for you.

1_70.text: I hope you will give it your support, so that together, we can see through the task we have begun.

1_71.text: A strong economy to help you and your family Our commitment to you: Your job, your home, the mortgage you pay, the school your children go to, your local hospital, your pension – all these things depend on a strong economy.

1_72.text: So we will carry on working through our long-term economic plan.

1_73.text: We will:keep our economy secure by running a surplus so that we start paying down our debts increase the tax-free Personal Allowance to £12,500 and the 40p Income Tax threshold to £50,000 commit to no increases in VAT, National Insurance contributions or Income Tax crack down on tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance and ensure those who can afford to pay the most do rebalance our economy, build a Northern Powerhouse and back elected metro mayors pursue our ambition to become the most prosperous major economy in the world by the 2030s.

1_74.text: Our long-term economic plan is turning around Britain’s economy.

1_75.text: Five years ago, Britain was reeling from the chaos of Labour’s Great Recession; in 2014 we were the fastest growing of all the major advanced economies – last year, we grew 75 per cent faster than Germany, three times faster than the Eurozone and seven times faster than France.

1_76.text: Five years ago, the budget deficit was more than 10 per cent of GDP, the highest in our peacetime history, and the national debt was rising out of control; today, the deficit is half that level and debt as a share of national income will start falling this financial year.

1_77.text: The fastest growing of all the major advanced economies in 2014 Industries are coming back to life.

1_78.text: Companies are striding into new markets.

1_79.text: Manufacturers are returning to our shores.

1_80.text: More tech companies are starting up here than anywhere else in Europe.

1_81.text: We have overtaken France as the third largest car producer in Europe and there are 760,000 more businesses than in 2010 providing jobs and creating wealth across the country.

1_82.text: The Great Recession has given way to a Great Revival, which is creating on average 1,000 new jobs every day: more than the rest of the European Union combined.

1_84.text: It is the product of hard work by people in every part of the country and it is thanks to the success of our long-term economic plan.

1_85.text: By halving the deficit, we have helped to restore confidence to the economy.

1_86.text: By maintaining fiscal discipline, we have helped keep mortgage rates lower than they otherwise would be.

1_87.text: And by establishing the independent Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), we have ended – permanently – the ability of politicians to cook the books for political gain at the nation’s expense.

1_88.text: With inflation at a record low, the latest OBR forecasts show that living standards will be higher in 2015 than in 2010, and are set to grow strongly every year for the rest of the decade, with the average family £900 better off.

1_89.text: It is only by securing the recovery, dealing with our debts and creating jobs that we can continue to raise living standards.

1_90.text: That means sticking to our long-term economic plan; Britain is on the right path.

1_91.text: But the job is not finished.

1_92.text: There are clouds on the international horizon.

1_94.text: We have cut the record deficit we inherited to five per cent of GDP, but that is still too high.

1_95.text: Our trade with emerging economies is up, with exports to China more than doubled since 2009, but overall we are still too dependent on slow-growing European markets.

1_96.text: Business investment is rising, but we still underinvest compared to other countries.

1_98.text: And while prosperity is now spreading around the country, our economic growth remains uneven, too reliant on financial services.

1_99.text: 1,000 jobs created for every day of the Parliament since 2010 We will finish the job we started in a balanced way.

1_100.text: Those with the broadest shoulders have contributed the most to deficit reduction – which is why inequality has fallen, and child and pensioner poverty are down – and they will continue to do so.

1_101.text: We will increase NHS spending every year.

1_102.text: We will control spending, eliminate the deficit, and start to run a surplus.

1_103.text: We will go from stuck in the red, to back in the black.

1_104.text: By building on the foundations we have put in place, we will have a truly national recovery and be able to pursue our ambition for Britain to become the most prosperous major economy in the world by the 2030s.

1_105.text: If we do not stick to our long-term economic plan, we will slip back again, reversing the progress we have made in the last five years.

1_106.text: More borrowing – and the extra debt interest that it brings – means there is less money to spend on schools and hospitals.

1_107.text: More spending means higher taxes for hardworking people, and interest rates that are higher than they otherwise would be – punishing homeowners, hurting businesses, costing jobs.

1_108.text: A strong economy allows us to invest in and protect our public services like the NHS and schools And failing to control our debt would be more than an economic failing; it would be a moral failing – leaving our children and grandchildren with debts that they could never hope to repay.

1_109.text: So you face a clear choice.

1_110.text: Economic competence, with David Cameron as Prime Minister, following through on our long-term economic plan.

1_111.text: Or economic chaos under Labour, with higher taxes, more debt and no plan to fix our public finances, create jobs or build a more secure economy.

1_112.text: Our plan of action: We will finish the job by eliminating the deficit to keep our economy secure and keep your taxes and mortgage payments down Our long-term economic plan reflects our values: we as a nation should not be piling up and passing on unaffordable levels of debt to the next generation.

1_113.text: We will eliminate the deficit in a sensible and balanced way that will enable us to continue to increase spending on the NHS and cut Income Tax for 30 million working people.

1_114.text: Our deficit reduction plan has two phases.

1_115.text: The first will see us continue to reduce government spending by one per cent each year in real terms for the first two full financial years of the next Parliament, the same rate as over the last five years.

1_116.text: That means saving £1 a year in every £100 that government spends.

1_117.text: We don’t think there’s a business that couldn’t do that – and we don’t think government, when it is spending your money, should be any different.

1_118.text: We have halved the deficit as a share of our economy That will require a further £30 billion in fiscal consolidation over the next two years, on top of the £120 billion that we have already identified and delivered over this Parliament.

1_119.text: We will find £13 billion from departmental savings, the same rate of reduction as in this Parliament.

1_120.text: We will find £12 billion from welfare savings, on top of the £21 billion of savings delivered in this Parliament.

1_121.text: And we will raise at least £5 billion from continuing to tackle tax evasion, and aggressive tax avoidance and tax planning, building on the £7 billion of annual savings we have delivered in this Parliament.

1_122.text: This £30 billion of further consolidation is necessary to ensure that debt keeps falling as a share of GDP and to deliver a balanced structural current budget in 2017-18, meeting the new fiscal mandate that Parliament voted on earlier this year.

1_123.text: Our commitment goes further than this.

1_124.text: A balanced current budget is not enough to deliver a reliable reduction in our level of national debt, which remains far too high in a world of continuing economic challenges.

1_125.text: International evidence and Treasury analysis shows that the only way to keep our economy secure for the future is to eliminate the deficit entirely and start running a surplus.

1_126.text: Anything less would be to ignore the lessons of the past.

1_127.text: That is why, in the second phase of our deficit reduction plan starting in 2018-19, we are set to move into surplus, with the Government taking in more than it is spending for the first time in 18 years.

1_128.text: That means we can start properly paying down our debts and reducing the scale of annual interest payments – reducing the UK’s vulnerability to future shocks by fixing the roof while the sun is shining.

1_129.text: We will achieve this by continuing to control government spending in 2018-19, no longer cutting it in real terms, but instead growing it in line with inflation.

1_130.text: To eliminate the deficit we must continue to cut out wasteful spending and make government more efficient, effective and accountable From 2019-20, after a surplus has been achieved, spending will grow in line with GDP.

1_131.text: A new fundamental principle of fiscal policy, monitored by the independent OBR, will ensure that in normal economic times, when the economy is growing, the government will always run a surplus in order to reduce our national debt and keep our economy secure, with a state neither smaller than we need nor bigger than we can afford.

1_132.text: Total government spending as a share of our national income at the end of the next Parliament is forecast to be very slightly higher than in the year 2000, the year before Labour lost all control of spending and the national debt started its longest rise for hundreds of years.

1_133.text: Our approach is focused on reducing wasteful spending, making savings in welfare, and continuing to crack down on tax evasion and aggressive avoidance.

1_134.text: This means that we can commit to no increases in VAT, Income Tax or National Insurance.

1_135.text: Tax rises on working people would harm our economy, reduce living standards and cost jobs.

1_136.text: Instead, as we reduce the deficit, we will cut Income Tax, as we have done over the last five years: during the next Parliament, we will increase the tax-free Personal Allowance to £12,500 and the higher rate threshold to £50,000, so you keep more of your hard-earned money.

1_137.text: The richest are paying a greater share of income tax than in any of Labour’s 13 years We will continue to build a stronger, safer and more secure banking system that serves its customers and provides businesses with the finance they need to grow and create jobs We will make sure our financial services industry is the best regulated in the world with our new system of supervision led by the independent Bank of England.

1_138.text: Our new Financial Policy Committee will monitor and control the growth of indebtedness and imbalances across the whole economy– a vital task that was totally ignored in the run up to the financial crisis.

1_139.text: Our tough new Financial Conduct Authority will protect consumers and ensure that financial markets work for the benefit of the whole economy.

1_140.text: To protect hardworking taxpayers from future banking crashes, we will finish the process of ring-fencing banks’ high street branches from their investment arms by 2019 at the latest.

1_141.text: In order to ensure that new pay structures for bankers rebuild trust and reduce short-termism, we will ensure that Britain continues to have the toughest regime of bonus deferral and clawback of any financial centre.

1_142.text: We will continue to sell the Government’s stakes in the bailed-out banks and building societies in order to deliver value for money for taxpayers and support the economy.

1_143.text: Hardworking taxpayers supported the banks during the financial crisis and so the banks should in turn support them during the recovery – that is why we will keep the bank levy in place and restrict established banks’ ability to pay less tax by offsetting their profits against past losses.

1_144.text: We will make the banks work for you

1_145.text: Our plan is to ensure banks help secure our recovery and back businesses to create jobs and growth in our economy.

1_146.text: We capped payday lenders, made it easier for you to switch your bank account and will continue to support the credit union movement in making financial services more accessible.

1_147.text: We will continue the successful Funding for Lending scheme into 2016.

1_148.text: We will help new and existing challenger banks to inject fresh competition into the market for personal current accounts, mortgages and business loans, including through the British Business Bank, while backing the financial technology revolution.

1_149.text: We will improve our support for investment into start-ups and roll-out our innovative Help to Grow scheme, which will plug a £1 billion finance gap for firms that are looking to expand, invest and take on new employees.

1_150.text: We will continue to lead the world on tax and transparency

1_151.text: Tackling tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance and tax planning is an important part of our long-term economic plan.

1_152.text: We will increase the annual tax charges paid by those with non-domiciled status, ensuring that they make a fair contribution to reducing the deficit, and continue to tackle abuses of this status.

1_153.text: We will lead international efforts to ensure global companies pay their fair share in tax, as David Cameron did at the G8 Summit in Northern Ireland in 2013, which secured significant international progress on fairer tax rules and full transparency over who really owns companies.

1_154.text: We will push for all countries to sign up to the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative; review the implementation of the new international country-by-country tax reporting rules and consider the case for making this information publicly available on a multilateral basis.

1_155.text: We will ensure developing countries have full access to global automatic tax information exchange systems and continue to build the capacity of tax authorities in developing countries.

1_156.text: We are also making it a crime if companies fail to put in place measures to stop economic crime, such as tax evasion, in their organisations and making sure that the penalties are large enough to punish and deter.

1_157.text: We are fixing the economy so that everyone feels the benefit We will rebalance our economy and build a Northern Powerhouse We are committed to a truly national recovery, benefiting all parts of our country.

1_158.text: We have devolved powers to Scotland and Wales, and set out long-term economic plans to raise the growth rate of all parts of England, bringing areas which have grown more slowly up to at least the national average.

1_159.text: Over the last year, the North grew faster than the South.

1_160.text: By connecting up the North with modern transport links, we will enable its great cities and towns to pool their strengths.

1_161.text: We will invest a record £13 billion in transport for the North.

1_162.text: We will electrify the main rail routes, build the Northern Hub, and provide new trains for the North.

1_163.text: We will upgrade the A1, M62, M1 and A555 link road.

1_164.text: And that is on top of our £50 billion commitment to build High Speed 2 – the new North-South railway linking up London with the West Midlands, Leeds and Manchester – and develop High Speed 3 to join up the North.

1_165.text: We will back scientific and technical strengths by creating new institutions such as Health North; the Royce Institute for Advanced Materials in Manchester, Leeds, Liverpool and Sheffield; the National Centre for Ageing Science and Innovation in Newcastle; the Cognitive Computing centre at Daresbury; and by making investments in energy research in Blackpool, Cumbria and Thornton.

1_166.text: We will back new jobs in the South West To help attract growth and new businesses we will improve connections to the South West with major investment in the M5, A358, A30 and A303, and the electrification of the Great Western Main Line – bringing new fast trains on the route.

1_167.text: We will invest to boost tourism in the South West and ensure the world-class defence assets and cyber-security industries of the South West benefit the local economy.

1_168.text: Britain's exports are growing fastest in the North East and our employment fastest in the North West We will make the Midlands an engine of growth We will back business by investing a record £5.2 billion in better transport, upgrading the M1 and M6, and electrifying the Midland Main Line from St Pancras to Sheffield –putting the Midlands at the centre of a modern, inter-connected transport network for the UK.

1_169.text: We will back the Midlands’ strength in advanced manufacturing, engineering and science with major projects such as the Energy Research Accelerator and support for innovation in the motor industry.

1_170.text: We will properly connect the East of England and back innovation We will improve rail connections to East Anglia, delivering ‘Norwich in 90 minutes’ and ‘Ipswich in 60 minutes’ and upgrade key roads like the A11 and A47.

1_171.text: We will support the creation of new jobs by backing the East’s great strengths – agri-tech, high-tech businesses around Cambridge, and energy businesses at Great Yarmouth and Lowestoft.

1_172.text: We support policies that grow the economy as a whole, generating new jobs and higher wages for everybody We will devolve powers and budgets to boost local growth in England We will devolve far-reaching powers over economic development, transport and social care to large cities which choose to have elected mayors.

1_173.text: We will legislate to deliver the historic deal for Greater Manchester, which will devolve powers and budgets and lead to the creation of a directly elected Mayor for Greater Manchester.

1_174.text: In Cambridgeshire, Greater Manchester and Cheshire East, we will pilot allowing local councils to retain 100 per cent of growth in business rates, so they reap the benefit of decisions that boost growth locally.

1_175.text: We will devolve further powers over skills spending and planning to the Mayor of London.

1_176.text: And we will deliver more bespoke Growth Deals with local councils, where locally supported, and back Local Enterprise Partnerships to promote jobs and growth.

1_177.text: Better roads, trains and modern communications Our commitment to you: You depend on infrastructure at every stage of your life: to go to school, to go to work, to enable businesses to grow and create jobs for your children and grandchildren.

1_178.text: We have a plan of action that will improve our roads, railways, airports and internet connections.

1_179.text: We will: invest in infrastructure to attract businesses and good jobs across the whole of the UK make your life easier, with more and faster trains, more roads and cycle routes keep commuter rail fares frozen in real terms for the whole of the next Parliament roll out universal broadband and better mobile phone connections, to ensure everyone is part of the digital economy.

1_180.text: Under Labour, road and rail were starved of resources, while too many people were stuck on the wrong side of the digital divide.

1_181.text: This meant packed trains, potholes, patchy broadband coverage – businesses held back and cities left behind.

1_182.text: Turning these problems around takes time.

1_183.text: Improving our trains, roads and broadband helps local businesses grow and create more jobs and opportunities

1_184.text: But because we have made savings elsewhere, we have been able to make significant investments in infrastructure.

1_185.text: We will commit, alongside running a surplus, to increase our capital spending – investment in infrastructure – at least in line with our national income.

1_186.text: We have set out a plan to invest over £100 billion in our infrastructure over the next Parliament.

1_187.text: This will fund the biggest investment in rail since Victorian times, and the most extensive improvements to our roads since the 1970s.

1_188.text: And it will give us the most comprehensive and cheapest superfast broadband coverage of any major European country.

1_189.text: We are investing over £2 billion electrifying our railways

1_190.text: Our plan of action: We will spend more on infrastructure, to improve your quality of life Overall public investment will be higher on average over this decade, as a percentage of GDP, than under the whole period of the last Labour Government.

1_191.text: We will deliver on our National Infrastructure Plan and respond to the Airports Commission’s final report.

1_192.text: We will transform our railway network We will invest £38 billion in our railway network in the five years to 2019.

1_193.text: Electrification of the railways is a key part of our investment programme, with work already underway across the North, the Midlands, and South Wales; there are plans to go further in the rest of the country, including East Anglia and the South West.

1_194.text: In addition to rolling out our national high-speed rail network, with High Speed 2 and High Speed 3, we will complete the construction of the new east-west Crossrail across Greater London, and push forward with plans for Crossrail 2, a new rail route running through London and connecting Surrey and Hertfordshire.

1_195.text: We will support a fairer deal for taxpayers and commuters: we will keep commuter rail fares frozen in real terms for the whole of the next Parliament – regulated fares will only be able to rise by Retail Price Inflation, and train operating companies will not have any flexibility to raise ticket prices above this.

1_196.text: We will also introduce smart ticketing and part-time season tickets and require train companies to improve compensation arrangements for passengers when trains are more than a few minutes late.

1_197.text: We are investing millions of pounds in fitting out trains with new wi-fi equipment and improving mobile phone signals, which will benefit passengers on trains across England and Wales.

1_198.text: We will support motorists and invest in our roads, to save you time and money We abolished Labour’s fuel duty escalator, and instead have frozen fuel duty, delivering the longest duty freeze in 20 years.

1_199.text: We will invest £15 billion in roads.

1_200.text: This will include over £6 billion in the northern road network, with the dualling and widening of the A1 north of Newcastle and the first new trans-Pennine road capacity in over 40 years.

1_201.text: We will take action to tackle some of the most notorious and longstanding problems on our road network, including improvements to the A303, A47 and A27.

1_202.text: We will add 1,300 extra lane miles to our roads, improve over 60 problem junctions, and continue to provide enough funding to fix around 18 million potholes nationwide between 2015 and 2021.

1_203.text: We will make motoring greener and promote cycling, to protect your environment Our aim is for almost every car and van to be a zero emission vehicle by 2050 – and we will invest £500 million over the next five years to achieve it.

1_204.text: We want to double the number of journeys made by bicycle and will invest over £200 million to make cycling safer, so we reduce the number of cyclists and other road users killed or injured on our roads every year.

1_205.text: We are investing £790 million extending superfast broadband to rural areas – with 2 million UK premises already connected and 40,000 being upgraded every week We will deliver faster internet, to help you work and communicate more easily We will secure the delivery of superfast broadband in urban and rural areas to provide coverage to 95 per cent of the UK by the end of 2017, and we will ensure no one is left behind by subsidising the cost of installing superfast capable satellite services in the very hardest to reach areas.

1_206.text: We will also release more spectrum from public sector use to allow greater private sector access.

1_207.text: And we have set an ambition that ultrafast broadband should be available to nearly all UK premises as soon as practicable.

1_208.text: We will boost mobile coverage, so you can stay connected We will hold the mobile operators to their new legally binding agreement to ensure that 90 per cent of the UK landmass will have voice and SMS coverage by 2017.

1_209.text: We will continue to invest in mobile infrastructure to deliver coverage for voice calls and text messages for the final 0.3 – 0.4 per cent of UK premises that do not currently have it.

1_210.text: We will ensure that Britain seizes the chance to be a world leader in the development of 5G, playing a key role in defining industry standards.

1_211.text: Jobs for all Our commitment to you: Whatever stage of life you are at – whether you’re looking for your first job out of school, or coming to the end of your career – we will work to help you enjoy the satisfaction and rewards of a decent job.

1_212.text: We will: help businesses to create two million new jobs, so we achieve full employment give businesses the most competitive taxes of any major economy back small firms with a major business rates review support three million new apprenticeships, so young people acquire the skills to succeed If you want to live in the most vibrant and dynamic country in the world, this election matters.

1_213.text: Only the Conservatives have the vision, the optimism, the ambition and the discipline to transform Britain.

1_214.text: That’s because we know that a decent job is the best weapon against poverty and the best way to provide security for families.

1_215.text: Britain has created more jobs than the rest of the EU put together since 2010 Thanks to the success of our long-term economic plan, Britain is creating more jobs than the 27 other countries of the European Union put together.

1_216.text: That means more people with the security of a regular pay packet.

1_217.text: Over the past five years, 1.9 million new jobs have been created; 1,000 jobs for every single day that we have been in government.

1_218.text: This represents a transformation in many people’s lives; giving families more security; boosting the self-esteem of young people taken on; and providing hope for those who have been unemployed for years.

1_219.text: But we need to go further.

1_220.text: We have set out the bold aim of achieving full employment, with the highest employment rate of any major economy.

1_221.text: We want Britain to be the best place in the world to start a business and will create another two million jobs over the next Parliament.

1_222.text: We will abolish long-term youth unemployment, and make sure that all young people are either earning or learning.

1_223.text: And we will make our economy more inclusive, by removing barriers that stop women and disabled people from participating in our workforce.

1_224.text: A job is the best way to provide security for families To achieve this, we will back British businesses: cutting red tape, lowering taxes on jobs and enterprise, getting young people into work, boosting apprenticeships and investing in science and technology.

1_225.text: With the Conservatives, Britain will be the best place in Europe to innovate, patent new ideas and set up and expand a business.

1_226.text: We aim to be number one in Europe and in the top five worldwide in the World Bank’s Doing Business rankings by 2020 and to lead Europe in attracting foreign investment.

1_227.text: Backing business also means helping our farmers and our rural communities.

1_228.text: Neglected for 13 years under Labour, we have started the process of championing and connecting up the countryside.

1_229.text: In the coming years, we will go further, helping our farmers, supporting British food around the world and opening up new export markets.

1_230.text: This is all at risk if the Labour Party forms the government.

1_231.text: Their policies to spend more, borrow more and tax more would be catastrophic for Britain’s businesses – and for all the families thrown back into the despair of joblessness and financial uncertainty.

1_232.text: Our plan will help to generate jobs and higher wages for everybody Our plan of action: We will boost apprenticeships and help you secure a good job We have already delivered 2.2 million new apprenticeships over the last five years.

1_233.text: Over the next five years, we will deliver three million more and ensure they deliver the skills employers need.

1_234.text: We aim to achieve full employment in the UK, with the highest employment rate in the G7, and we will help businesses create two million jobs over the Parliament.

1_235.text: We have abolished the jobs tax – employers' National Insurance contributions (NICs) – for the under 21s and next year we will do the same for young apprentices under 25.

1_236.text: We will continue to help smaller businesses take on new workers through the Employment Allowance, which frees businesses from the first £2,000 of employers’ NICs so that a third of employers pay no jobs tax.

1_237.text: We will support business to keep creating 1,000 jobs a day over the next five years We will aim to abolish long-term youth unemployment

1_238.text: Our economic plan has helped deliver sharp falls in long-term youth unemployment, taking the numbers of 16–18 year-olds not in education, employment or training to historic lows.

1_239.text: We will provide support to those 16 –17 year olds still not in education, employment or training and to those who risk becoming so.

1_240.text: Jobcentre Plus advisers will work with schools and colleges to supplement careers advice and provide routes into work experience and apprenticeships.

1_241.text: But it is not fair – on taxpayers, or on young people themselves – that 18-21 year-olds with no work experience should slip straight into a life on benefits without first contributing to their community.

1_242.text: So we will introduce tougher Day

1_243.text: One Work Requirements for young people claiming out-of-work benefits.

1_244.text: We will replace the Jobseeker’s Allowance for 18-21 year-olds with a Youth Allowance that will be time-limited to six months, after which young people will have to take an apprenticeship, a traineeship or do daily community work for their benefits.

1_245.text: It is also not fair that taxpayers should have to pay for 18-21 year-olds on Jobseeker’s Allowance to claim Housing Benefit in order to leave home.

1_246.text: So we will ensure that they no longer have an automatic entitlement to Housing Benefit.

1_247.text: We will reward entrepreneurship To support jobs, we cut Corporation Tax from 28 to 20 per cent over the course of the Parliament, reduced National Insurance bills and capped the rise in business rates.

1_248.text: We have extended 100 per cent Small Business Rate Relief and are providing extra support for high street shops by increasing the business rates retail discount to £1,500.

1_249.text: In the next Parliament, we want to maintain the most competitive business tax regime in the G20, and oppose Labour’s plans to increase Corporation Tax.

1_250.text: We will conduct a major review into business rates by the end of 2015 to ensure that from 2017 they properly reflect the structure of our modern economy and provide clearer billing, better information sharing and a more efficient appeal system.

1_251.text: We will protect you from disruptive and undemocratic strike action We will also repeal nonsensical restrictions banning employers from hiring agency staff to provide essential cover during strikes; and ensure strikes cannot be called on the basis of ballots conducted years before.

1_252.text: We will tackle intimidation of non-striking workers; legislate to ensure trade unions use a transparent opt-in process for union subscriptions; tighten the rules around taxpayer-funded paid ‘facility time’ for union representatives; and reform the role of the Certification Officer.

1_253.text: Strikes should only ever be the result of a clear, positive decision based on a ballot in which at least half the workforce has voted.

1_254.text: This turnout threshold will be an important and fair step to rebalance the interests of employers, employees, the public and the rights of trade unions.

1_255.text: We will, in addition, tackle the disproportionate impact of strikes in essential public services by introducing a tougher threshold in health, education, fire and transport.

1_256.text: Industrial action in these essential services would require the support of at least 40 per cent of all those entitled to take part in strike ballots – as well as a majority of those who actually turn out to vote.

1_257.text: Britain has the most competitive business tax regime in the G20 –and we want to keep it that way We will cut red tape, boost start-ups and small businesses This Government was the first in post-war history to reduce the burden of regulation.

1_258.text: We will cut a further £10 billion of red tape over the next Parliament through our Red Tape Challenge and our One-In-Two-Out rule.

1_259.text: This will support our aim to make Britain the best place in Europe, and one of the top five worldwide, to do business by 2020.

1_260.text: We will also treble our successful Start Up Loans programme during the next Parliament so that 75,000 entrepreneurs get the chance to borrow money to set up their own business.

1_261.text: We will raise the target for SMEs’ share of central government procurement to one-third, strengthen the Prompt Payment Code and ensure that all major government suppliers sign up.

1_262.text: We have already helped small businesses by increasing the Annual Investment Allowance, reducing the burden of employment law through our successful tribunal reforms and supporting 27,000 new business mentors.

1_263.text: We will go further by establishing a new Small Business Conciliation service to mediate in disputes, especially over late payment.

1_264.text: The gender pay gap is down to a record low – and there are more women on FTSE 100 boards than ever before The creation of the Office of Tax Simplification (OTS) in 2010 has resulted in many improvements to the UK tax system.

1_265.text: We will establish the OTS on a permanent basis and expand its role and capacity.

1_266.text: We will boost our support for first-time exporters and back the GREAT campaign, so we achieve our goal of having 100,000 more UK companies exporting in 2020 than in 2010 and reach our target of £1 trillion in exports.

1_267.text: And we will set a new, significantly higher, permanent level for the Annual Investment Allowance.

1_268.text: We will fight for equal opportunity Last year alone, 140,000 disabled people found work.

1_269.text: But the jobless rate for this group remains too high and, as part of our objective to achieve full employment, we will aim to halve the disability employment gap: we will transform policy, practice and public attitudes, so that hundreds of thousands more disabled people who can and want to be in work find employment.

1_270.text: We now have more women-led businesses than ever before, more women in work than ever before and more women on FTSE 100 boards than ever before.

1_271.text: We want to see full, genuine gender equality.

1_272.text: The gender pay gap is the lowest on record, but we want to reduce it further and will push business to do so: we will require companies with more than 250 employees to publish the difference between the average pay of their male and female employees.

1_273.text: Under Labour, women accounted for only one in eight FTSE 100 board members.

1_274.text: They represent a quarter of board members today and we want to see this rise further in the next Parliament.

1_275.text: We also want to increase the proportion of public appointments going to women in the next Parliament, as well as the number of female MPs.

1_276.text: Our aim is to make Britain the best place to do business in Europe We will back you at work Now that the economy is growing strongly again, we have seen the first real-terms increase in the National Minimum Wage since Labour’s Great Recession began.

1_277.text: We strongly support the National Minimum Wage and want to see further real-terms increases in the next Parliament.

1_278.text: We accept the recommendations of the Low Pay Commission that the National Minimum Wage should rise to £6.70 this autumn, on course for a Minimum Wage that will be over £8 by the end of the decade.

1_279.text: We also support the Living Wage and will continue to encourage businesses and other organisations to pay it whenever they can afford it.

1_280.text: We will also take further steps to eradicate abuses of workers, such as non-payment of the Minimum Wage, exclusivity in zero-hours contracts and exploitation of migrant workers.

1_281.text: We will continue to invest in science, back our industrial strategies and make Britain the technology centre of Europe Great science is worthwhile in its own right and yields enormous practical benefits too – curing diseases, driving technological innovation, promoting business investment and informing public policy for the better.

1_282.text: We ring-fenced the science budget by making difficult choices to reduce spending in other areas.

1_283.text: Now we will invest new capital on a record scale – £6.9 billion in the UK’s research infrastructure up to 2021 – which will mean new equipment, new laboratories and new research institutes.

1_284.text: This long-term commitment includes £2.9 billion for a Grand Challenges Fund, which will allow us to invest in major research facilities of national significance, such as the new Alan Turing Institute, and projects such as the Polar Research Ship and Square Kilometre Array.

1_285.text: We have boosted research and development tax credits and we will continue to support our network of University Enterprise Zones, ensuring that Britain's world-beating universities are able to make money from the technology they develop.

1_286.text: We will support our modern industrial strategies, such as our successful Life Sciences strategy, to help people compete and win in the intense global race for high value, high knowledge jobs.

1_287.text: We will work with the Automotive Council in support of our resurgent car industry and direct further resources towards the Eight Great Technologies – among them robotics and nanotechnology – where Britain is set to be a global leader.

1_288.text: We have delivered a network of catapult centres – R&D hubs in the technologies of the future – and we will create more to ensure that we have a bold and comprehensive offer in place for Britain’s researchers and innovators.

1_289.text: Inequality is down from the record high it reached under Labour We will support the rural economy and strengthen local communities We have the land, the technology, and the entrepreneurial flair to enable us to make the most of the economic potential of our rural areas.

1_290.text: We will provide rural Britain with near universal superfast broadband by the end of the next Parliament and secure the future of 3,000 rural Post Offices.

1_291.text: We know how important it is to preserve vital community assets such as pubs, town halls and sports facilities, so we will strengthen the Community Right to Bid that we created.

1_292.text: We will extend the length of time communities have to purchase these assets, and require owners to set a clear ‘reserve’ price for the community to aim for when bidding.

1_293.text: We will set up a Pub Loan Fund to enable community groups to obtain small loans to pay for feasibility work, lawyers’ fees, or materials for refurbishment, where they have bid to run the pub as part of our reforms to the Community Asset Register.

1_294.text: We will champion our farmers and food producers We will set out a long-term vision for the future of British farming, working with industry to develop a 25 year plan to grow more, buy more and sell more British food.

1_295.text: We will allow farmers to smooth their profits for tax purposes over five years, up from the current two years, to counter income volatility.

1_296.text: We will treble the number of apprenticeships in food, farming and agri-tech, as part of our plan to secure three million more apprenticeships.

1_297.text: We will support a science-led approach on GM crops and pesticides and implement our 25-year strategy to eradicate bovine TB.

1_298.text: We will liberate farmers from red tape by coordinating all visits through a single Farm Inspection Taskforce, which will involve farmers themselves and use data from existing industry schemes, such as Red Tractor.

1_299.text: We will push for further reform of the EU’s Common Agricultural Policy.

1_300.text: We will promote British food abroad by setting up a Great British Food Unit to help trademark and promote local foods around the world and back British food at home, by guaranteeing that all central government departments purchase food to British standards of production by the end of the Parliament.

1_301.text: We will also help consumers to buy British by pushing for country of origin labelling in Europe, particularly for dairy products, following on from our success with beef, lamb, pork and poultry.

1_302.text: And we will champion our new Groceries Code Adjudicator, so farmers receive a fair deal from the supermarkets.

1_303.text: We will support our fishing and coastal communities We will defend our hard-won Common Fisheries Policy reforms, which include ending the scandalous practice of discarding perfectly edible fish and reforming the quota system so that all at-risk species, including cod, plaice, haddock and seabass, will be fished sustainably by the end of the next Parliament.

1_304.text: We will continue to devolve the management of North Sea fisheries to local communities, and rebalance the UK’s inland water quotas to smaller, specific locally-based fishing communities.

1_305.text: We will support countryside pursuits We will protect hunting, shooting and fishing, for all the benefits to individuals, the environment and the rural economy that these activities bring.

1_306.text: A Conservative Government will give Parliament the opportunity to repeal the Hunting Act on a free vote, with a government bill in government time.

1_307.text: Cutting your taxes and building a fairer welfare system Our commitment to you: Our goal is a country that not only rewards those who work hard and do the right thing, but gives everyone – no matter their background – the chance to fulfil their potential.

1_308.text: Achieving this means seeing through our major reforms of tax and welfare.

1_309.text: We will: cut income tax for 30 million people, taking everyone who earns less than £12,500 out of Income Tax altogether pass a new law so that nobody working 30 hours on the Minimum Wage pays Income Tax on what they earn back aspiration by raising the 40p tax threshold – so that no one earning less than £50,000 pays it cap overall welfare spending, lower the amount of benefits that any household can receive to £23,000 and continue to roll out Universal Credit, to make work pay bring in tax-free childcare to support parents back into work, and give working parents of 3 and 4-year-olds 30 hours of free childcare a week.

1_310.text: Under Labour, those who worked hard found more and more of their earnings taken away in tax to support a welfare system that allowed, and even encouraged, people to choose benefits when they could be earning a living.

1_311.text: This sent out terrible signals: if you did the right thing, you were penalised – and if you did the wrong thing, you were rewarded, with the unfairness of it all infuriating hardworking people.

1_312.text: We have cut Income Tax for over 26 million people – and taken over 3 million people out of Income Tax altogether Over the last five years, we have cut people’s taxes wherever possible.

1_313.text: We have raised the tax-free Personal Allowance to £10,600 from £6,475: over 26 million people are now keeping more of their hard-earned money and 3 million of the lowest paid are paying no Income Tax at all.

1_314.text: We believe that cutting people’s taxes is the right thing to do – not only because it is your money, but also because cutting the taxes of the lowest paid and helping them stand on their own two feet is the most effective poverty-tackling measure there is.

1_315.text: Real fairness means that where people really cannot work, they must be supported – but where they are able to work, they should.

1_316.text: We have made long overdue changes to our welfare system.

1_317.text: We have capped benefits so no household can take more in out-of-work benefits than the average household earns by going out to work.

1_318.text: We have begun to introduce Universal Credit – a way to simplify benefits into a new single payment – so that work always pays.

1_319.text: We are reassessing those on incapacity benefits so that help goes to those who really need it.

1_320.text: The days of something for nothing are over – and all this has helped to reduce by 900,000 the number of people living in workless households.
